title: Test All Fonts
body:
This change allows us to render visual diff images for all three fonts.

runNodeTest() now tests all three fonts, and outputs images files with names like:
```
  Accidental.Basic.Bravura.png
  Accidental.Basic.Gonville.png
  Accidental.Basic.Petaluma.png
  ...
  Vibrato.Harsh_Vibrato.Bravura.png
  Vibrato.Harsh_Vibrato.Gonville.png
  Vibrato.Harsh_Vibrato.Petaluma.png
```
This allows us to tweak individual fonts and use `npm run test:reference` to see the changes via visual diff.

title: Possible missing offsetYBaseStemUp: -2,
body:
https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/blob/a61b6f59bcd9376c00bd853573cb3a487bc8264f/src/fonts/bravura_metrics.ts#L149

On my simple tests with EasyScore, I notice that my quarter notes with the stem going up look different from my quarter notes with the stem going down.

I assumed they should be just 180 degree rotations of one another, but the quarter note with the stem going up has a sharp edge where the stem meets the note head. 

When you zoom in on the web page, you see that the stem pokes out a little beyond the edge of the note head. It's not a smooth transition.

I traced it to the bravura_metrics.ts file, and when I add an extra line:

```
      noteheadBlack: {
        offsetYBaseStemUp: -2,    // <--- I added this line
        offsetYBaseStemDown: 2,
      },

```

Then the notes look great and symmetrical. They also match how it looks when I use the Bravura font in Affinity Designer and insert a quarter note with stem going upward.

So should we add this line? Or does it break other things? I am new to VexFlow so I am not sure if adding this line will break your visual regression tests.

Thanks!

title: Migration/ref images
body:
@0xfe Checking against reference images. Instructions:
- checkout master
- run `npm run reference`
- checkout the branch you are working on
- run `npm run test:reference` to check that you did not introduce any visual change compared to master

You can use other commits than master as reference.
The script now also checks that ImageMagick is installed. Failing if it is not.

title: StaveNote constructor is a performance bottleneck
body:
I was profiling my application and I was surprised that the largest chunk of time (about 1/3) is spent in the StaveNote constructor.  Not the formatter (1/6th) or the draw routines (also about 1/3) which I expected.  (the rest is my application stuff).

Is this expected?   The majority of the time is spent in different 'reset' functions and buildNoteHeads.  Also I may be reading the Chrome call diagram wrong.  But this diagram seems consistent with what I observe when profiling the parts of my application that create the notes vs. the parts that render the things.

EDIT:  I realize part of the issue is that I'm setting the stem direction on the constructor, and also calling setStemDirection which just does the same thing.  Once that is fixed, the time spent is less but still significant.  It's not clear why autoStem and reset take so long.  Updated diagram to show this.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5438280/111713415-93cc4900-881d-11eb-8e4e-ecad599ddf5d.png)

title: Use text metrics to calculate annotation widths
body: See my comments in issue #848 .  Use text metrics to calculate the correct width of annotatons for lyrics, etc.

title: Annotations widths are wrong
body:
Annotations assume each character is 7px wide, which is perfect if you are typing in a monospaced 10pt font using all caps :)  The result is usually too wide.

I'm going to be submitting a pull request for a change to use text metrics for annotation widths.   Here's an example, before:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5438280/110631516-37599180-816c-11eb-95c4-0b6e4729b9b2.png)

after:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5438280/110631564-46404400-816c-11eb-8438-31ca10dd4f80.png)

To my eye, these did not change any existing test cases, but all the same I'm wondering if we want to be able to opt out for people who depend on the existing width calculation. 

Also, I have metrics for Arial and Times fonts that I could include with the change (only the ~124 or so us-en ASCII glyphs) that I could include, if you don't think it will be too bloat-y.  If not, it will fall back to one of the existing fonts which will still be pretty close.

title: How can I improve my code which seems poorly constructed?
body:
Hello,
 I'm simulating an accordion keyboard with a button in the HTML code and a "note" note table in the JS part. With each click on the button I add a note in the staff and after 16 notes, a new staff is added below and so on. The code works fine but I have to remove the context each time for each addition of a note (see resetContext function). And also every time I add a scope I have to add a div (see creDiv function) otherwise I delete the previous scope. I think that I am complicating things and that something escaped me in the understanding of vexflow but I do not see. Thank you for enlightening me and suggesting your possible improvements.

You can see the code here --->https://jsfiddle.net/Guy44/68ghLuoj/7/

cordially
Guy

title: formatter.joinVoices is different if called multiple times with multiple voices.
body:
``` javascript
formatter.joinVoices([voice1]);
formatter.joinVoices([voice2]);
```

Does something different than:

``` javascript
formatter.joinVoices([voice1, voice2]);
```
The fiddles show the issue.  It seems the single call is the one that is not behaving correctly, but I'm not sure what the intent was.  
Once difference I see in the code is that, with 2 calls, each tickable at the same location is added to a different modifierContext.  I'm not sure if that is causing the issue, though.

https://jsfiddle.net/AaronDavidNewman/3w1x76m0/
https://jsfiddle.net/AaronDavidNewman/mgfaLxcr/

1 join:

title: how to display the musical notes one by one ?
body:
Hello, 
I just discovered vexflow. I looked at all the tutorials but I couldn't find how to add the notes one by one to the staff. I have a virtual accordion keyboard and I want each key pressed to display the corresponding solfeggio note on the staff. I used the function 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"function writeNote (pitch, rhythm) { 
 document.getElementById ('score'); // add additional if statements to include more rhythmic options if (rhythm === '/ 8') { score.set ({time: "1/8"}) } else if (rhythm === '/ q') { score.set ({time: "1/4"}); } else if (rhythm === '/ h') { score.set ({time: "1/2"}); } system.addStave ({ voices: [score.voice (score.notes (pitch + rhythm))] }). addClef ('treble'); vf.draw (); } " 
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 I get the 1st note, but I cannot display other notes. It seems that each time vexflow expects the number of notes for a measure (4 in my case). If so, is there a solution and if so thanks for your help. 
Cordially 
Guy

title: chordsymbol factory fix, smufl fontgen skip missing glyphs

Unrelated issues 822 and 837, but a small change so I included both.
822: syntax error in ChordSymbol factory.js methods.  I added factory calls to unit tests to verify they work.  
837: smufl_fontgen.js: when generating glyphs for a music font, only create glyphs for fonts present in the font file, so the font stack falls back to other fonts for missing glyphs

title: FontStack not doing what I expect
body:
I was playing around with a new Smufl font called Leland (from the MuseScore people).  It only has about 350+ glyphs atm, so it is missing quite a bit.  When I try to use diminished chord symbols for instance I get this;

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5438280/107889743-42593300-6eda-11eb-8c11-acd34d085916.png)

I thought the point of fontstack was to look in other fonts, if a glyph doesn't appear in the chosen font, and get the font from the next one in the list.  (Edit: my font stack in this example is Leland, Gonville, Bravura, Custom).  Clearly this is not happening.  So my question is:
1. Is this something that the individual modules (e.g. chord symbol, ornament) are supposed to do at draw() time?  or 
2. is there some way to specify this in the font itself, or
3. some other way?

title: Add svg title & description as parameters to renderer for SEO (and accessibility?)

First of all, thanks for your fantastic work on vexflow! I'm building a [scale-lookup app](https://www.scale-lookup.com) with it.

I'd like to have the option of setting the title and description within the svg for the purpose of SEO. I suppose this might also have a value for accessibility. (Possibly I'd also have an aria-labelledby tag - cf. https://css-tricks.com/accessible-svgs/#2-inline-svg)

I guess I could do this and create a PR, but I would appreciate your thoughts before I do. Is this a good idea?

When there are a few chord symbols and many notes, it is often desirable to ignore the width of the chord symbol and let the music flow normally.
With `reportWidth = true:` (default)

With `reportWidth = false:`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5438280/105273601-43a87180-5b61-11eb-8a50-34630f0bacce.png)

This change also uses the new TextFont class for text font metrics, vs reading it from the text fonts directly like I originally did.

title: Add support for drawing lines
body:
VexFlow does not support to add lines below or above the notes. See this example:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29139420/104808823-02befe80-57e9-11eb-865d-c6adf45250c0.png)

In MusicXML i can draw such lines with the following tag:
_Start of a line:_
```
      <direction placement="below">
        <direction-type>
          <bracket type="start" number="1" line-end="none" line-type="solid" default-y="-69.20"/>
          </direction-type>
        </direction>
```
_End of a line:_

```
      <direction placement="below">
        <direction-type>
          <bracket type="stop" number="1" line-end="none"/>
          </direction-type>
        </direction>
```

If vexflow supports to draw such lines, it would be possible to add this feature in the [opensheetmusicdisplay](https://github.com/opensheetmusicdisplay/opensheetmusicdisplay) project, to generate the intended sheet of music with lines.

title: [Suggestion] Make Renderer.Backends a plugin system
Put drawLedgerLines() within stavenotegroup
body:
The call to drawLedgerLines method when put out of vf-stavenote group makes the drawn ledger lines to be not easy to remove from the stave. By keeping them together within the vf-stavenote group, one can remove a note and the corresponding ledgerline by doing just this:

`note.attrs.el.remove();`

title: How to make invisible notes/rests
body:
I have a case where I want to hide the notes in some voices in the beginning of a measure, but still keep the formatting they would provide.  Like for a piano part, when the measure starts out in unison and then splits, it is confusing to have the note twice.
I tried adjusting fill style, but then there are 'holes' in the stave lines since they are drawn first.  I could hack around it by moving the rest to a place where nothing else is, but in a complex score this may not be possible.

I  think what I want is opacity, but the renderer contexts don't seem to support it.  Or is there a different way?  I feel like this is a simple thing I am missing.

![hiderest-snip](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5438280/102721522-ea7ac300-42c0-11eb-8d38-49de4349f87c.PNG)

title: Migrate vexflow sources to Typescript
body:
I migrated all the sources to Typescript. Only tests have to be migrated someday as well. I did not migrate the tests, because it would had made the PR even bigger and more complicated to review. 

Tests are all green, but since a huge amount of files were affected would be nice if you could review and find mistakes.

This is a contribution to the https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/780 issue.

- [x] Seamless for existing users. This migration utilises Vex.Flow namespace in index.ts - so it is should be backwards compatible.
- [x] Use eslint also for ts files
- [x] Check that there are no existing use cases or workflows that will break by moving to TS.
- [ ] Review the TS codebase.
- [x] Check that you can import the typescript classes in javascript without using the minified build.

title: Added support for fingerings in EasyScore
Text Font feature
body:
This is the base component for text font metrics.  I updated the chordsymbol.js module to use TextFont object as an example.  Other than chordsymbol using the new file, there are no other changes or new tests.

There are many places where modules use `this.context.measureText(...)` to get the bounding box of text elements.  In most cases we should be able to substitute the text font object and this should speed up rendering (and also allow applications to use their own fonts).  But I think we should do this on a per-module basis as we'll have to verify the visual regression tests.  Some may change slightly and we may have to create 'opt-in' logic for those.  Also, we may need to include metrics for built-in fonts (e.g. Arial, Times New Roman) since most text formatting in the other unit tests is done using those fonts.

title: Expose font metrics in a standardized way
body:
I propose creating a simple TextFont object that acts as a registry for the default fonts, as well as any other fonts an application may want to use.  The application would register their preferred font metrics in the same way the default ones are registered, and include the font data any way they like (webfont, static, etc.).

Benefits might be:
* use font metrics in other text modules like annotations.  Currently these modules can't calculate the metrics pre-render and have to guess.
* automate basic calculations like width in pixels of a glyph.  If exact metrics are not available for a glyph, use a fallback glyph
* Vex applications can use non-English fonts
* vex applications can create font choosers with available fonts

Registering a font would be like:
``` javaascript
     TextFont.registerFont({
        name: 'RobotoSlabMetrics',
        resolution: RobotoSlabMetrics.resolution,
        glyphs: RobotoSlabMetrics.glyphs,
        fontFamily: RobotoSlabMetrics.fontFamily,
        serifs: true,
        monospaced: false,
        maxSizeGlyph: 'H',
        superscriptOffset: 0.66,
        subscriptOffset: 0.66,
        description: 'Default serif text font to pair with Bravura/Gonville engraving font',
      });
```
Fields like `serifs` and `descriptions` are informational and can be used by applications for font-list dialogs, or permit selecting a fallback font dynamically.

A font instance would be the font metrics combined with a particular font size (which could be changed dynamically).

``` javascript
const myFont = new TextFont({name: 'RobotoSlab', size: 12});
// ...
width += myFont.getWidthForGlyph('w');
```

I considered adding kerning logic here also.   I think that would be good, but what I do in Chord symbols isn't _really_ kerning.  Kerning and ligatures would be another effort.

title: Stem length to middle line
body:
Behind Bars, p. 14: Stems for notes on more than one ledger line extend to the middle stave-line.

Subclasses getStemExtension on stavenote to account for the height of the note.  As notes get further from Mid line (b/4 in t.c.) stems get longer (unless they go the opposite direction).  Does nothing to non-stem notes like whole notes.

Adds new test and visual test:
![StaveNote StaveNote_Draw___StaveNote_Stem_Lengths](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91670380-e5fc8580-eaea-11ea-8175-97a5b9b3e0ec.png)

Fixes behavior in about 18 tests.  Example:

Blessed:
![Clef Clef_Change_Test_Blessed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91670258-b39e5880-eae9-11ea-8164-512c5a7a6d96.png)

New:
![Clef Clef_Change_Test_Current](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91670259-b436ef00-eae9-11ea-93b2-39387a4dfa20.png)

Diff:
![Clef Clef_Change_Test](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91670260-b4cf8580-eae9-11ea-934b-9f8e801c550d.png)

Improves beam angles in several tests:

Blessed:
![Curve Simple_Curve_Blessed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91670271-d16bbd80-eae9-11ea-8333-e17005f88b3d.png)

New:
![Curve Simple_Curve_Current](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91670272-d2045400-eae9-11ea-90a9-c35af187065a.png)

Diff:
![Curve Simple_Curve](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91670273-d29cea80-eae9-11ea-889b-5a46071d3358.png)


It makes more obvious an existing bug in a current test.  The accent mark and the fermata on the last note of the first measure here appear to be on top of each other, but actually they are separated by 1/2 line space, similar to the staccato and accent on blessed g/5 in m. 1.  Solution will come in another PR: while the first articulation can appear in a half-line-space, all additional ones on the same side need a minimum of 1 line space (or need to take glyph-size into account). 

![Articulation Articulation___Inline_Multiple_Blessed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91670296-1263d200-eaea-11ea-9c09-a80f139a38e7.png)
![Articulation Articulation___Inline_Multiple_Current](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91670297-12fc6880-eaea-11ea-8a2d-ff1428beb951.png)
![Articulation Articulation___Inline_Multiple](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91670298-1394ff00-eaea-11ea-9c96-a76964c50210.png)

I believe that this is a fundamental enough improvement to put in first and fix 3-auto-positioned articulations later?

title: Double thickness of Ledger Lines
body:
Elaine Gould in "Behind Bars" notes: "Ledger lines are an extension of the stave. They are spaced the same distance apart as stave—lines, but *they are about twice as thick*"  Ledger lines in Vexflow have always been too thin for my tastes.

Makes default ledge lineWidth double the default staff width.

Obviously breaks many visual regression tests.  Here is a pretty normal change:

Blessed:
![Accidental Automatic_Accidentals___Multi_Voice_Inline_Blessed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91667721-9f9c2c00-ead4-11ea-8e73-0c27fd0b2955.png)

Current:
![Accidental Automatic_Accidentals___Multi_Voice_Inline_Current](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91667723-a0cd5900-ead4-11ea-9d33-5999f87127dd.png)

Diff:
![Accidental Automatic_Accidentals___Multi_Voice_Inline](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91667724-a165ef80-ead4-11ea-830f-2a7b333571d9.png)


On some lineStyles and scales, the rounding in making the PNG makes the line change more obvious:

Blessed:
![Annotation Bottom_Annotations_with_Beams_Blessed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91667741-c9ede980-ead4-11ea-89f0-62aeae7bfd94.png)

Current:
![Annotation Bottom_Annotations_with_Beams_Current](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91667744-cb1f1680-ead4-11ea-99eb-1ccc16e9f517.png)

Diff:
![Annotation Bottom_Annotations_with_Beams](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91667745-cb1f1680-ead4-11ea-99fe-18e68e6542db.png)


This was the only test that explicitly called setLedgerLine style (on the second to last eighth note) -- its ledger line style is respected.  However the stave.lineWidth = 3 -- which is already almost ridiculously thick -- makes even more ridiculous ledger line widths.  Should we set a maximum width above which we do not double ledger line thickness?  Or do people get what they ask for?  I think it looks okay in context.

Blessed:
![StaveNote Stave__Ledger_Line__Beam__Stem_and_Flag_Styles_Blessed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91667758-e12cd700-ead4-11ea-8d25-8ffe50d4dc66.png)

Current:
![StaveNote Stave__Ledger_Line__Beam__Stem_and_Flag_Styles_Current](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91667760-e1c56d80-ead4-11ea-9026-d8237bf81a93.png)

Diff:
![StaveNote Stave__Ledger_Line__Beam__Stem_and_Flag_Styles](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3521479/91667761-e25e0400-ead4-11ea-8975-1a17733f2c3a.png)


Other visual regression test failures have to do with placement of articulations which changed in a recent PR, not this one.

title: Add web components for basic voices.
body:
This PR starts the creation of a web component version of VexFlow. 

At this stage, the web component supports only one system per component, but a system can have multiple staves, which can each have multiple voices. Voices currently only support basic notes (no tuplets, no beams beyond auto-beaming) -- anything that can be parsed by the existing EasyScore parser when using the `score.notes(...)` constructor. 

An example of how the components can be used in HTML is in src/web-components/demo/index.html. The outer element, `vf-score` acts as the "container" for the rest of the elements and executes almost all of the drawing/rendering. For the most part, all of the other elements just create components and add them to the factory renderQ before dispatching an event to their parent element to tell the parent element that they've generated their data. These events are the `<component>ReadyEvent`s inside src/web-components/events. 

The idea for testing was to mimic as many of the existing visual tests as possible. This PR includes one test file that the current state of the web components was capable of mimicking.

title: Use EasyScore with a ShadowRoot element
body:
Hi! I'm interested in using the EasyScore API to a `<div>` element inside a ShadowRoot. Right now, this doesn't appear possible because the `Factory` takes in just an elementId, and the underlying code uses `document.getElementById(elementId)` to create the `Renderer`.

I tested creating a `Renderer` following the native API and passing it in the `Factory` constructor, but that seems to result in an extra blank svg area being created.

I'd be interested in trying to modify the code such that using ShadowRoot elements with EasyScore is also possible, whether that be by passing the actual element or passing in what scope the Renderer should look for the element (document versus shadowRoot). However, I noticed that the Factory, which includes the `elementId` gets passed around quite a bit, and wanted to ask those with more context how complicated a change like this might be.

title: Fix easyscore dots
body:
This PR fixes #782.

```

title: Questions
body:
These aren't necessarily issues with the software. More questions I had.

1. It said music playback was powered by flash. As I'm sure you know Flash won't be supported much longer. Is there any way for that functionality to be implemented with the HTML5 Canvas?
2. So how are you playing music? Are you generating an XML file? What is this file? Does it convert to MIDI. I have found when I am using professionally recording software the MIDI sounds incredibly real. I don't know if I would need to get another MIDI Engine (if that's what it's even called) that sounds better.

I'm not sure where else to post this question.

Formatting issues with annotations
body:
I'm not sure if this is a bug, but it is definitely different that pre-softmaxFactor .  The actual width of a measure can vary greatly depending on some interaction that I don't understand, possibly between the proportions of the note values and the width of the annotations (I use annotations for lyrics).  

In the jsfiddle example, moving the 'z' from the 3rd word the 5th word causes the actual size of the measure to different by about 25%.  But increasing the measure width by about 2% fixes the issue.

In my application (smoosic) it is a real-time music editor, and it relies on estimates to determine system and page breaks.  The estimates don't have to be exact but I expect them to diverge gracefully.  

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5438280/79813978-b8d0e700-8342-11ea-9f17-5c22463fdf1f.png)

Here is a fiddle that demonstrates the problem.
https://jsfiddle.net/AaronDavidNewman/jg8b0vsd/

title: alignment issues with new formatter
body:
I am having issues when aligning voices in different staves, and the note lengths don't evenly match up:

![formatovf](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5438280/79673276-f9dbc680-819d-11ea-99f1-7fcc6bb369a2.png)

If I don't specify the justify width, the overflow doesn't happen but the notes are all scrunched up.  I played around with softmaxFactor but it didn't help this issue very much.  I know what the justify width is supposed to be, but the bounds of the rendered notes end up being way wider than that, whereas before (pre-softmax changes) the notes always fit in the width I specified.

I have a fiddle here:
https://jsfiddle.net/AaronDavidNewman/yrtao9bn/26/

Thanks, love the new fonts btw!

title: How to use TextNotes
How to use opacity to make notes transparents?
Weird misalignment with two voices
Have annotations all at the same y level
body:
I am rendering something like 

![align](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/579771/79076344-a574aa80-7cb6-11ea-9f37-e3d073cee1c6.png)

by simply having the following in a loop
```javascript
var note = new VF.StaveNote({clef: "treble", keys: [upper_note], duration: "q", auto_stem: true });
note.addModifier(0, new VF.Annotation('O'));
note_list.push(note);
```
and then rendering it with
```javascript
voice.addTickables(note_list);
var formatter = new VF.Formatter().joinVoices([voice]).format([voice], 600);
voice.draw(ctx, topStaff);
```

I would like to have all the `O`s aligned on the same vertical position, which I'd be fine to set manually e.g. by beforehand finding the highest note and set that. Looking at the source code

https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/blob/a2acedf0b32e7a22718d30fec6e48a5bc2e429f8/src/annotation.js#L193-L202

what I want does not seem possible, but perhaps it is (I am definitely not an expert in javascript and there may be some trick to force some of those variables to a "wrong" value so that I achieve all the `O`s at the same vertical level).

Alternatively, I could accomplish what I want in a different way, can you suggest options? I thought of:

* Another voice of `TextNote`s
* Another voice of `StaveNote`s with a constant high enough notes (made transparent) and with its own annotation
* Another voice of `StaveNote`s with a constant high enough notes without (or transparent) ledger lines and stems

Unfortunately neither of those work as I'd want (perhaps it's just me but I will submit separate issues about the problems I am experiencing)

title: Drum notation: glyphs inherit from keys above
body:
When I set the bassdrum (f/4) or snare (c/5) the glyphs are inherit from the keys above.
```
          let notes = [
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/4', 'g/5/x3'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['c/5', 'f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/5/x2'], duration: '16' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/4'], duration: '16' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/4', 'f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/4', 'f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['c/5', 'f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
          ];
```
![Screenshot from 2020-04-02 20-22-06](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4282711/78289769-f819ce00-7522-11ea-8793-1fb4795e0319.png)


I've found a workaround to set the glyphs explicit to /n, but don't think this should be normal behaviour.
```
let notes = [
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/4/n', 'g/5/x3'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['c/5/n', 'f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/5/x2'], duration: '16' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/4/n'], duration: '16' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/4/n', 'f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/4/n', 'f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['c/5/n', 'f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
            new VF.StaveNote({ keys: ['f/5/x2'], duration: '8' }),
          ];
```
![Screenshot from 2020-04-02 20-22-34](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4282711/78289792-fe0faf00-7522-11ea-89a4-90e8461d25f8.png)

title: Request: Textnote Figured Bass Continuation Line
body:
In my music theory course, it is sometimes desired to add a line to show that the figures still apply later in the measure, like so:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3662655/77706050-acea4300-6f97-11ea-8c02-7f7544c74d12.png)
or to indicate that a chord has a function other than an inversion (so-called "cadential 64"):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3662655/77706074-ba9fc880-6f97-11ea-8f4d-4e0a1fb0a12a.png)
I know that in issue https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/180 it was shown that the figured bass is possible but I don't think I've seen how to do the lines in the library. Is there a simple way to do this in the library or otherwise?

title: Typescript definitions - Cannot access ambient const enums when the '--isolatedModules' flag is provided
body:
I'm running into an issue with the typescript definitions. When trying to instantiate a renderer, I need to use the enum `Vex.Flow.Renderer.Backends` however I can't because of the following error : 
`Cannot access ambient const enums when the '--isolatedModules' flag is provided`

_This problem also exists for the other enums as well, I am just using the renderer backend as an example as it is mandatory to use it for using vexflow with Typescript._

I am also pretty new to Typescript therefore I'm not sure if I understand everything about enums correctly yet. From my understanding, const enums are replaced at compile time by their value and cannot be used because the object usually created by the enum is not present at runtime. However, this object (and I think all enums from this file) should be available for developers using vexflow. 

**Suggested change**
I suggest to change all `const enum` to `enum` in vexflow type definitions to be able to use them in Typescript. I can work on a PR for this change if you think this is a correct change. If not, please explain to me why as it would greatly help me understand typescript enums better :) 


I can crosspost this issue directly on DefinitelyTyped repo if this is more appropriate.

[LInk to the typescript definition file](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/types/vexflow/index.d.ts)

Thanks

title: ReactJS and VexFlow - joinVoices() issue
Canvas Backend breaks at height > 32767 (browser limit)
body:
Using the Canvas backend, you can resize a canvas to height=32767 and it renders fine, but resize to height=32768 and it breaks, showing this in Chrome:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/75064146-a2471480-54e6-11ea-96e4-bd026ed3cf9d.png)

Try it here:
https://jsfiddle.net/2Lsme8yd/
(setting the height back to 32767 fixes the problem)

This is because browsers limit the size of a canvas element:
https://stackoverflow.com/a/11585939/10295942

(It's funny that they just break without a real error message though.
And that a 16 bit signed integer seems to be the somewhat arbitrary limit. I guess you can fit width+height in one 32-bit register then.)

Btw, there's a npm module canvas-size that tells you the current browser's maximum canvas size, which could be used:
https://stackoverflow.com/a/53677532/10295942

So, @0xfe what do you think would be the best way to deal with this? OSMD logs a warning and simply reduces the height (and width) to the maximum of 32767.
I suppose Vexflow could do the same, outputting a warning with Vex.W(). Or exit with 1? ;)

I can make a PR for this, just wanted to discuss how to proceed first.

title: refactor visual_regression script: warn if no pngs found,…
body:
...and remove unused file results.txt.pass (prevent it from being created then deleted)

i added some checks that the necessary image directories exist and include png files.
When they don't, you get a warning and a hint that you probably forgot running npm run generate:current/blessed.

Before, when the images didn't exist and you can `npm run diff`, the script would output these errors, some of them unhelpful:
```sh
ls: ./build/images/blessed/*.png: No such file or directory
Running 0 tests with threshold 0.01 (nproc=2)...
./tools/visual_regression.sh: line 80: let: _progress=(1*100/0*100)/100: division by 0 (error token is "*100)/100")
./tools/visual_regression.sh: line 81: let: _done=(*4)/10: syntax error: operand expected (error token is "*4)/10")
./tools/visual_regression.sh: line 82: let: _left=40-: syntax error: operand expected (error token is "-")
Progress : [] %./tools/visual_regression.sh: line 98: ./build/images/current/*.png-temp.warn: No such file or directory

Results stored in ./build/images/diff/results.txt
All images with a difference over threshold, 0.01, are
available in ./build/images/diff, sorted by perceptual hash.


You have        1 warning(s):
  Warning: *.png missing in ./build/images/blessed.
Success - All diffs under threshold!
```

Now it outputs something like this:
```bash
Warning: directory ./build/images/current missing.
    Please run npm run generate:current (and if necessary npm run generate:blessed) first.
    Exiting without running visual regression tests.
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! errno 1
npm ERR! vexflow@1.2.90 diff: `./tools/visual_regression.sh`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the vexflow@1.2.90 diff script.
npm ERR! This is probably not a problem with npm. There is likely additional logging output above.

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /Users/simon/.npm/_logs/2020-02-20T19_04_45_103Z-debug.log
```

The npm error output is a bit excessive in my opinion, but i'm not sure it's better to exit with 0 when there was nothing to test.

I can of course make some adjustments to the PR if suggested.

title: Incrorrect x-position when showing Vex.Flow.Repetition.type.DS with "B" key signature
Option for dynamic layout
body:
Hi,

I'm just starting to use this library, and it seems awesome. I'm a bit puzzled about the way staves layout is supposed to work, though.

First, I followed the EasyScore tutorial, but it took me a long time and quite some digging to realize a stave is only supposed to hold one measure. Adding more bars requires adding new staves. Is that correct? If that is, and since it's such an important feature, may I suggest to add this info in a more proeminent place in the tutorials?

I also have some problems understanding how the layout is supposed to work. As far as I can see, in every examples I could find, setting the layout is done manually, by setting absolute coordinates to successive staves.

Let's say I want to display some music on screen with different sizes (e.g a responsive web app). How should I approach it? Is there a built-in way to do it, because I could'nt find it?

Now if someone more competent than I am could just point me in the correct directions, I'd be happy to submit PR to maybe clarify the tutorials to help first-timers like myself.

title: Method for Auto-Tying
body: Hello, I was wondering if there was a method for automatically splitting up notes in a voice that cross beat boundaries. Say I have something like: ``` var notes2 = [ new VF.StaveNote({clef: "bass", keys: ["c/2"], duration: "8" }), new VF.StaveNote({clef: "bass", keys: ["d/2"], duration: "8" }), new VF.StaveNote({clef: "bass", keys: ["e/2"], duration: "8" }), new VF.StaveNote({clef: "bass", keys: ["f/2"], duration: "4" }), new VF.StaveNote({clef: "bass", keys: ["a/2"], duration: "8" }), new VF.StaveNote({clef: "bass", keys: ["b/2"], duration: "8" }), new VF.StaveNote({clef: "bass", keys: ["c/3"], duration: "8" }) ] ``` I'd want it to look something like this:

title: Add `!` to Banner comment
body: Many code minimizers will retain comments that begin with `/**!` or `/*!` so if the code goes through a minimizer (even a minimizer of a minimizer) this will help others keep their license obligations.

title: Setting accidental color
body:
Hi!

I'm wondering if there is any possibility to set color on particular accidentals.
I see that I can do something like 
`notes[0][2].setStyle({fillStyle: "blue", strokeStyle: "blue"})`
but this is setting color also on note head and stem

title: Bug: Key signatures don't update with Stave Clef changes
body:
I'm trying to make a simple selector for a user to set the Clef and Key, but I'm noticing I get the same results with both clefs, that the key isn't considering the set clef.

url: https://music-helper.netlify.com
code: https://github.com/mix3d/music-helper

I'm listening for changes in the dropdown, then calling `setClef()` or `setKeySignature()` on the staff, and then `context.clear();` and `stave.draw();`

If I set the keySignature again after setting the clef, it draws correctly, so this is an order of operations issue (but no API docs sooo... #530 ). I would expect the Staff to update the keySignature correctly when it's Clef changes. 

Example:

title: Security Issue: https-proxy-agent
body: Building a new project with vexflow@latest (v1.2.89 at time of writing) trips 21 _high_ security advisories, all for the sub-dependency `https-proxy-agent` being below 2.2.3: https://npmjs.com/advisories/1184

title: bugfix(svgcontext.js): restore scale on resize & state save/restore
body: Fixes #723

title: Feature: Update renderer to take in a user-created Context type
body:
Since the render contexts are currently hidden from the export, there isn't an easy way to extend context classes at the consumer level (without modifying vexflow source directly).

Assuming a new Context class implements / inherits the needed base Context functions (see `@types/vexflow`s `IRenderContext` class for example), there shouldn't be any reason why the Renderer couldn't handle being passed in a custom Context class to instantiate itself with.

Another way to solve this issue, (that might allow for user error, however), would be to expose the Backend classes somewhere at the root level, such that a developer could extend/override those classes at runtime. 

Either of these could be a solution to #722, letting a dev like myself fix in my own code, making it easier to introduce non-compliant but implementation specific features without having to fork the root project.

title: SVGContext's Scale does not stick after Renderer.resize()
body: A simple update to the resize function to call this.scale() with its own state should be sufficient. I may even submit a PR for it.

Yes this won't be compatible with Canvas, but SVG is superior anyways soooo...

title: is#720 Move npm from package.json dependencies to devDependencies
body:
This implements solution 2 from #720 

This change was made because the npm version used by vexflow (^6.5.0) has a security vulnerability.
npm ^6.50 relies on an old version of a package called 'https-proxy-agent'.
When a user adds vexflow to his project (npm install vexflow), he'll get a message that his project has 21 security vulnerabilities.

This change aims to fix those vulnerabilities by moving npm to devDependencies, which are not downloaded during `npm install vexflow`

title: Remove npm from package.json dependencies
body:
When you install Vexflow (`npm install vexflow`), you will get this message:

```bash
found 21 high severity vulnerabilities
run `npm audit fix` to fix them, or `npm audit` for details 
```

This is exactly the same issue as #653 . Just related to a different version of npm.

Let's run `npm audit` to see what is causing this message about vulnerabilities:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5359825/68082777-00a99380-fe21-11e9-9da5-d4fb3853299c.png)

As you can see in the `Path` row, `vexflow > npm`, this is caused by an old npm version that relies on a version of `https-proxy-agent` package whose version is older than 2.2.3.

This is caused by this line in package.json:

```
  "dependencies": {
    "npm": "^6.5.0"
  }
```

Solutions:
1. Update npm in package.json like #653 did
2. Move npm to devDependencies
3.  ~~(**BEST**) Remove npm from package.json completely and never have to worry about something like this again. Anybody that has downloaded the vexflow project NEEDS to have npm installed anyway, because they wouldn't be able to download the devDependencies for vexflow.~~

npm is downloaded based on package.json, but everybody has npm installed because they installed Node.js (npm comes with Node.js), so why keep it in package.json?

title: Placing a single note at specified X position
body:
Hi,
sorry for opening an issue but I am at a loss how to use vexflow. I tried many things mentioned in the wiki and other issues but I just can't find the right functions.

My Goal is to place a note on a stave at a specified x value while ignoring the space needed for the accidental. The note should stay at the same position whether it has an accidental or not.
I tried to use tick context: `VF.TickContext().addTickable(notes[0]).preFormat().setX(50)` but I don't know how to draw the note onto the stave. Another attempt was to take the example here: [https://jsfiddle.net/7y74r86s/4/](https://jsfiddle.net/7y74r86s/4/) and modify it so that the quarter notes align: [https://jsfiddle.net/1t4a9gmh/13/](https://jsfiddle.net/1t4a9gmh/13/) I the first two notes to be are at the same x position. Also if I don't use ghost notes I get this error `t {code: "IncompleteVoice", message: "Voice does not have enough notes."}` and I have no idea why.

Thanks in advance for you help.

title: Resizing renderer changes SVG's elements positions in DOM
body:
Hey, I've been working on a musical notation app using your wonderful library, but I ran into a problem.

I'm currently implementing adding multiple measures to the score and splitting them into new rows after certain max cap of measures per line is reached. Everything works fine, however I realized that after resizing the renderer to match the number of rows rendered (e.g. initial height of the renderer (with one measure in one row) is 200 px, therefore when you add another row of measures, you need twice that height, etc.) the SVG's elements (`<rect>`s to be specific, but my guess is all of them) change their y, top and bottom positions (after getting them with `getBoundingClientRect()`) by exactly the added height to the renderer (e.g. 200 px). Quite frankly, I'm baffled, because in order to determine the measure the mouse cursor is currently over I'm using it's bar lines positions (which are rendered as `<rect>` elements) and this creates an annoying problem to deal with.

My question is: is it a bug? Or is it a way the renderer is supposed to be working?

title: Simplified visual regression tests
body:
Hello Mohit,
Hope you are doing well, long time no see!

Recently while I introduced VexFlow to my friend, I found the current test can be broken in some cases.

SlimerJS does not provide support for the latest Firefox browser, so if someone already has installed Firefox on the machine, then `generate_svg_images.js` may fail due to the version conflict.

And nowadays there are many better alternative ways to generate images rather than using SlimerJS, so I applied.

I replaced SlimerJS & rsvg-convert to jsdom & node-canvas.
Now jsdom + node-canvas generates png images directly using `tools/generate_png_images.js`

I changed test script dependencies, so current travis-ci test will fail until you release new one.

Thanks,
Taehoon

title: Implemented KeySigNote  #695
body:
The KeySigNote implements that same pattern as TimeSigNote.
A Key Signature that can be used in the middle of a voice.

I'm not at all familiar with the codebase, so I'm not 100% sure of some of the implemention details.
So review carefully :-)

title: Changing the key signature.
body:
I've been trying to find way to change the key signature in the middle of a score, but it looks not possible at the moment.
I'm not that familiar with the code, but a first glance, it looks like the same pattern as ClefNote could be applied to key signatures.
I would be happy to work on this and submit a PR.

title: Add .gitattributes file / update dependencies to latest stable versions
body:
I added a `.gitattributes` file to prevent git from converting LF linebreaks to CRLF when cloning the project on Windows (because of the option `core.autocrlf=true`) to avoid the following eslint error when running `grunt`:

> Expected linebreaks to be 'LF' but found 'CRLF'

> https://eslint.org/docs/rules/linebreak-style#using-this-rule-with-version-control-systems

The second commit is for updating dependencies to latest stable versions. I had to modify two `.eslintrc` files to disable new rules that were applied by default and the `Gruntfile` because the configuration for `grunt-contrib-uglify` changed. I also added the webpack option `libraryExport` to expose the Vex global object in the generated vexflow-debug.js file. I removed the babel plugin `add-module-exports` which was previously used for this purpose.

```

New Test images:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3293067/47884491-46c9c100-de74-11e8-9942-22e13e6a7fdd.png)

- Since, Some layout values(position, size, thickness...) of Multiple Measure Rest componenents are ambiguas, the MultiMeasureRest supports some render_options with rough default values.
- MultiMeasureRest does not implement rendering of description text strings. So, the `"TACET"` text example renders text by using context.fillText().: <https://github.com/sug1no/vexflow/blob/948310a79525d5ead5e2621e34b9e398c4391aa9/tests/multimeasurerest_tests.js#L80>

References:

- <https://usermanuals.musicxml.com/MusicXML/Content/EL-MusicXML-multiple-rest.htm>
- BEHIND BARS:
  - p564 Multiple rests
  - p580 Tacet
- <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rest_(music)>
- <https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tacet>

- <https://usermanuals.finalemusic.com/Finale2012Mac/Content/Finale/Multimeasure_rests.htm>
- <https://musescore.org/en/handbook/measure-rests>

title: rhythm whole note & double whole note display incorrect
potentital bug for auto beam
body:
Hi, Thanks for all the brilliant work that has been done.
When I use automatic beam with easyScore, I found something sort of tricky.
I had a measure with notes: `'c4/q, d4/8, e4/8, f4/q, g4/q'`, I got error `Beams can only be applied to notes shorter than a quarter note.`
Well it works when I just convert the sequence to `d4/8, e4/8, c4/q, f4/q, g4/q`.Not sure if this is by design.
Below is a minimal example.
https://jsfiddle.net/9gqy6due
Another suggestion: is it possible score.beam could neglect errors and just present actual notes without beam?

title: parallelly execute 'rsvg-convert' and 'compare' to reduce execution time
body:
This PR parallelly execute 'rsvg-convert' and 'compare' to reduce execution time as follows:

on my ubuntu vm on w10:

master: 
```shell
$ time  ./tools/visual_regression.sh
...
real	1m15.138s
user	2m36.060s
sys	0m20.897s
```
current:
```shell
$ time  ./tools/visual_regression.sh
Running 293 tests with threshold 0.01 (nproc=8)...
...
real	0m32.919s
user	3m30.496s
sys	0m31.862s
```
- environment variable
  - NPROC: specify number of simultaneous jobs

```
$ NPROC=1 npm test  # limit to 1 process
```

Since, SlimerJs only supports the old Firefox, npm test on my MBP(osx 10.13.6 + Firefox 62) was failed and i gave up.

title: fix(tremolo): offsets depending on stem direction, scale for grace notes
body:
Tremolo x and y offsets were hardcoded for downward stems. (Snare2 test)
Now they depend on stem direction, and size is scaled for grace notes.

add test Percussion Snare3 with upward stems, modify test Snare2 for more tremolo variety
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/47200705-7c03e880-d377-11e8-82e8-86504526c38a.png)

The offsets were also off, here's a comparison [Before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/47200613-2596aa00-d377-11e8-91ca-74c97e25f736.png) and [After](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/47200580-0730ae80-d377-11e8-986a-26285d8cf210.png).
(ignore weird use of the tremolo, this should only show consistency of the offset)

Offsets could be even more consistent between grace notes and stem directions. Though i don't think many people will look at tremolos that closely.

title: New Release?
body:
@0xfe Could we perhaps make a new release? We've had some neat improvements since the last one.
I hope i don't appear impatient, just wanted to ask, and i appreciate all your support.

I assembled a changelog:
```
Change percussion cross note head glyph #641
Add rectangle and square note heads and glyphs #642 PR #645
Detecting custom glyphs (x, d, t etc.) for head width calculation #643
Stem linking correctly for special note heads #646
Clef, TimeSig, Bar: fix large voice bbox #651
fix npm install/audit vulnerability warnings by updating dependencies #653
scale stem length like flag to fix too short stem #644 #649
Add directionless Arpeggio Stroke #658
Grace notes can have articulation #659
```

title: fix(articulation): Grace notes can now have articulation
body:
GraceNotes weren't able to have articulation before, because articulation.js only checked whether the note's category is 'stavenotes', not 'gracenotes'. GraceNote extends StaveNote.

Of course it would be ideal to check whether something is a superclass of StaveNote, but Javascript isn't good enough with type detection and inheritance, right?

Now we can have some funky grace note articulations:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/46533724-f592d580-c8a5-11e8-9ca5-9bbd62c2cdc4.png)

Tests pass.

title: Add directionless Arpeggio Stroke
body:
* Adds a stroke for directionless Arpeggios. (Commits can be squashed to the first message) * Adds a test for them (bottom one): ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/46366828-5f2f9b80-c67c-11e8-8efa-f860e5d38d4b.png) (i tried to simply add that bar to the Brush/etc test, but for some reason another call to vf.notes() lead to a `Note needs a TickContext` error.) * Makes Stroke render after GraceNoteGroup and NoteSubGroup in ModifierContext. Both cases are tested in the new test. Before, the stroke was rendered before grace notes and in-measure clefs (as NoteSubGroup): ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/46365240-5a68e880-c678-11e8-8145-14f393c8ab03.png) * eslint passes, all tests pass. (they also passed before i changed the tests and added mine)
By the way, directionless Arpeggios are the most common in classical music, as they are almost always played from bottom to top anyways. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/46364921-74ee9200-c677-11e8-91c8-653b1068d61c.png) (Mozart Rondo alla Turca, bar 125) (example for classical Guitar: [Fernando Sor Op. 11, no. 6](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/46367927-3066f480-c67f-11e8-90d7-9f041795463b.png)) Can we maybe also have a new release after this? Would be nice just for the npm vulnerability warnings as well.

title: enhancement: also accept canvas context instead of HTMLElement.
body:
This will enable usage of this library in web workers using the OffscreenCanvas API. 

More about this has been discussed [here](https://github.com/opensheetmusicdisplay/opensheetmusicdisplay/issues/396).

The only limitation right now is that this library depends on DOM access. Once it is enabled to accept canvas context, we can move this to web worker and control the canvas from there. 

I can create a PR.

title: How to represent ghost notes in drums
body: In drum notation, ghost notes are represented with the note head surrounded by parenthesis (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghost_note#/media/File:Ghost_note_drumming.png). I see that this notation exists for tablatures, however I was wondering how I could use it with "standard" notation ?

title: chore: fix 20 npm vulnerabilities by updating npm (6.4.1) etc.
body:
This mainly updates npm to 6.4.1. Without this, npm audit shows 20 moderate vulnerabilities when having vexflow as an npm dependency in another project, and 35 vulnerabilities, one high, when doing npm install in vexflow. There shouldn't really be a security concern, but one shouldn't have these warnings then, either.

After this, it's 0 vulnerabilities for Vexflow as a npm dependency in another project, and 4 low vulnerabilities, one moderate for Vexflow devDependencies. All tests still pass, seems like no breaking changes.

`npm audit` now runs automatically at the end of npm install with npm 6.x, and it doesn't look nice to have these warnings when using Vexflow as a dependency.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/45558465-46cc1e00-b840-11e8-9dce-9eb9287e5e09.png)

The npm 6.4.1 update is enough to eliminate these 20 vulnerabilities, so that's the most important change.

The other 5 vulnerabilities from Jscs and grunt-release are only devDependencies of Vexflow, and should hardly be a concern at all.

Npm Audits before/after:
[npm-audits-before-after-dependency-updates.zip](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/files/2383705/npm-audits-before-after-dependency-updates.zip)
Run `npm audit` (npm@6) to check these yourself.
https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/audit
https://docs.npmjs.com/getting-started/running-a-security-audit

Jscs is unmaintained and merged with Eslint, so to eliminate the vulnerability one would have to fork the npm package or switch to Eslint.

For grunt-release, I could ask them to update their dependencies.

If this makes sense and is merged, it would be nice to have a new Vexflow release at some point, but no hurries!

title: Repeat dots create unnecessarily big paths
body:
An example of path created as a top repeat dot:
```xml
<path stroke-width="0.3" fill="black" stroke="none" stroke-dasharray="none" font-family="Arial" font-size="10pt" font-weight="normal" font-style="normal" x="493.43131199999993" y="228.5" width="3" height="41" 
      d="M489.43131199999993 244.5 A2 2 0 0 0 485.43131199999993 244.5M0 0M485.43131199999993 244.5 A2 2 0 0 0 489.43131199999993 244.5M0 0"></path>
```
A more readable path definition:
```
M 489.43131199999993 244.5
A 2 2 0 0 0 485.43131199999993 244.5
M 0 0
M 485.43131199999993 244.5
A 2 2 0 0 0 489.43131199999993 244.5
M 0 0
```

The dot is displayed correctly, however because of the two `M 0 0`, the bounding box is much larger than it needs to be. Because of this it's impossible to use bounding box to determine the actual sheet size in order to remove the unneeded whitespace.

title: EasyScore vs. VexTab?
body:
Hi, I've been re-acquainting myself with VexFlow after a couple of years away. I'm now considering it for some notation rendering projects at SightReadingMastery. I'm glad to see that the VexFlow project is still alive and receiving active contributions.

A couple years ago VexTab looked like the go-to high-level language for creating scores with VexFlow. However, it now appears from GitHub that the VexTab project isn't very active, and the VexFlow documentation references EasyScore instead. (Although www.vexflow.com still features VexTab prominently.)

Am I right that EasyScore replaces VexTab for most purposes? Or do they solve different problems? Some clarification about the status/relationship of EasyScore and VexTab would be appreciated.

title: CanvasContext can't draw (colored) rectangles
body:
SVGContext does this fine, but canvascontext.clearRect() only draws transparent rectangles, and rect() does nothing.
You can see for yourself in this [fiddle demo](https://jsfiddle.net/sschmidTU/jvw0ecxz/).
(or see [this screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/43590362-1c111972-9671-11e8-837a-07e99c14fdb7.png))

I looked at the code and tried hard to fix it, but no cigar. I tried to set the backgroundFillColor in CanvasContext in multiple ways.

I also don't fully understand the way the context object is handled in canvascontext. In the constructor it saves a context object as a new property under a new name, and then uses it for all draw calls. Does it use the functions in SVGContext? Or RaphaelContext? It's a lot of duplicate code as well.

What i want to use this for is drawing a rectangle as background for the Canvas image, which by default is transparent. Using Canvas, you can right-click on the image and save it, but you'll get a transparent background instead of white, so you need more image editing. It's not as convenient to save an SVG as image, unfortunately.

If we can fix this, i'll add visual regression tests for colored backgrounds.

title: SMuFL mappings in tables
body:
Hoping that this will be a useful contribution for an eventual push to allow for the complete SMuFL font plug in, letting a smooth transition from Gonville to SMuFL font plugin take place.  Gives a mapping for almost all glyphs from SMuFL names to Vexflow codepoints so that these can start being replaced in the hardcoded code and then eventually using the existing .json files, other SMuFL fonts could be used for an extended character set.

This pull request only contains the mappings for SMuFL to Gonville.  Next possible steps include allowing any glyph to be accessed in places such as TextNote and lyric annotations using the SMuFL name.  Then replacing references to codepoints to SMuFL names, and then creating plugable fonts.

A step towards #349 and esp. #350 ("SMuFL glyph name (eg: `accidentalSharp`) for the respective VexFlow Gonville glyph identifiers (eg: `vb9`)")

7 glyphs in Gonville could not be mapped -- three seem to be duplicate notehead glyphs (e.g., noteheads that are the same for quarter as for eighth and smaller notes), two are accidentals that cannot be found in the extensive SMuFL list (slashed double flat, v90, and an alternative 3/4 sharp, v7a), an unused marcato alternative? v5a, and an alternate positioning for a down arrow (v11).

title: fix NoteSubGroup x-shift each render
body:
Before, NoteSubGroup x-offset was reapplied every render, similar to what was mentioned in #632:
```tick_context.setX(x + x_offset);```

This resulted in NoteSubGroups moving x-wise every draw():
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/43330515-b608e5f8-91c3-11e8-95eb-c2d4644c26aa.png)

I improved and reapplied the fix from #632. Now, GraceNoteGroups and NoteSubGroups use the same align function in modifier.js, whereas before they both had an align function that was duplicate code. I tried moving the alignment to a format method, because it should rather be there than in draw(), but when i tried it seemed like it was too early and didn't work.

In TickContext I added the possibility to represent x-positioning as base x plus offset, so we can simply overwrite the x-offset and not apply the x-offset of the previous draw()-call to the next one.

This could be a good method to use in general, though it'll still be possible to simply get and set x in TickContext.

This PR fixes both in-measure clef (as NoteSubGroup) and grace note rerender shift in [OSMD](github.com/opensheetmusicdisplay/opensheetmusicdisplay/).

All Qunit tests pass btw.

title: Fix dotted note dot y-shifting each draw
body:
Before this fix, dotted note dots get y-shifted a half line each render/draw:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/43258353-cc1b999a-90d2-11e8-97dc-edf9a974b513.png)
We redraw a lot in OSMD compared to Vexflow tests, so we noticed [this issue](https://github.com/opensheetmusicdisplay/opensheetmusicdisplay/issues/300) pretty quickly.

The bug was introduced by [fixing quarter dotted rest dot positioning](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/commit/298cd8813e0a545c31fb312bd9f7dfa31e634e17) ([#607](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/607)).

Rest note and stave note shiftY seem to be handled differently, stave notes apply the previous y-shift incrementally while for rest nodes you can add to the y-shift every draw without misplacement.
So the dot_shiftY maybe should be refactored to operate the same for stave notes and rests (= vs +=), but this fix handles the difference for now.
All visual regression tests pass and i haven't noticed other issues, using this for a while in OSMD.
Dotted notes are perfect now.

By the way, most physical sheet music editions use a quarter plus eigth rest instead of a dotted quarter, easier to read and can align with other notes in the staff.
Beethoven Sonata Op. 106 "Hammerklavier" beginning:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/43258732-0dfda8e8-90d4-11e8-9ceb-69018d7b2d99.png)

title: Fixed gracenote offset after redraw
body:
Hi,

we had some problems in opensheetmusicdisplay/opensheetmusicdisplay#293 that grace notes shifted to the right everytime we redraw stuff. We do this a lot because we can zoom in and out and also add debugging layers on top. Anyways I found that the GraceNoteGroup does this ```alignGraceNotesWithNote``` everytime it draws, thus adding the offset again and again which causes the whole group to shift.

My fix checks if the group is already aligned and skips that. It's rather quick and dirty (adding a prop after creation) but so is the mentioned function. Why is there formatting done during draw anyways?

title: Calculate notes left to fill the voice
body:
Hopefully this is the right place to ask "newb" questions.

I'd like to be able to add notes to a voice interactively while still keeping the correct number of notes to fill the voice. What I have done now is creating a method that calculates the number of notes "left" to add in the voice and filling the rest with silence.

For example, let's say I have a voice with a time signature 4/4. If my user adds a 1/4 note, then I add a 1/2 and a 1/4 silence, which all adds up to "1", and fills the voice correctly.

Now, I'm wondering if what I'm doing isn't completely overkill and if there isn't something already done in Vexflow? I've managed to make it work correctly, but wondering if it was the best approach.

Still about the voices, how do you "auto-beam" notes that are in a voice? The examples doesn't show the use of auto beam with voices.

Another question, not related, is that I'd like to add a second stave under the first one with a second voice. I can't find any example anywhere on how to do this.

title: Delayed ornaments get shifted to the left instead of right
body:
Doing setDelayed(true) on a VF.Ornament, the ornament gets shifted to the left, instead of halfway between the corresponding note and the next one.
Here, the red arrows point to where the delayed ornaments should be placed:
![delayed_ornaments_bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33069673/42347618-b585f70c-80a6-11e8-8b3d-d14a2fcc53a9.png)
(the first turn is not delayed, so it's placed correctly)

I set up an interactive code demo on jsfiddle that you can modify and see that setDelayed(true) will always cause this issue:
https://jsfiddle.net/sschmidTU/6es9n407/

~~The issue is probably in `if (this.delayed)` in ornament.js~~
Edit: this part seems fine,

There are two other bug sources with signatures and multiple bars, see comment below.

I'm trying to fix it and make a pull request, though i'm having runtime issues with my VexFlow build (TickContext).

Issue #376 - add .editorconfig
body:
Addressed #376 and added the .editorconfig. As you're extending airbnb as a base for eslint, I used their base editorconfig with an additional line so trailing whitespace isn't trimmed in .md files. The rest is standard.

```
root = true

[*]
indent_style = space
indent_size = 2
charset = utf-8
trim_trailing_whitespace = true
insert_final_newline = true
end_of_line = lf
# editorconfig-tools is unable to ignore longs strings or urls
max_line_length = null

[*.md]
trim_trailing_whitespace = false

title: How can I show single note?
First pass at API documentation
body:
Fixes #530 

This implements API documentation for VexFlow. It's not adding any new
prose - only converting existing comments to JSDoc-style comments,
moving certain comments to position them correctly.

Adds one new dependency:

- documentation

Adds two new npm run scripts:

- dev-docs: build & serve HTML docs
- docs: build Markdown docs into API.md

Adds documentation output: API.md

---

Note that my time commitment here needs to stay pretty low: I have a
full-time job, significant side projects, and ongoing open source
commitments, so I don't have the bandwidth to get to 100% documentation
coverage or anything like that.

But I think this PR as it stands is enough for new contributors to jump in,
add more documentation, and find more old-fashioned comments that can just be
converted to JSDoc and start showing up in the docs.

title: svgcontext: remove some attributes when possible
body:
svgcontext generates some additional attributes.

please refer to the following uri:
https://jsfiddle.net/jc5tut2f/

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<svg width="500" height="500">
   <path stroke-width="1" fill="none" stroke="#999999" stroke-dasharray="none"
     font-family="Arial" font-size="10pt" font-weight="normal" font-style="normal"
     d="M10 80L410 80" />
...
   <rect stroke-width="0.3" fill="black" stroke="black" stroke-dasharray="none"
    font-family="Arial" font-size="10pt" font-weight="normal" font-style="normal"
    x="10" y="79.5" width="1" height="41" />
...
   <path stroke-width="0.3" fill="black" stroke="none" stroke-dasharray="none"
    font-family="Arial" font-size="10pt" font-weight="normal" font-style="normal"
    x="410" y="79.5" width="1" height="41" d="..." />
...
   <text stroke-width="0.3" fill="black" stroke="none" stroke-dasharray="none"
    font-family="Arial" font-size="12pt" font-weight="normal" font-style="normal"
    x="79.90079999999999" y="70"
    width="1" height="41">Render this</text>
...
</svg>
```

* the following attributes can be removed?:

- [x] {path, rect}.font-{family, weight, style, size} : #628
- [x] path.{x, y, width, height} : #628
- [x] text.{width, height} : #628

title: Passing DOM element to Factory's renderer.elementId param
body:
I am wondering about the EasyScore example, and how you configure the renderer by means of the Factory.

Because I am using React I don't want to use `getElementById`, but get the DOM element with React Component's `ref` attribute

Although the Factory explicitly asks for a `elementId`, I see in Renderer that it is still ok to pass the element itself.

```
    this.element = document.getElementById(elementId);
    if (!this.element) this.element = elementId;
```

Can I safely assume this option will remain available in the future?

title: How to center a single note
Notes with both custom glyph and microtonal accidental
body:
I want to use diamond noteheads (available via [these glyphs](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/blob/2ab00d3496167bced338a8be0c5f2396a01e3c58/src/tables.js#L180-L185)) with microtonal (quarter-tone) accidentals.

The only way I have found to create a note with a diamond notehead is via `Flow.keyProperties()`, and the way to get to that is by creating a `StaveNote` with `keys`.

But `Flow.keyProperties()` doesn't allow all the accidentals in [`Flow.accidentalCodes.accidentals`](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/blob/e107adf1b7c4512b4ec73d46b0e607332b5535b8/src/tables.js#L277). It uses [`Flow.keyProperties.note_values`](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/blob/e107adf1b7c4512b4ec73d46b0e607332b5535b8/src/tables.js#L127) instead, which only allows chromatic accidentals.

For example:

```js
// Works (G sharp)
new VF.StaveNote({keys: ['G#/4/D0']})

// Doesn't work (G three-quarter flat)
new VF.StaveNote({keys: ['Gdb/4/D0']})
```

I was able to create notes with the microtonal accidentals via `EasyScore.notes()`. But that option doesn't accept a glyph code (for the diamond).

So unless I'm missing something, it seems I can't have both.

I'd happily work on a PR, if you can confirm that functionality is missing.

I was able to build after Gregory Ristow's fix of webpack dependency a couple of weeks ago, but now webpack does not build for a different reason.  On both Windows 7 and Windows 10 I get:

> Running "eslint:target" (eslint) task

Also I know we are using an old version of webpack - I am able to build the latest version by itself.

title: Ledger Line Logic
body:
Fixes #566, fixes ledger line formatting issues remaining in #557.

Changes:
- Ledger line drawing is now handled entirely by `StaveNote`
- All ledger line logic is removed from `NoteHead`
- Ledger lines are now drawn with the same style of the staff they're related to
- If both displaced and non-displaced notes are present above or below the staff, ledger lines are drawn for both positions until no longer needed in either position.
- `Stave.setStyle()` is now available to match the api's of other `Element`s.
- `StaveNote.setLedgerLineStyle()` uses `Stave.getStyle()` as its default style, merging onto it any changes.

This results in two obvious visual changes throughout with ledger lines:
- Ledger lines are now thinner than before (1px, matching Vex.Flow.STAVE_LINE_THICKNESS)
- Ledger lines are now colored as `#999999` by default (matching `Stave.options.fill_style`'s default).

Before:
![annotation bottom_annotations_with_beams_blessed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8905340/28747012-a2bc008a-7463-11e7-8c7a-d5305c10557c.png)
After:
![annotation bottom_annotations_with_beams_current](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8905340/28747013-a5fa6b9c-7463-11e7-9a86-30a3c64fa154.png)

To my eyes, I really appreciate the consistency of style between the ledger lines and the staves. However: I find myself wondering if `#999999` is too light of a default now that the ledger lines are the same color and thinner. Thoughts?

Finally, the NoteHead Bounding Boxes test loses a ledger line because this logic is moved into `StaveNote`. This isn't a grave concern to me -- I think it's pretty unlikely anyone is using VexFlow in a way that they're relying on `NoteHead` to draw a ledger line. (And, anyway, it would only ever draw the final ledger line before a note -- not all of the ones between the note and the staff.)

Before:
![notehead bounding_boxes_blessed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8905340/28747057-94f58286-7464-11e7-917c-f483bbee811c.png)

After:
![notehead bounding_boxes_current](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8905340/28747059-99c88f1a-7464-11e7-8328-5c2ecdbb1008.png)

That said: if anyone sees an issue with consolidating ledger lines in `StaveNote` please let me know. I'll hold off on merging this for a few days.

Thanks!

title: Ledger Line Logic
body: Currently, when a `StaveNote` has an offset `NoteHead` ledger lines are drawn in the normal (non-offset) position between the note & the staff, but not at the offset position except the last ledger before the offset `NoteHead`: ![screen shot 2017-07-27 at 7 12 41 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8905340/28695829-967beeb2-72ff-11e7-8557-204a76358e40.png) ![screen shot 2017-07-27 at 7 12 32 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8905340/28695830-997d46b0-72ff-11e7-9a40-3ebbf184f463.png) Instead: if any notehead is offset, all ledger lines should be drawn at the width of the normal ledger plus the offset ledger, until there are no more notes at the normal position or the offset position beyond the range of the staff:

Hello Everyone
I have been using VexFlow for a long time, from an old version, for [BandPad project](https://bandpad.co/livescore/score/AlKolEle/he?tunePass=8b40e36e6f933f3639102c0695208238d25be42d1e903cd5253c9bbe0e259ff89c9e70a0e8fb635d052aa93e3ffb0233) .
After some years I'm trying to update the code to the current version and I ran to this problem:
The formatter doesn't take the clef and the time signature as part of the measure when spacing the notes in the measure.

This is how Finale space the Vex example
![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4021701/28511558-745c271c-7056-11e7-8d9a-9b9634d68eea.jpg)
The last quarters are spaces from the end of the bar, this space is equal to one-quarter.

This is how Vexflow space same example
https://jsfiddle.net/8eckj32x/13/
No space

If I remove the clef and the time signature and that problem is gone
https://jsfiddle.net/amitgur/09cdeavg/

Any help with that problem

title: How do I match score graphic elements to my data model?
body:
Hello all,
First and foremost, thank you for keeping this alive. 

I am working on a desktop music application built using Adobe AIR, that involves (as a secondary task) displaying and editing a musical score. I have been using abcm2ps.exe so far for rendering the score, but I consider switching to Vexflow.

My need, put in one phrase is: assuming that I have my own data model that represents the score, how do I annotate each visual element generated by Vexflow (measure, clef, note, etc.) so that, when user clicks on the visual element, I can figure out that s/he wants to deal with a specific item in my data model?

Notes:
(1) I cannot use the SVG rendering mode; due to Adobe AIR limitations, I'm stuck with Canvas.
(2) I have read the Vexflow tutorial and found nothing that could work with Canvas (I might be wrong, though).

Thank you kindly,
Claudius Tiberiu Iacob

The missing dependency is added here.

title: Can't obtain Notehead Bounding Box
body:
After everything is formatted, my_notehead.getBoundingBox() gives the error "Can't call
getBoundingBox on an unformatted note.", because my_notehead.preFormatted is set to false.
However, there are four variables needed for the calculation, all of which are returning good values -- therefore the bounding box should be obtainable!

The variables are:
my_notehead.stave.getSpacingBetweenLines() 
my_notehead.getAbsoluteX()
my_notehead.width
my_notehead.y

![oriented](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16670803/27511228-a098737e-58ed-11e7-9c6a-9faa12505ba6.png)
(The attached picture shows why this is needed -- this illustration has to do with melodic pitch-shape: lines between notes should be oriented down or up, according to melodic direction, but this would only work with the bounding box on the notehead, not on the stavenote!)

title: Tuplets -- single-note tuplet // for notating unusual rational rhythms
body:
I'm setting up to use the powerful tuplet support supplied by @gristow to try to notate some unusual rhythms. 

I'm wondering why an error is thrown if the list of notes to be tupletized has length 1. The error is thrown from a check early in the tuplet process, before it's clear that it's really going to cause any problems.

I think it makes sense to have tuplets of length 1, e.g. if I have a single note of duration 1/7 and I want to notate it as an eighth-note, then I need to multiply it by 8/7.

Here's my general idea about how to notate the kinds of rhythms I'm working with.
Example measure durations: (1/7, 1/7, 2/9)
The sum of this is 32/63, so we can make an approximate measure of 2/4 time and tuple the whole measure by 64/63 to make it fit. This gives:

   
|------64/63-----------|
9/64 9/64 7/32

This is notatable, but in the general case it may not be, and anyway it would be better if the notes looked simple. So we can add a second (inner) layer of tuplets for each note/group of notes, to approximate them to (e.g.) eighths. 


    
|---------64/43-------|
|----9/8------||--7/8----|
  1/8 1/8 -------    1/4
 
Now everything adds up and is notated in "square" measures and notes.

---
One further thing would be to be able to change the way the tuplets print their numeric labels. The above is not clearly legible as (1/7, 1/7, 2/9). This means decoupling the label from the actual multiplier and allowing the user to specify it directly, overriding the default. E.g. we could relabel to show the true duration of an eighth-note.

    
|---1/7-------||----1/9--|
  1/8     1/8 -------  1/4

title: Webpack dependency is incompatible with current config object
body:
In `package.json`, the Webpack dependency is specified as `"*"`. It installs version 2.x, with breaking changes in the config object - so the VexFlow build is interrupted with an error.

**Changing the Webpack dependency to `"1.*"`** got the build to complete.

Perhaps this can be included in PR #525? Updating the config object to Webpack 2.x might take some effort.

title: Fretboard diagrams
body:
I am submitting a feature request for fretboard diagrams :-) 

Rationale (if you need one) : As a guitarist, fretboard diagrams are useful to specify not only the chord being played, but also the *voicing* of the chord, and it allows the notator / arranger to suggest a suitable hand position. Specifying all this info with regular notation alone is not ideal, and using tab notation is too restrictive for passages that are better notated with actual music (for example, melodies in a lead sheet).

Ideally the fretboard diagram API would allow the notator to specify an unambiguous voicing and to have some control over the parameters of rendering. This means: 

- fret / string positions of the notes
- number of frets to show (default is usually 4)
- label in front of specific fret(s) (usually numbers in Arabic or Latin numerals)
- number of strings to show
- tuning of each string
- diagram scaling factor
- diagram location offset
