title: Formatting order needs to be rethought
body:
Ok so now that we'll soon have staves set on elements before formatting, we'll be able to freely convert between pixels/staff spaces and do all positioning of elements in `Formatter#format` and the various formatting hooks.

Unfortunately, we still have some major issues around this:

1. We can't format modifiers (ie: articulations) vertically until stem tips have been finalized
2. Stem tips can't be finalized until beam slopes have been calculated
3. Beams slopes can't be calculated without x positions on the notes
4. We only have x positions after all modifiers have been formatted, and the tick contexts have been formatted (This is why stem tips are currently calculated in `Formatter#postFormat`)

I'm fleshing out some thoughts on this, but they'll likely be pretty radical :P

title: Lint tests; Enable dot-location eslint rule;
body: [See rule documentation for details](http://eslint.org/docs/rules/dot-location). This now enforces the dot operator to be placed the same line as the property being accessed. All lingering occurrences of this style have now been fixed.

title: What is your use case for VexFlow? How well has VexFlow worked for you?
body:
Hi everyone, I wanted to get an idea of how everyone is using VexFlow. Particularly to help guide my contributions to the project. Some granularity in how your system hooks together is useful.

For a personal project, I used VexFlow as the formatting/rendering layer to build a music notation editing engine. I designed my own "model" layer, which was manipulated by a user, and I rebuilt/formatted/drew VexFlow objects whenever that model changed. Since my primary concern was prototyping iterating on a web-based notation editor, I was not concerned with flexibility around visual quality or styling. VexFlow worked quite well for this, but I also have a comprehensive understanding of the codebase.

At my current job at [Tido](http://tido-music.com/), we built a dynamic notation renderer with a highly modified build of VexFlow. Again, VexFlow objects were generated from a data model. This rendering engine appears in the iPad app [Mastering the Piano With Lang Lang](http://masteringthepianowithlanglang.com/). But even for Level 1 of the series (ie: basic educational piano), VexFlow proved to be inadequate for the quality and flexibility we required. So we only used it as a glorified glyph painter and wrote our own spanning elements (eg: hairpins, slurs) and our own formatting pipeline.

title: System and Factory don't really work together
[Breaking Change] Require stave to be set before formatting StaveNotes
body:
This shouldn't get merged in until we have an agreed way forward for the next string of releases. Things like the tutorials/jsfiddles will need to be updated.

- `StaveNote#preFormat` throws if no stave is set
- Renamed `StaveNote#setStave` to `StaveNote#updateStave` as per the discussion in #412 
- `Voice#draw` throws if passed a `stave`, to notify the user that this pattern is not valid.

title: StaveNote.formatByY incorrectly shifts top voice
body:
In `stavenote_tests.js`, this causes incorrect output for the test: `StaveNote: Center Aligned Notes - Multi Voice`

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/21508973/d6982c56-cc7c-11e6-927b-408bad9eaa86.png)

`formatByY` determines that the measure rest and the first `b4` have a vertical collision and shifts the `b4` to the right.

title: Review Tuning data structure
body: See https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/355 for start of discussion.

title: VexFlow needs an API reference - JSDoc comments
body:
The current documentation is really lacking. The linear style really doesn't work for VexFlow. Without a proper API reference, a project of VexFlow's complexity is very difficult to use in an in-depth manner. While [JSDoc comments](http://usejsdoc.org/about-getting-started.html) are cumbersome, I think the benefits outweigh the costs. 

* The generated docs will be of much higher quality (ie: hyperlinked symbols)
* Tooling can take advantage of the data
* We can more explicitly declare what is private/public, and generate public-only docs
* ESLint has a [`valid-jsdoc`](http://eslint.org/docs/rules/valid-jsdoc) rule to enforce a basic level of quality.

[documentation.js looks interesting](https://github.com/documentationjs/documentation)

title: Rename `selector` to `elementId`
body: Pretty much every occurrence of the name `selector`/`sel` is incorrect. [The `Renderer` class uses `document.getElementById` to get a DOM Element](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/512/files#diff-5326222f837d36fd2bff476584c07621R129) so in fact passing in a valid selector wouldn't even work. An id on its own, eg: `'container'`, is not the same as a selector which uses an id, eg:  `'#container'`.

title: Fix blurry canvas rendering on retina screens
body: Use `window.devicePixelRatio` when setting up canvas

title: API documentation doesn't work
body: The link on the wiki just leads to a file listing that doesn't contain any trace of API documentation.

title: No file extensions on import statements
body:
When modules are a proper, browser-supported thing, a statement like:
`import { Stave } from './stave';`
...will likely 404 since ./stave isn't a file.

I think it would be best (read: future-proof) if these imports pointed to actual files?

title: Reset noteheads when `StaveNote#setKeyLine` is called; Refactor threevoice_tests.js;
body:
Take a look at the diffs. They are significant due to the new test setup affecting the automatic rest alignment.

Some of these tests relied on formatting code that was executed *only if* missing a stave (which really doesn't make sense to me why any kind of multi-voice formatting would be attempted in this case). Anyway, we are soon making this an invalid state. So now, the rests are formatted by code that formats StaveNotes with a stave. But the output is not good. The vertical adjustments will have to be completely rewritten to take real bounding box metrics into account (but this can only happen once the new stave requirement is in place), and changes will need to be made to support >2 voices.

See comment in code for more details.

title: Fixed bar width support ?
body:
Is there a way to tell the formatter to use a fixed amount of width for each bar ?

This improves rhythm pattern readability.

title: Experimental idea for EasyScore
body:
Currently EasyScore has one potential point of extension called `commitHooks` (introduced in https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/426).

This is:
* perfect for stuff like attributes
  * eg `c#4/4[id="note1",class="red"]`
* constraining but acceptable for simple modifier cases
  * eg: `c#4/4[articulations="staccato.above,marcato.below"]`
* not useful for anything complex
* executed inline with parsing, so we can't expose anything ahead of the current position

With tagged template literals we could mix JavaScript expressions within the EasyScore language. 

Total Strawman:

```javascript
easyScore`
  (a4 e5 f5)/16
    ${modify({
      0: vf.Fingering({ number: '1', position: 'left' }),
      2: vf.Fingering({ number: '4', position: 'above' }),
    })}
  e5, e5 ${link(vf.Tie)} e5, e5/8, e5, e5/2
`;
```

In this example `modify` and `link` are higher order functions that return a function which will be passed something like: `(prevNote, nextNote, allNotes)`. In order to expose all parsed notes, these transformations would be run after all entire line has been parsed.

Thoughts?

title: Refactor StaveTie tests
body:
~So I really got a little more experimental... but I think this managed to reduce boilerplate really clearly and isolates the parts being tested.~

~I've always found the string+test mapping in each `Start` function to be pretty annoying. So I got rid of it and rely on iteration through the keys using a `runModule` test helper.~

~Definitely looking for feedback on this!~

Also bug https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/489 was found during the course of this refactor.

title: Add TextBracket to Factory; refactor TextBracket tests
body: Note the destructured `TextBracket` constructor parameters. I'm personally very fond of this pattern (I use it extensively with my React projects since all React components take a single `props` object). Makes default values really convenient without cluttering up the assignments in the body.

title: Widely spaced, beamed notes cause incorrect beam slopes
body:
These beams are seen in the `tradeoffs` test in `tests/beam_tests.js`

Here are some beams formatted to a 300px width:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/21288478/01721238-c47c-11e6-8903-ea37919a8eb8.png)

Here are the same beams formatted to a 500px width:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/21288480/0ddb9940-c47c-11e6-9016-dabe6207d9c3.png)

The first beam became very slanted (although not incorrect, just ugly). The second beam's slope is going in the wrong direction.

Originally discovered in PR https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/456

title: Question: is vexflow suitable for real-time music notation?
body: For an experiment I'm doing I don't want to generate a complete score first and display that. Instead I'd like to update/display the score while it is being generated (a kind of real-time music score display server). Does vexflow provide a suitable basis to dynamically extend the displayed score?

title: Player is still not working
body: There's an issue on Vextab for it, but it seems that that is no longer maintained since there's been no commits in 5 months.

title: EasyScore: rest in middle of measure not working (possible bug)
body:
So, I'm messing with some strings with easyScore and when a rest is in the middle of a measure, it returns an error.

This string: `A4/8, B4/8, A4/8, B4/8, B4/8, A4/r8`(with a rest at the end) generates this ([fiddle here](https://jsfiddle.net/0b6hcc69/45/)) :

![image](http://i.imgur.com/UeeZImA.png)

--

But this string `A4/8, B4/8, A4/8, B4/r8, B4/8, A4/r8` (with a rest in the middle) generates an error ( [fiddle here](https://jsfiddle.net/0b6hcc69/44/)) :
```javascript
formatter.js:84 Uncaught RuntimeErrorcode: "IncompleteVoice"
message: "Voice does not have enough notes."

__proto__: Object
(anonymous) @ formatter.js:84
createContexts @ formatter.js:76
createModifierContexts @ formatter.js:404
joinVoices @ formatter.js:659
(anonymous) @ system.js:92
format @ system.js:89
(anonymous) @ factory.js:329
draw @ factory.js:329
(anonymous) @ embedded:18
transform.run @ VM161 babel.js:3192
exec @ VM161 babel.js:3247
runScripts @ VM161 babel.js:3284
```

**AND** this string `A4/8, B4/8, A4/8, B4/8, A4/8, B4/r8, A4/8, A4/8`, that should return an error because it's too many notes in the same voice, renders just fine with the rest at the end, and ignoring notes after that. Seems to me that this is the reason I mentioned in #477 when it ignored a *too many notes* error.  [fiddle here](https://jsfiddle.net/0b6hcc69/46/)

I tried looking into the files [easyscore.js](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/blob/d27e7b027b15c1bf583da9d583ccaede548c6b1a/src/easyscore.js) and [note.js](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/blob/5654fa3c492bde48a8189f9d13932b81818801e3/src/note.js) and couldn't find anything wrong.

So at the moment what I have to do is check if the note, for example "Db" has a "b" in it, if so decrease it by a semitone so I can give C to Vex Flow.

So yeah I've to give the **wrong** note to VF to have the correct one drawn.

title: [EasyScore] More than one bar in a stave not working
Beams breaking when moving from A to B inside of the Treble Clef
body:
Hi, I'm having an issue with beams breaking whenever I'm going moving between A and B inside the treble clef, and while I do know about the beam positioning, I'm not in a great position to use it. I'm generating a random scale on my backend, giving it to teoria to build the scale, then handing it to vexflow for templating purposes, so I won't know until runtime if I'm going to need to position the beams up or down.

Here is the bit of code where I'm templating:

```javascript
                system.addStave({voices:[
                    score.voice(
                        score.beam(
                            score.notes(first))
                                .concat(score.beam(score.notes(second)))
                                .concat(score.beam(score.notes(third)))
                                .concat(score.beam(score.notes(fourth)))
                        )
                    ]
                }).addClef('treble').addTimeSignature('4/4');
```

And here is what I'm getting when I break that specific octave:

![scalesnippet](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17570063/20528689/34ff6de8-b09b-11e6-83a9-31456c6ee72e.png)

Any help would be greatly appreciated, thanks!

title: Embedding VexFlow snippets
body:
This is a feature suggestion that I think would help spread VexFlow usage across the Web.

Just like YouTube videos, Twitter posts, Instagram images, etc. can be embedded in Medium.com stories, Facebook posts, tweets, and other (micro-)blog engines, it would be great to give musically-oriented users the ability to embed music snippets created with VexFlow. The difference between this and a dedicated blog engine like My VexFlow is that the latter is an uphill and essentially unwinnable battle to compete with professional blog engines with millions of dollars of funding.

Technically, this means:
- Create a host for VexFlow snippets. This would function like Github gists or JSBin. 
- Each snippet would have a permalink and would expose the necessary metadata for embedding: an oEmbed endpoint, Twitter Card metadata, Open Graph metadata.
- A new JS script that embeds the VexFlow code into a host page needs to be written. This script would be delivered by the oEmbed endpoint.
- For embeddability within Medium.com, this new host needs to be registered with Embedly as a [whitelisted provider](http://embed.ly/providers/new)

Hope this makes sense to folks here!

title: fillStyle on noteheads doesn't always work -- styles not persistent
Order of StaveNote.keys does not match StaveNote.note_heads or setKeyStyle index param
body:
**Here's a CodePen demonstrating the problem: http://codepen.io/anon/pen/YpWNML?editors=0010** based on [the FAQ page here](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/wiki/The-VexFlow-FAQ#can-i-color-notes-individually).

If I create a new StaveNote with the keys in a _particular order_ (notice how G/4 is a higher pitch than C/4 but I'm listing the notes out of order here):
`var chord = new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ['G/4', 'E/4', 'C/4'], duration: '8'});`

I would like to be able to programmatically style my C/4 note, currently at `chord.keys[2]`, to be a different color than all other notes -- let's say that I generate the StaveNote programmatically and I know that the last key has a special meaning, and all other keys in the chord are listed in the order in which they're pressed down by the user on a MIDI input device, not in order of their pitch.

So now if I try to do this, expected it to make my C/4 note red:
`chord.setKeyStyle(2, {fillStyle: "red"});`

When I render the note, G/4 note is colored red instead. I expected index 2 to match C/4 because that's how I listed the keys when I created the StaveNote. This is unintuitive and makes it harder for me to control the styling of my notes programmatically.

Thanks for your help on this! By the way, this is my first time opening an issue in an open source project (I'm still pretty newbish at programming), and just wanted to say I love this project and really appreciate all the hard work you all put into making VexFlow!!

body:
Hey, is there a way to remove specific items from the score after drawn? I'm trying to write a React wrapper for Vexflow, so would be nice to remove elements from the score after they get removed at the react render tree. I saw in issue #371 that in the SVG drawings I could access the rendered element, which is great! The problem I faced is that sometimes a note adds more than just itself, for example, https://jsfiddle.net/8eckj32x/13/

In that JSFiddle, if you add in the end this code:

``` javascript
voice.tickables[0].attrs.el.remove()
```

You will notice that the note is removed, but the extra line draw at the end isn't, making this way of deleting inconsistent.

Is there another way to remove specific items from the score after drawn?

Maybe I’m doing something wrong and this combination should never happen?

title: `Factory` method conventions
body:
So far, the `Factory` methods seem bring a bit more consistency to object construction. Now that we've implemented a variety of objects, it might be worth defining some conventions. I think there's a bit of inconsistency that could be ironed out.

Two forms of Factory method arguments exist so far:
1. An object with all config properties at the top level
   - The object is passed straight into the respective constructor
   - eg: `StaveNote(noteStruct)`, `GraceNote(noteStruct)`
2. An object with properties and a nested `options` object
   - The object is picked apart and the values passed appropriately -- this could be to a constructor or to subsequent method calls.
   - eg: `Beam(params)`, `Stave(params)`, `Annotation(params)`

For the latter, it's not really clear to me how the `options` object is intended to be used. Take the defaults for `Annotation` :

``` javascript
{
  text: 'p',
  vJustify: 'below',
  hJustify: 'center',
  fontFamily: 'Times',
  fontSize: 14,
  fontWeight: 'bold italic',
  options: {},
}
```

Since the font/justification properties are at the "top level", what goes in the `options` object? Not that they shouldn't be "top level" properties, but the distinction between the two tiers is not clear to me.

title: Default Style Audit - Bach Minuet in G
body:
@0xfe has been [working on a simple full-score example in VexFlow](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/437). Even though it's still in progress I thought this was a great  opportunity to assess VexFlow's default style.  Almost everything in the example consists of defaults except for the  slurs' (ie `Curve`) control points, which are manually set.

![Bach Minuet in G](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/8b7356acc32db4764828e5c34012ae701f15805a/687474703a2f2f696d6775722e636f6d2f596646766a44442e706e67)

Stylistic Issues:
1. Key signature too far away from the clef
2. Time signature too far away from key signature
3. Time signature numbers are too small
4. Fingering 2 not centered over notehead (Bar 6)
5. Gracenote is a bit too far away from the note (Bar 8)
6. Left modifiers increase spacing between objects when not needed (Bar 1, 7, 9, 15) or by too much (Bar 8)
7. Beam sitting between staff lines (Bar 11) (https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/432)
8. Beam angles are too aggressive
9. Beams feel a bit thin
10. Metronome mark too close to tempo text
11. Too much spacing between beamed inner notes. (Bar 14)
12. Too much spacing between last two notes (Bar 15)
13. Slurs are too thick
14. Slurs endpoints should be centered over the notehead if on the notehead-side
15. Slur endpoints shouldn't start on staff lines
16. Slur endpoints should go above staccato dots
17. Augmentation dots are a bit close to notehead
18. The thin/thick repeat barlines are too close to each other
19. Repeat barline dots too close to barline
20. Notes before/after repeat are too close to the barline

_Disclaimer: This is naturally a bit opinionated, but I don't think I've said anything too controversial._

title: Using ES6 code will not allow using vexflow in some modern browsers (as of yet)
body:
In several places, ES6 syntax has been introduced for `const` declaration, but not every browser supports it yet. It appears Firefox won't support it until [version 51](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1263355).

I think this issue should be left open, and a new release should not be created, until all major browsers support declarations like `for (const a in b)`. Until then, releases should be based on revisions prior to the implementation of ES6-style code.

title: Incorrect notehead displacement when `.setStemDirection` is called after construction
body:
~~Take a look at the `EasyScore - Draw Basic` test. The chord's noteheads are incorrectly displaced.~~

Take a look at what happens if you call `setStemDirection(Stem.DOWN)` after the construction of a stem-up chord with displaced noteheads.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/18035893/e85b740a-6d56-11e6-8918-1d76fff7394d.png)

My guess is that the noteheads only get built on construction, and so changing the stem after construction does not change placement. That being said, the displacement of noteheads is certainly a kind of "formatting" and not something to be done on construction. However, that's a larger change, and in the meantime we should rebuild when `setStemDirection()` is called.

title: Improve quality of beams within the stave by using staff line positions
body:
Beams look pretty poor. Our current algorithm for calculating the slope is completely independent of the staff. However, best practice says that the start and end of a beam are placed on the lines.

See Behind Bars, page 17, Beam Placing within the Stave, 

> A horizontal beam should not be placed in the middle of a space. The closeness
> of beams and stave-lines is uncomfortable to read [...] A beam must be attached to the top or bottom of a stave-line or else be centred on the line.

title: Add new `Registry` class to manage VexFlow elements.
body:
This is a first pass at the `Registry` class. It allows us to index and keep track of VF elements in a document and query by various attributes. This allows us to build simpler APIs:

For example, we could add a Tie or Slur simply based on element IDs:

``` javascript
vf.Tie('foo', 'bar');
```

Or color all elements in a specific class red:

``` javascript
registry.getElementsByClass('specialnotes').forEach(n => n.setColor('red'));
```

Or we could build stylesheets that post-format generated notation (strawman):

``` javascript
registry.applyStyle('newstyle.css')
```

There are two ways to use the registry:

1) Explicitly register elements with a registry via `registry.register(element)`. This could be something a factory or builder does.
2) Use `Registry.enableDefaultRegitstry(registry)` to auto register any new elements with the specified registry.

It's not complete yet, but I'm sending this out for early review.

title: Extract out builder commit behavior into functions
body:
WIP - But wanted to get your initial thoughts on this

---

This refactors the `Builder` with a new property: `onCommit`. It's an array of functions which will will be run in sequence and passed `(currentOptions, note, factory)` -- the expected usage is around matching key/values in the `currentOptions` object and then transforming the `note` in some way. The `currentOptions` object is formed by the assigning the piece options into the builder options

I extracted the `id` setting into its own function. And also implemented articulations in this way:

```
c4/4[articulations='staccato.above,tenuto.below']
```

Most importantly, this provides the user with a hook for arbitrary extension.

title: EasyScore: Implementation of proposal in #419
body:
This is an implementation of the notation language proposed in #419. There are a few parts to this:
- `parser.js` - A simple context free parser framework.
- `easyscore.js` - Implementation of the EasyScore grammar. This includes:
  - `Grammar` - Uses the above parser framework to define a syntax for the language.
  - `Builder` - Builds VexFlow elements based on the parser output.
  - `EasyScore` - Helper class that connects `Builder`, `Parser` to create notation.
- `factory.js` - Updated to build `EasyScore` instances.
- Tests available in `tests/parser_tests.js` and `tests/easy_score.js`.

title: Easy element builder for tests and other simple use cases
body:
We need a simple way to build common elements (notes, accidentals, beams, dots, etc.) This would vastly reduce the amount of code in the tests, and make the simple stuff easy to do.

Also, now that we have the `Factory` and `System` classes, there's a place to put it.
## Proposal

I propose a new method, `Factory.easyVoice(line, options)` that takes a string expressing a short sequence of music and creates the relevant VF objects.
## Usage

Using the factory to build everything:

``` javascript
let vf = VF.Factory();
vf.addStave();
vf.easyVoice('C5/8, D#5/8, Bbb4/w', options: {stem: up});
vf.draw()
```

Using the factory for just `easyVoice`:

``` javascript
let voice, elements = new VF.Factory().easyVoice('C5/8, D#5/8, Bbb4/w', options: {stem: up});
voice.setContext(ctx).setStave(stave);
new VF.Formatter().joinVoices([voice]).format([voice], 400);
voice.draw();

// Render beams, ties, etc.
elements.forEach(el => el.setContext(ctx).setStave(stave).draw())
```
## Examples
#### `easyVoice("C5/8, D#5/8, Bbb4/w")`

Constructs the three stave notes, C5, D5, and B5, of durations 8, 8, and w, and attaches the `#` and `bb` accidentals to the latter two. It sticks them in a voice, and returns `{voice: ..., elements: [...]}`.
#### `easyVoice("(C#5 G5 E5)/w, D#5/8, Bb4/w")`

Same as above, except the first `StaveNote` is a chord.
#### `easyVoice("C#5 G5 E5)/w, D#5/8[id='foo', stem='up'], Bb4/w")`

Same as above, except also set the `id` to `foo` and its stem facing upwards. The `[key=val,...]` syntax allows you to attach arbitrary properties to a note.
## Options

The `options` object passed into `Factory.easyVoice` can have properties that affect all the notes, like `stem` or `stave`.
## Grammar

The grammar for the line is straightforward, and can be built with a simple hand parser:

```
SLASH: /
LPAREN: (
RPAREN: )
LBRACKET: [
RBRACKET: ]
COMMA: ,
EQUALS: =
QUOTE: '
DOT: .
SPACE: \s+

groups: chord | chords
chords: chord COMMA
chord: (note | notes) (SLASH duration)? (SLASH type)? (dots)? (options)?
notes: LPAREN (note SPACE)+ RPAREN   
note: key accidental? octave?
key: [a-gA-G]
accidental: [#bn]*
octave: [0-9]+
duration: [0-9qhw]+
type: [rRsSxX]
dots: DOT+
options: LBRACKET (keyval | keyvals+) RBRACKET
keyvals: keyval COMMA
keyval: key EQUALS val
key: [a-zA-Z0-9-_]+
val: QUOTE [^']+ QUOTE
```

title: Rationalize `getExtraPx` and `getMetrics`
body:
We have `getMetrics` which seems to return all of the same information as `getExtraPx`, and is used well across the codebase.

There are currently 4 references to `getExtraPx`.

Your mission, if you choose to accept it, is to replace these references with `getMetrics`, and kill `getExtraPx` once and for all.

title: WIP/Blocked: Extend staff lines to middle line if too far above/below the stave
body:
_This is a WIP but currently blocked by reasons explained below_

Concerning Stem lengths, see Behind Bars, page 14, _Stem Length, Notes on Ledger Lines:_

> Stems for notes on more than one ledger line extend to the middle stave-line
> (marked below):

The PR introduces changes that implement this behvaior:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/17463042/fa00169a-5cb5-11e6-9561-5383d87f4006.png)
_sidenote: the beams should not be flat_

Unfortunately, trying to implement this behavior exemplifies a big problem:
**The stave isn't necessarily set on all elements when formatting occurs.** So what should be a simple implementation, results in ~~~57~~ ~270 failed tests [because of this new error](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/compare/master...Silverwolf90:extend-stems-to-staff-middle?expand=1#diff-14d05dc59b818c53fb8a5a1cd38c1a22R139).
### Proposal

It should be a new requirement that the stave is set on all formatted elements **before** formatting occurs, which would also enable some big improvements to vertical formatting (see https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/411).

This also relates to better defining the formatting lifecycle (see https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/401).

title: Vertical formatting results in lots of collisions when mixing elements and changing sizes
body:
This relates to a lot of things I've been bringing up lately (positioning, boudingboxes, units, hardcoded values, etc). So I figured I should showcase the current state of vertical formatting:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/17462011/57e1096a-5c96-11e6-839a-3983db1bee12.png)

https://jsfiddle.net/vrd5757s/1/

Fundamentally, the mixing of elements should not be a complex case to handle: advance the position of the next element by some value derived from the previous element. There are implementation details around this, but the basic mechanism is the same. The current formatting lifecycle, specifically the `ModifierContext` (see https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/409) and the `.format()` methods make this much more convoluted then it needs to be, while also enforcing an inflexible ordering of `Modifiers` which is problematically opinionated.

title: Dots should be aligned on chords with displaced noteheads
body:
See Behind Bars, page 57, "chords with adjacent notes" 

> Align dots vertically for each part, independently of other chords

Currently the dots are not aligned:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/17461483/8e8994e8-5c85-11e6-9196-15c963a649d3.png)

title: ModifierContext is too complex. Replace with a simpler formatter.
body:
A `ModifierContext` has a `state` that has 4 properties, each which maps to a `Modifier.Position`.

| `state` property | `Modifier.Position` | Unit |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `top_text_line` | `ABOVE` | staff space |
| `text_line` | `BELOW` | staff space |
| `left_shift` | `LEFT` | pixels |
| `right_shift` | `RIGHT` | pixels |

_Sidenotes:
`text_line` should be renamed to `bottom_text_line`. 
Having different units for horizontal/vertical formatting is not ideal. But we can't escape that for now._

All these properties do is keep track of an incremented value in a specific direction. Isn't this already what the `Formatter` does? It advances a position forward along the x axis (albeit with complex logic to determine the amount...). It feels like the `ModifierContext` duplicates and conflates responsibilities since it tries to manage 4 positions at once. So what if we deprecated the `ModifierContext`, and replaced it with with a new, simpler formatter that takes `Modifier.Position` and advances a position given:
- a `Modifier.Position`
- Objects for formatting
- Config options, ie: spacing

To replace the `ModifierContext`, I think we'd need 4 differently parameterized versions of these (one for each `Modifier.Position`).

In fact, in order to format `GraceNotes` within a `GraceNoteGroup` we use the existing `Formatter` and set its available width to 0 that the minimum width for each note is applies. But this is clearly a hack based on the absence of a simpler formatter.

title: Tuplet beam breaks

title: Improve glyph+stem proportions.
body:
~~This is still a WIP -- looks like down-stemmed gracenote flags aren't working as expected. But I wanted to open this up in case anyone had any objections. I'll fix the gracenotes shortly.~~

---

Now that glyph widths are not hard-coded, we can more easily increase glyph sizes to be more standard (and more visually pleasing).

Before this change, the default stem height was 32px. But this is non-standard given a stave with a default 10px staff space. Typically in standard music notation, the default stem height is 3.5 staff spaces (ie: 35px given a 10px staff spcae). The reason it was set to 32px is because the noteheads were too small, so a 35px stem looked too long. I've increased the size of the noteheads, in order for their height to take up an entire staff space. And increased the Stem to the standard 35px.

The crux of this change was replacing the `head_width` property of notehead glyphs in `tables.js`. It was replaced with a `.getWidth(fontScale)`.

I also extracted some of the common font scales into the `Flow` object.

Here are some of the tests with the new glyph sizes:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/17273647/ad809756-56b4-11e6-9ec1-12b25e13dc60.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/17273652/bea5dd84-56b4-11e6-9c64-3f974c1a379a.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/17273694/27f74ff6-56b6-11e6-972c-0c4c41fa8317.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/17273696/36982f94-56b6-11e6-9c83-ba0e24d54912.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/17273697/3e73ed3e-56b6-11e6-9318-9c9d1aaed0e8.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/17273701/56ccb4c4-56b6-11e6-9450-7720a48dbb1b.png)

@mscuthbert and @gristow, do think this is a visual improvement?

Edit: this works toward https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/349

title: Version 1.2.50 broke IE support

From v1.2.50 upwards, Internet Explorer (9 & 10 -- 11 not tested, Edge seems unaffected) throws error: `RuntimeError: The provided duration is not valid: undefined`.

title: Lack of folder structure
body: VexFlow currently has 75 items sitting in `/src` and could benefit from a little more structure. What if we move to a folder structure that more closely resembles the [class hierarchy](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/wiki/VexFlow-Class-Hierarchy)?

title: Clean up tests
body:
What I see as the current issues with the tests:
- Not using ES6
- Inconsistent style -- not linted
- Tons of duplication
  - No test helpers around graphical objects
- No clear pattern for writing a test
  - objects constructed, formatted, draw in different orders for different tests -- often in ways that are not intended to work, but happen to anyway
- Lack of clarity
  - Too much test code is focused on boilerplate

---
### Update (Aug 28th, 2016)

The addition of the `Factory` and `EasyScore` is a massive win for the last 3 points. I've begun refactoring a lot of the tests to use these classes. See https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/433, https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/431, https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/423, https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/420, https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/417

It's worth noting that VexFlow is soon going to a add a new requirement: **a `Stave` must be set on all appropriate `Elements` before formatting** (see https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/412 for the relevant discussion). However, the following tests still do not satisfy this requirement (see list at bottom of this post)

Basic voice creation can probably use `EasyScore` ([wiki](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/wiki/Using-EasyScore)) while more complex test setup might require extending and using the `Factory`.

[Example of refactoring using `EasyScore` - #433](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/433)
[Example of refactoring using only the `Factory` - #417](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/pull/417)

However we still have the problem that we can't use ES6 -- I think we should transpile the tests when running them in a headless browser that requires ES5 (ie: PhatomJS).

### List of remaining tests to fix -- updated 24/12/2016

```
NONE. Wooooooo
```

title: We need to explicitly define the object lifecycle
body:
Two major problems: 
- VexFlow has no clearly defined object lifecycle
- VexFlow provides no support in assembling objects the right way

This is something that that tests get really wrong. They all construct, setup,  and draw things in different order. It's incredibly inconsistent. We're always telling people to look at the tests to learn how to use VexFlow's more obscure parts, but as I'm looking through them now. It's chaos. We can't expect people to look at the tests to get any clarity on how to use this library. 

I'm bringing this up because I was trying to make a very reasonable change to `StaveNote`:

Currently, a `StaveNote` sets the `x` value for it's `Noteheads` and `Stem` in it's `render()` method. But this is clearly the wrong place. We shouldn't be mutating anything in `render()`. So I moved that logic into `.postFormat()`. Since that's clearly the the place to set the `x` values. However, doing so broke _tons of tests_ because lots of them are doing things in the wrong order. But that fact would have never been apparent when the tests were written.

title: Add StaveModifier to build, use StaveModifier.Position in tests

Hi Mohit,

Here's a single tiny commit!

title: Remove rollup in favor of webpack for super-fast incremental rebuilds.
body:
Throwing this out there... I was unable to get fast incremental rebuilds working with rollup (@aaronmars do you know how?). If it's possible I'm happy to stick with it. But I couldn't figure it out, so I replaced rollup with webpack (using `grunt-webpack`).

See the rebuilds in action by running: `grunt webpack:watch`. On my machine, the initial build takes `~8s`, and a rebuild takes `~800ms`. Makes for a much nicer dev experience.

The `watch:scripts` task has been removed in favor of `webpack:watch` (in order to take advantage of webpack's built-in file watching). The task for building _without_ watching is `webpack:build`.

title: Refactor stems/beams
body:
Still  a WIP, tab is broken.

Important things to note:
- The logic `StaveNote.getStemExtents()` has been removed and now delegates to `Stem.getExtents()`
- Went through `Beam` and did a lot of renaming, most variable names were really vague and I think it's a lot easier to understand now.
- A lot of logic in `beam.applyStemExtensions` was just plain wrong mainly due to incorrect assumptions around stem coordinates because it's a [very confusing part of the codebase](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/wiki/Development-Gotchas) -- that method has been greatly simplified
- `Formatter.FormatAndDraw` now passes `options.stave` to `formatter.formatToStave` which is required to trigger the `postFormat`  lifecycle (this also explains why the stem extents were wrong in the articulation PR)

title: Lots of duplicate assertions
AttrNoteGroup; which is for ClefNote, TimeSigNote and BarNote multi-voice support
body: Hi Mohit, Here's new class! AttrNoteGroup (I simply named as AttrNoteGroup because that kind of ClefNote etc are categorized by "Attributes" in MusicXML.. :) thanks for any other name recommendation if you have) Current Attributes Notes system works in case of single-voice well, but with current "ignore_ticks" option, it cannot handle multi-voice & multi-staff notes. Here is an example below, ClefNotes are not formatted correctly. I firstly thought modifying Formatter to support this kind of formatting, but it will make Formatter more complicated and Formatter already has this kind of formatting feature, Modifier. It is similar with GraceNoteGroup, but it covers ClefNote, TimeSigNote and BarNote which can be categorized by "Attributes". AttrNoteGroup makes Modifier for StaveNote using that kind of attributes notes. So it makes Formatter handle multi-voice & multi-staff examples properly. And, I didn't change other test cases which uses ClefNote, TimeSigNote or BarNote yet, but I think it's better to change those examples, too. It will be better not to use that notes without AttrNoteGroup as we don't use GraceNote without GraceNoteGroup, how do you think of this? And because current "ignore_ticks" works only for specific case (single-voice) and it can be also replaced by Modifier system, so it may be good to make it deprecated. Only other class which has "ignore_ticks" statement is TextNote but it actually has no test cases for that. Thanks!

title: Fix GhostNote and add tests

title: Editorconfig
body:
I really like the idea of .editorconfig (http://editorconfig.org).  It allows a project to define some basics (like indentation, newlines, etc.).  This way, editor applications can conform to these settings per-project.

I am a perfect use case as I prefer 4-space indentation, and I'd like my editor to default to that.  VexFlow uses 2 spaces, so if it has an .editorconfig, I don't have to constantly change the settings in my editors/IDEs.

The best thing is this just helps catch eventual linter errors before they happen, and it helps maintain code style.  It's totally opt-in since it requires a compatible editor.

Is this an OK thing to add?

title: Secondary beam breaks doesn't work with tuplets
body: If auto-beaming is configured to work with secondary breaks, tuplets are not counted correctly. Fo example, if I have a 16th note triplet, and auto breaks are to be on 8th note boundaries, the tuplet notes' fractional values are not considered. Here's an example of the bug: This is generated with `Beam.generateBeams(notes, { secondary_breaks: '8' });` The 16ths in the tuplet are being treated like full-value 16ths rather than all three of them adding up to the space of a single 8th note.

title: Migrate to ESLint
body:
As we start to move over to ES6, I wanted to propose using ESLint over JSHint.

Reasons:
- More flexible, powerful
  - Larger set of more configurable rules
  - Supports custom rules, we could create our own `vexflow` specific set of eslint rules that suggest best practices, or warn of improper usage.
- Some errors can be automatically fixed with a CLI flag: `eslint --fix`
- It's currently winning the linter wars
  - JSCS team decided to make 3.0 the last major version and join the ESLint team

I personally use the [airbnb](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript) style guide's [`eslint-config`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/eslint-config-airbnb), with some tweaks. For the most part it's a great starting place, but I find it overly strict in some cases. But in general, VexFlow would benefit significantly from having stricter linting rules.

title: Use `rollup` task with `grunt watch`
body: See title.

title: ES6 class syntax
body:
After implementing ES6 modules, the next layer of this onion would be the class syntax.
This would, of course, be a much more invasive change, but, again, the logical structure of the library makes is so darn tempting...

Here's what I'm thinking:
- Enable babel in the Rollup workflow
- Change all of the `Vex.Inherit(Class, SuperClass, ...)` calls to `export class Class extends SuperClass { ... }`
- Change all static properties to static getters and setters
- Change function declarations to the new class syntax (using `static` where appropriate)

Again, this can be done with source changes only.  The Quint tests and visual regression tests would serve as verification that nothing functionally has changed.

title: Es6 modules
body:
Remove the concept of a Vex global in the sources, and re-introduce it at build time for compatibility with existing code.

Use Rollup.js to build a bundle that behaves exactly like the existing global-based one.

title: ES6 modules

title: Feature Request: Instrument parameter when initialising tabstave
body:
As it stands, initialising a tabstave by default generates a 6-string stave with standard guitar tuning. 
To get a bass tab, one has to use tabstave.setNumLines(4) , and also set the tuning; This is cumbersome. For 7 and 8 string tabs, one cannot even enter notes on the 7 and 8 strings before defining a tuning. 
One should be able to do things like "instrument = bass" or "instrument = banjo" which would set the correct number of strings as well as the standard tuning for that instrument. 

May I create an "instrument" class that handles this?

title: Accurate glyph metrics using a Glyph's Bounding Box
body:
This is a WIP.

Note that this is one of the changes outlined in https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/349
- Add a `BoundingBoxComputation` class -- [which was completely taken from here](https://github.com/icons8/svg-path-bounding-box/blob/master/lib/Path/BoundingBox.js)
  - This is only needed for a temporary amount of time. With SMuFL metadata we would no longer need a utilitiy to determine glyph bounding boxes.
- Add static method `Glyph.getOutlineBoundingBox`
  - Did a bit of refactoring to share logic between this and `Glyph.renderOutline`
- Every time `glyph.reset()` is called, the `bbox` property is set
- `Glyph.getMetrics()` will now return the `width` and `height` of the `bbox`
- Removed `Glyph.setWidth()` since there should be no reason to manually set the width of a glyph
  - This was only used in `Vex.Flow.KeySignature` -- that call has been removed

@0xfe The regression tests don't run on Windows. Any other options?

title: Modern Module System + ES6 (via Babel)
body:
The current module system + manual management of dependencies is really out-dated, it would be ideal to move to a modern module system, either ES6 Modules or CommonJS.

I think ES6 modules are preferable, but would come with the additional burden of a transpilation step (usually with Babel). However, VexFlow is already a compiled target so this wouldn't significantly change the current workflow.

In general, how do we feel about using ES6? @0xfe what browsers do you intend for VexFlow to support? The readme says "modern browsers" but that's rather vague. Barring modules, most of the spec is supported by modern browsers and wouldn't require a transpilation step, but would come at the cost of supporting outdated browsers.

It would also nice to have a build step that has a watcher with a cache, right now `grunt watch` takes about `4.3s` to recompile. That's a feedback loop that could be sped up significantly.

title: Export MIDI?
body: Is it possible to export MIDI from vexflow?

title: SMuFL support + status of Gonville support
body:
(Might be worth looking at this proposal first: https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/349 -- Once those tasks are completed this issue becomes more relevant)

In the [old issue on SMuFL support](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/181), we agreed on not using the metadata but a different set of hardcoded metrics, and I think that was a mistake. Being able to rely on SMuFL metadata entirely for layout will simplify the codebase. Now that I've used SMuFL pretty extensively, I'm in favor of going **all-in** on SMuFL, rather than ending up in some half-way state because we're trying to support Gonville too. It would still be a big net positive if we could use the SMuFL metadata, even at the cost of supporting Gonville. 

I do think we need to seriously consider what is gained from supporting Gonville. It's non-standard, has a minimal glyph set, completely lacks metadata, and adds complexity to the codebase to support it alongside SMuFL. Basically, now that SMuFL exists, I do not think VexFLow should aim to support non-standard music fonts.

If we did want to continue supporting Gonville alongside SMuFL we have to store data about Gonville that allows us to approprately transform and consume Gonville glyphs as if they were SMuFL compliant
- We need the following data on each Gonville glyph:
  - Horizontal origin alignment
  - Vertical origin alignment
  - Orientation for multi-line segments
    - All [multi-line segments](http://www.smufl.org/version/latest/range/multiSegmentLines/) in SMuFL are oriented horizontally but in Gonville _some_ are oriented vertically
  - SMuFL glyph name (eg: `accidentalSharp`) for the respective VexFlow Gonville glyph identifiers (eg: `vb9`)
- Some Gonville glyphs coincidentally match up with SMuFL (like noteheads), so it might only be necessary to maintain a mapping of deviations from SMuFL
- Provide SMuFL compliant metadata for Gonville glyphs

title: Proposed steps to prepare for SMuFL support
body:
I wanted to get this discussion going again, as I've been giving a bit of thought to VexFlow lately. I don't have much time these days, but I figured I could lay down my thoughts on how we could get to SMuFL support and maybe we could agree on a plan.

I previously worked on a branch to support SMuFL ([branch](https://github.com/Silverwolf90/vexflow/tree/remove-hardcoded-head-width) related to https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/181), and while I got it into a working state it was quite a mess. Such a drastic change permeates through the entire codebase, and I'm not sure the current codebase is good enough to support such a large change in a clean manner. Although, the new testing infrastructure should also help significantly.

The first things that need to be done is to improve font infrastructure without doing anything SMuFL specific:
- **Rely _only_ on glyph metrics provided by automatic font processing**
  - Get accurate bounding box information for each glyph
    - In the font files, the height (eg: `Vex.Flow.Font.glyphs['v0'].ha`) values seem to be completely off. Take a look at the following image, but ignore horizontal/vertical alignment of the box on the glyph, it should be obvious that the height of some of the boxes clearly don't fit the glyphs.
      ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/15986828/fdce9166-300a-11e6-916a-a4a8a0fecc47.png)
  - Bounding box data is generally not available on a per-glyph basis in most font encodings. But there are tools to extract the bounding box from an SVG path (I've not used them though):
    - https://github.com/icons8/svg-path-bounding-box
    - https://www.npmjs.com/package/svg-bounding-box
- **Implement horizontal/vertical origin alignment on the `Glyph` class**
  - Some kind of api like: `glyph.setAlignH('center')` `glyph.setAlignV('baseline')`
  - This removes need for low-level fine-tuning in high-level classes, ie: the `Ornament` class shouldn't need to worry about pixel amounts to center the `Glyph` at a point
  - I implemented this functionality in that old branch, probably a lot of that code can be re-used
- **Use appropriate glyphs for articulations that are `above`/`below`** 
  - VexFlow articulations only use the glyph meant for placement above a note, even if it placed below. But Gonville has specific glyphs with origin points meant for articulations placed below a note
  - Articulations should not need to rely on these awkward `shift_up` and `shift_down` properties in `Vex.Flow.articulationCodes.articulations`
- **!!! Remove all hardcoded numbers around glyph positioning !!!**
  - This is the most important thing to make SMuFL support as easy to implement as possible, all previous tasks in this issue are here to support this
  - This includes both magic numbers in the code and any hard coded glyph metrics or numbers for fine-tuning, there are a ton in `tables.js`
  - The exceptions are anything that can't be computed from the width/height, like `stem_extensions` for different durations with flags
  - This should not be done all at once, but a few at a time. Some hardcoded numbers, like notehead widths, might cause more changes than others.
- **Font sizes for relatively scaled objects, eg: `GraceNote`, should use a percentage scale rather than a hardcoded fontsize**
- **All glyph rendering should use the same API.**
  - Currently there is a mix between calling `new Glyph(...)`, `Glyph.renderGlyph(...)` `Glyph.renderOutline(...)`

At this point we should be in a pretty decent place to start thinking about supporting SMuFL compliant fonts.

title: Code quality: Mix of underscores + camelCase
body:
I've been looking through the codebase lately and I forgot how much of a mix there is between naming styles. This should be made consistent one way or the other. I'd propose that since all API methods are in camelCase that it makes the most sense to have the entire codebase in camelCase.

The only place off the top of my head where I think this could cause a breaking change is for options objects, eg: `Vex.Flow.StaveNote.render_options`. I'd prefer to deprecate those and add camelCase versions. But they could also not be included in these changes.

title: How to: CANVAS, SVG and RAPHAEL
body:
Hi, 
I didn't really find how to use SVG without Raphael. Here is an overview of the three options CANVAS, RAPHAEL and SVG.

**1. CANVAS:**
- In your html code of the website, create a `<canvas>` element with width and height and give it an id like id="myCanvas".
- In your javascript vexflow code do `var renderer = new Vex.Flow.Renderer(yourCanvasElement_ID, Vex.Flow.Renderer.Backends.CANVAS);`

**2. RAPHAEL**
- Raphael is deprecated, use SVG instead
- In your html code of the website, create a `<div>` element with width and height and give it an id like id="myRaphaelCanvas".
- In your javascript vexflow code do `var renderer = new Vex.Flow.Renderer(yourRaphaelCanvasElement_ID, Vex.Flow.Renderer.Backends.RAPHAEL);` 
- download and include the raphael-min.js javascript library to be loaded in your source code like you do with vexflow-min.js

**3. SVG**
- In your html code of the website, create a `<svg>` element with width and height and give it an id like id="mySVGCanvas".
- within the <svg> element, specify the argument `viewbox = "0 0 width height"`and set it to the same width and height as specified in your `<svg>` element. I had to familiarize with how SVG coordinate systems work, with viewbox, viewport and preserveAspectRatio properties to see the output.
- In your javascript vexflow code do `var renderer = new Vex.Flow.Renderer(yourSVGElement_ID, Vex.Flow.Renderer.Backends.SVG);`
- no additional libraries required.

For SVG savvy people this may be boring stuff, but maybe a bunch of other non-experts like me would like to see a summary of options like this. @Mohit: Maybe it fits into the VexFlow tutorial.

title: Tuplet Improvements
body:
This PR resolves #329.
- Added support for nested tuplets, and autodetection of tuplet collisions by implementing a tuplet stack on `tickable`:
  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8905340/13905397/c746b158-ee94-11e5-99cb-82c9ae87bbcb.png)
- Refactored option `beats_occupied` to `notes_occupied` in `tuplet.js`, to clarify that the two parameters `num_notes` & `notes_occupied` together form the tuplet ratio, and that they may in fact have nothing to do with the beat.
- Added extensive commenting of `tuplet.js` to better document parameters & options.
- Added `location`, `ratioed`, `bracketed` properties to `options` in `tuplet.js`
- Deprecated use of `beats_occupied`, `setBeatsOccupied` and `getBeatsOccupied` in `tuplet.js` for `notes_occupied` variants.

title: Tuplets / Triplets not fully supported
body:
*\* QUICK FIX requested. Detailed instructions given. This is a half-hour job.

See graphics below for cases not handled: two notes of unequal duration that together form a triplet (or in the general case, n notes of unequal duration that together form an m-tuplet).

The tuplet module takes two integer prarmeters,
num_notes and 
beats_occupied

Currently, parameter num_notes sets the number of notes to be affected, in this case 2, but also sets the glyph above the bracket, which should be 3 in this case. 

Notice also that the scaling is incorrect so that notes sounding together are not printed vertically aligned. In this case, all note durations should be scaled to take up 2/3 of their usual horizontal space.

In the most general case, tuplets require three integers to be specified: the number of notes falling under the bracket, and the ratio that the notes are scaled by. In the most common case, the ratio is 2/x (i.e. quintuplets are scaled by 2/5). By convention, in the 2/x cases the bracket says only x (3 for triplets, 5 for quintuplets), otherwise the (inverted) scaling ratio is shown. 

It would be possible to cover the great majority of useful cases with only two integers of input, by assuming that the numerator of the scaling ratio is 2. The module currently takes this numerator (as beats_occupied) but NOT the important denominator. It would be a very quick fix to the code to change the spec so that the second input "beats_occupied" functioned as the denominator here; both for glyph and scaling purposes.

The most general implementation would need to take both a numerator and denominator for the scaling ratio; the third graphic below shows a score by Stockhausen that requires this notation. This is correct, meaningful notation which should ideally be representable, but these are "advanced" cases that are not used nearly as often as those in the first graphics, which are extremely common and should definitely be represented. 

It may be slightly more complicated to do this more general fix, since modules other than tuplet.js would need to be touched, as the input type to tuplet is changed, but the easier fix mentioned above would only affect this module, and current correct functionality would be maintained (e.g. num_notes = 3, beats_occupied = 2).

![tuplets1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16670803/13731030/3bdb920e-e91d-11e5-953f-47b2c79e9617.png)
![tuplets2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16670803/13731031/3d3a773c-e91d-11e5-8c38-e4ae1751886a.png)
![klavierstucke_ stockhausen _nr2-klavierstuck1-anfang](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16670803/13731126/111b4f12-e91f-11e5-8d79-16ed34e890dd.png)

title: Support more flexible key signatures
body:
Arabic key signatures include half-flat accidentals, e.g. Rast, Bayati, Sikah... It would be great to support these in VF, and I suggest the following changes to the core VF key signature handling:
1. allowing key signatures containing arbitrary accidentals, by explicitly enumerating the accidentals
2. specifying known key signatures that list or generate their own accidentals

The second issue is trickier for Arabic key signatures, because Rast is actually a mode that can be transposed to any key (more or less).

title: (CLOSED) $5,000 Bounty: Create MusicXML Parser for VexFlow
body:
## The Bounty (CLOSED)

A bounty of $5,000 (USD) will be awarded to the first person (or team) that can build a MusicXML parser that renders notation with VexFlow. The winner will also be eligible for up to $5,000 of additional development work (so really, this is a $10,000 bounty.)
## The Goal

The goal is to implement a MusicXML parser that generates VexFlow notation, similar to how VexTab does.
- The parser must fully support the MusicXML 3 specification.
- Code must be written in ES6, well commented, and neatly organized.
- Code must work in all major browsers in both Canvas and SVG.
- Code is expected full test coverage, along with visual tests for each of the features (similar to the VexFlow tests.)
- VexFlow itself might need updates to support various MusicXML features -- you will send PRs to 0xfe/vexflow to implement these features.
## How this will work
- If you're participating, contact me at `mohit@muthanna.com` and let me know. I encourage you to communicate with me regularly as you build this.
- Submit your finished repository to `mohit@muthanna.com` a `tar.bz2` (or `gz` or `zip` or whatever) archive. 
- Make sure to include a `README.md` file with build instructions, test instructions, documentation, etc.
- I will review and evaluate your work, and possibly send it back requesting minor changes, corrections, or more information.
- If I like it, you win! You get a check for $5,000, and we might work together on further improvements or other projects (also for which you will get paid.)
## Terms and Conditions

(Sorry, but I have to do this.)
- You must be in a country where such bounties are legal, and where there are no trade restrictions placed by the US or Canada.
- Your participation in this bounty will not violate any law applicable to you, or disrupt or compromise any data that is not your own.
- You are solely responsible for any applicable taxes, withholding or otherwise, arising from or relating to your participation in this bounty, including payments.
- You must be at least 13 years old to participate. If you're under 18, you need to get guardian consent before any payment can be made.
- If you win, you must transfer full ownership of the code to me. This means that you may be unable to use, build derivative works from, or redistribute any code developed for this bounty.
- I reserve the right to modify, discontinue, or terminate this bounty at my discretion.
- I shall not be liable to you or to any third-party for any damages that you may incur as a result of your participation in this bounty.
## FAQ

Answers to some questions that have been asked so far.
- Does it have to be pure ES6?
  Yes. ES6 all the way.
- Can I translate from another library or language (e.g., an existing C++ MusicXML parser.)?
  No. For ownership reasons, the code has to be entirely your own.
- Is there a deadline for this bounty?
  There is no deadline, but that may change in the future to something reasonable.
- Should I develop this in the open?
  Use good judgement. There's nothing stopping someone else from claiming your code as their own and submitting it.
- How much test coverage is good enough?
  It is important that the final product be easy to maintain, so full test coverage is a hard requirement. Yes, it's tedious, but you will build a better product that way.
- What runtime dependencies can I use?
  Please try to keep dependencies at a minimum. Ideally, the only dependency you will need is VexFlow, but I can grant one-off exceptions for lightweight open-source libraries such as lodash. If you're not sure, please check with me before you add a new dependency.
- I'm interested. How do I start?
  Just start. Feel free to send me an e-mail letting me know that you did (or not, it's entirely up to you.) Although, I encourage you to keep a line of communication open with me.

title: StaveConnector: NONE type, allowing multiple texts and support brace type x_shift
body: Three updates to StaveConnector! 1. NONE type Added new StaveConnector type NONE, users can use NONE type when they want to render only text without drawing connector. 2. Allowing multiple texts Unlike Stave, it was not possible to add multiple texts to StaveConnector (this feature was what I did 2 years ago.. haha), now StaveConnector supports adding multiple texts. 3. Brace x_shift support There are some cases which both brace and bracket staveconnectors added. Like the example below, Modified test case (below) now uses all NONE type, multiple texts and brace x_shift. - Before - After

title: Incorrect positioning of annotation below whole note
Replacing StaveModifier handling system from using glyphs to modifiers only
body: Happy new year! At first, thanks so much for adding such kind of really nice visual regression test. I made lots of change in this PR and it wasn't be possible without the visual regression test. Changes in this PR are below, ## Replacing StaveModifier handling system from using glyphs to modifiers only There were little bit special stave modifiers which added into stave begin or end: Clef, TimeSignature and KeySignature. When stave.addClef(or addKeySignature, addTimeSignature) called, that stave modifier generates glyphs and add to stave right that time. But it makes stave hard to modify stave modifier values because stave.glyphs works independently with modifiers after added. So, I removed current stave glyph system (in case of end_glyphs, I added it 2014...) and now stave only uses modifiers with self formatting. #### Add StaveModifier.Position Now StaveModifier has position which Modifier has, but there are new types BEGIN and END. ABOVE, BELOW, LEFT, RIGHT positions does not require formatting but BEGIN and END requires formatting before drawing. BEGIN and END are for Clef, TimeSignature, KeySignature and StaveBarline. #### Make StaveBarline to be normal StaveModifier likes Clef, TimeSignature and KeySignature. StaveBarline can have BEGIN or END positions. Previously StaveBarline was a kind of exceptional case in case of stave's stavemodifier handling, but now it works similarly like other stave modifiers. #### Auto alignment of BEGIN && END stave modifiers Now, stave automatically fix order between clef, time, key and barline. Like this example below, I didn't change test codes but result is different, [Previous] [Now] [Previous] [Now] [Diff] #### Although test case which is over threshold 1.0 is only TimeSignature.basic_time_signatures but there were also another cases which cannot be ignored Rhythm.Rhythm_Draw___32nd_note_rhythm_with_scratches 0.245074 Rhythm.Rhythm_Draw___16th_note_rhythm_with_scratches 0.0515266 Rhythm.Rhythm_Draw___beamed_slash_notes__some_rests 0.0175269 => KeySignature and TimeSignature order changed. ( clef - time - key => clef - key - time ) Clef.Small_Clef_End_Test 0.0373351 Clef.Clef_End_Test 0.0272275 Clef.Clef_Test 0.0182327 Clef.Small_Clef_Test 0.00800095 => Stave end modifier first padding value changed: 2 => 5

title: Add support for all quarter tone accidentals
body:
Please consider adding support for quarter tone accidentals.

These include the Western notation for half-sharp, half-flat, sharp-and-a-half and flat-and-a-half, all of which are explained on https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accidental_%28music%29#Microtonal_notation (and a picture us also available).

These also include the Iranian notation for half-sharp and half-flat, which are depicted in Persian Wikipedia's pages on [sori](https://fa.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D8%B3%D8%B1%DB%8C_%28%D9%85%D9%88%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%82%DB%8C%29) and [koron](https://fa.wikipedia.org/wiki/%DA%A9%D8%B1%D9%86), respectively.

Ideally, a different identifier should be used for the western and eastern half-notes, so they can coexist in the same sheet if need be. An example of when this is needed is when sheet music is being written for many instruments (as is used by conductors) some of which are oriental instruments and some western instruments but all can play quarter tones.

-- UPDATE --

As shown below, vexflow already supports the Western quarter tone accidentals. There is need for support of Iranian accidentals though.

title: Awkward dots definition syntax
body:
As far as I can tell, when specifying dots on a note, they must be handled in 2 places.  Even then, there is an inconsistent result.

The following code produces a StaveNote:

``` javascript
var n = new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["f/5"], duration: "16", dots: 1});
n.dots === 1; //true
n.getIntrinsicTicks(); //1536
```

...but there is no dot visible when the note is rendered.  In order to get that to happen, you have to do:

``` javascript
var n = new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["f/5"], duration: "16" });
n.addDotToAll();
n.dots === 1; //true
n.getIntrinsicTicks(); //1024
```

This is inconsistent.  By adding dots in the note constructor, no dot is rendered, but the dot count and note ticks are correct.  By adding dots after the fact (with `addDotToAll()`), the dot is rendered, the dot count is incremented, but the note ticks do not change.

I'm wondering what the desired fix is here.  My first impulse is to have the constructor-supplied `dots` parameter behave the same as the a subsequent call to `addDotToAll()`:
- When dots are defined in the constructor, the dot count and ticks will be correct, and a dot will be rendered.
- When addDotToAll() is called, the dot count will be incremented, the tick count will get incremented, and the added dot will be rendered.

The final bit of confusion is the fact that `addDot(index)` is possible... What is the desired result of `note.dots` and `note.getIntrinsicTicks()` when a dot is added to only one note in the voice?

title: Displaced head should take away from modifier width
body:
In stave chords with both displaced heads and modifiers on the same side of the note, the displaced head extent can sometimes overlap the modifiers.

![screen shot 2015-10-10 at 5 40 19 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/241299/10413440/b282274a-6f76-11e5-8a70-859969ebdb9a.png)

The left chord above has this problem, the right doesn't. In the left chord, the total width is larger than it should be.

Possible fixes:
1) the extra modifier width should be decreased appropriately to accommodate for the overlap, or,
2) width calculations used by the formatter should account for the overlap.

title: Secondary breaks/partial beam fixes
body:
This fixes an edge case where partial beams were not pointing the correct direction when the secondary beam was being broken manually with `Beam.breakSecondaryAt()` (as reported in https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/302).

The fix required a re-write of `Beam.getBeamLines()`.

I also took the liberty of adding a new option to `Beam.generateBeams()` called `secondary_breaks`.  This parameter will force secondary breaks to be auto-applied per beam group, rather than relying on breakSecondaryAt() for each case.

title: Bug in calculation of partial beams with secondary breaks
Enable Flat beams in Beam.generateBeams()
body:
This change allows beam slope calculations to be bypassed in the beam generation logic, and allows for a flat beam.  The current, default behavior of generateBeams() is unchanged.

The offset for the flat beam can be universally applied for all of the notes sent to generateBeams(), or it can be automatically calculated per beam group.

To enable flat beams with different heights per beam group, send in `flat_beams: true` to the generateBeams() options.

If the same height is desired for all of the beams in the set of notes sent to generateBeams(), a 2nd parameter, `flat_beam_offset`, can be passed along with `flat_beams: true`.  This parameter is ignored if `flat_beams` is `false` (the default).

I added 5 tests for the 2 modes described above with both up-stems and down-stems (and mixed, up and down).  I tried to put in as many edge cases as I could think of.

title: Allow flat beams
body: This would add a `flat_beam` option to Beam.generateBeams().  The thinking is you could pass this in to skip the fancy (and really smart) slope calculations if you just want a particular group of notes to have flat beams.

title: All clefs keys
body:
## Support for Keys in all Clefs

Fixes #295 

Previously, key signatures only rendered on the correct lines in treble, alto, tenor, and bass clefs. This PR provides support for key signatures in all of the clefs supported by VexFlow (treble, soprano, mezzo-soprano, alto, tenor, baritone-f, baritone-c, bass, french, subbass, percussion).

Previously, for instance, mezzo-soprano would show flats on the wrong lines/spaces:

With testing revised for all keys in all clefs.

SVG Context
body:
Fixes issue #277 - Create SVGContext
- Implements new SVGContext using native SVG, rather than an external SVG library.
- Rewrites test helpers to run tests on specified backends.
- Deprecates RaphaelContext. (Noted in code; no warnings thrown at runtime.)

title: Create SVGContext?
body:
We're not gaining a huge advantage by using Raphael over native SVG support -- except for IE <= 8 support.  I'm doing a lot of other SVG programming these days, and would be happy to make an SVGContext for us, if others think it worthwhile.

(I know we've tried to keep canvas & Raphael contexts as similar as possible.  One advantage that creating a native SVG context could have would be the potential to register the rendered SVG object with its Vex.Flow object -- so that if someone wanted to, they could reach into the SVG and apply styles directly to objects without re-rendering the entire context.  I'm thinking, in particular, about the potential of animation effects -- a note gradually glowing on a mouseover, etc...  Though, short of using the non-standard Function.caller this would probably require code changes throughout all draw() methods.)

title: Fixed Raphael scaling for Raphael 2.1.2.
body: This pull request fixes support for Raphael scaling for Raphael versions 2.0 and higher, by using Raphael's Element.transform() method instead of the deprecated Element.scale() method.  Calls to scale() are retained, so as to not break scaling for users with earlier versions of Raphael.

title: Fixed Raphael scaling for Raphael 2.1.2.
body: Replaced deprecated raphael.js Element.scale() with Element.transform() calls.

title: RaphaelContext.scale() doesn't work with latest raphael.js
body: I haven't had a chance to track this yet -- maybe someone else has: the .scale() method works with Raphael 1.4; it's broken with Raphael 2.1.2.  (No error is thrown, but the scale does not change, no matter what input is given.)

title: Accidental layout
body:
#### Description

This pull request is a significant rewrite of the accidental layout engine, to bring it more in line with layouts as described by Elaine Gould (_Behind Bars_).  In particular:
- Not all accidentals need the default 3-line vertical clearance.  Double sharps require only 2.5 on either side; flats and double flats require only 2.5 below.
- Generally, when three notes have accidentals with vertical crashes, the accidental of the middle note is placed farthest to the left.  (This is not the case, however, when the interval of the lowest two accidentals is a second.)
- Tightens spacing for widely-spaced chords.
#### Examples:

Here's a comparison of the old layout engine and the new:
![vex-accidentals-revision](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8905340/5248148/981f780c-7946-11e4-9034-d00bd7f7013c.png)

title: StaveNote and Stem styling
body:
#### Description:

This pull request extends the current styling options by allowing styling of stems (previously only noteheads & modifiers were supported) and adding an ease-of-use function to allow the styling of a complete Vex.Flow.StaveNote with one call.
#### Summary of Changes:

Added setStyle() class to stavenote.js, to set a style for each key and to the stem.
Added three styling classes to stem.js:
- setStyle() -- set a style for the stem
- getStyle() -- return the stem's style
- applyStyle() -- update the rendering context with the style for drawing

Added drawNoteStyles() test to stavenote_tests.js

title: Fixes voice.getBoundingBox when ghostnotes are used
body: Since a ghost note does not have a bounding box, if a voice starts with a ghost note then calling voice.getBoundingBox returns null.  This PR fixes the issue by checking each note until a valid bounding box is found.

title: StaveNote.getLineNumber(is_top_note) is not returning correct result_line.
body:
As of [9996f03d](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/commit/9996f03d243136ef57afd2fd8bf98909bbfcffc5) in [stavenote.js line 516-521](https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/blame/master/src/stavenote.js#L516), the conditional expression is not interpreted (in IE11) as 0xfe's intention. Lacking of a pair of curly braces for the first if clause, namely if(is_top_note), made the else clause interpreted as the same level as the inner if clause, namely if(this_line > result_line). Suggesting replace line 516 to 521 with following:

```
if( ( is_top_note && this_line > result_line) || 
    (!is_top_note && this_line < result_line) )
    result_line = this_line;
```

title: Improve tests using some kind of perceptual hashing
body:
There are currently lots of tests that rely on humans eyeballing images to spot regressions. This no longer works because there are just too many of them.

We can automate this using the following procedure for every test that generates an image:
1. Calculate a perceptual hash for the image. Good-known-hashes are committed to the repo.
2. If there was a prior committed hash calculated then calculate the distance between the two hashes.
3. If the distance exceeds a constant threshold, fail the test and highlight regions of the image with differences.
4. If the changes were intentional, commit the new hash to the repo. 

To get this right, we need:
1. An appropriate perceptual hashing algorithm for low-noise images.
2. A distance function for the hashes. (Assuming the hashes are vectors in a finite space.)
3. A constant threshold. (This is tunable.)

title: Updated tuplet to adjust for stem direction
body: When drawing a tuplet over notes that have mixed stem directions, the tuplet should always draw above/below the highest/lowest note even.

title: Fix auto-stem calculations
body:
Automatic stem directions for beam groups should be correct now (this addresses the issues brought up in #118 ). The same function now used when `autoStem` is passed on `Beam` construction, and when we call `.generateBeams()`.

Tests have been added with checks on the stem direction for each beam. The auto-stem test has been renamed for clarity and now uses the same checks as the automatic beam generation since they should be identical.

**Auto-Stem on Beam Contruction**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/3897779/a5ff7e56-2264-11e4-95b6-60f495b5f201.png)

**Automatic Beam generation**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/3897799/cefb39a8-2264-11e4-92f2-aa2611110b7a.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/3897806/dc8e8638-2264-11e4-9ef1-106d6559a571.png)

Fixed a bug in `TabNote` where the stem direction was being forced up no matter what.

title: Fix offset beat group beaming
body:
Fixes a beaming case that got broken during the massive amounts of PR merging/rebasing :) At some point the following case got broken, and the last two 8th notes weren't being beamed. Now fixed.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/3892892/24ce1a0a-2236-11e4-9eab-a4d534d0a145.png)

title: No ledger lines for rests.
body: Fixes two places where ledger lines would appear for rests that were outside the staff.  Fixes several notational errors on "Auto Align Rests"

title: Remove float comparisons where Fraction comparisons would be better
body: Fixes https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/issues/234 -- multiple non-power-of-two ticks added together sometimes cause floating point comparison problems. Replaces all comparisons of FractionA.value() == FractionB.value() with FractionA.equals(FractionB) and adds Fraction.lessThan, Fraction.greaterThan, etc.

title: stops beam stems from being messed up the second time you draw them
body: When a note with a beam is drawn for the second time (and after), the stem will become far too short (not even appearing most of the time). To see why this is important, take a look at the site I'm building, which is still a bit rough, but working, http://computingmusic.cs.mcgill.ca/ It allows users to upload an midi or abc file and see it as sheet music and then perform analyses on it. Since pieces are often far too long to fit on a canvas, I solved the problem by having the canvas fit to the screen and update when click-dragged or otherwise moved to show only the part of the piece in view. This means that on each movement I have to redraw all of the notes, and if beam stems only work on the first draw things look very ugly. This pull request fixes this problem.
