title: setter for Stave.x
body:
If the Stave object is moved after it's creation (that is a new `stave.x` is assigned) it losses the modifiers that are already attached (e.g. a Volta object). 

This is a proposed fix for this issue: providing a setX for moving the stave object in order to update the modifier's position.

title: Add duration conversion functions and replace duration checks accordingly
body:
Added `.durationToFraction()` and `durationToInteger()`

Refactored `.durationToTicks`

title: Fixed default rest positioning
body:
This PR does two things:
1. Fixes positioning of Whole Rest
2. Normalizes rest positioning across all clefs while using the key type `R`, ie: `keys: ["r/4"]`. _(But really the octave is irrelevant, we just need it to not break key parsing)_

Basically, in `StaveNote.calculateKeyProps()` I simply override the `line` value if the `props.key` is `"R"`. Let me know if you'd prefer a different way of fixing this.

I also modified the `stavenote_tests.js`, so all rests simply take `r/n`. 

**Treble**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/3235773/383ffc0c-f0d6-11e3-8dbf-708df325aa4b.png)
**Bass**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/3235774/48b80912-f0d6-11e3-9e4b-d9477071a4b1.png)

title: Duration aliases complicate duration checks
body:
Right now, if you need check a note's duration, and the duration has an alphabet based alias (`w`, `h`, and `q`) you have to remember to include it in the check as well. Take a look at the following example.

`stavenote.js` line 245

``` javascript
if (this.duration == "w" || this.duration == "h" || 
    this.duration == "1" || this.duration == "2") 
```

Having to remember to check against the aliases is confusing. So I propose we implement one of two solutions:   
- On construction, convert every alias into the the integer representation like so:

``` javascript
this.duration = Vex.Flow.durationAliases[initData.duration] || initData.duration;
```
- or replace the checks with a `Note.prototype.isDuration()` method that would accurately check against the integer and alphabetic durations

title: Calmer beams with new cost algorithm
body:
This patch applies the (previously unused) slope_cost option in Vex.Flow.Beam to not penalize the slope itself but to penalize the difference between the test slope and a slope which examines the stem height of the first and last notes only and aims for a slope that is half the angle of their difference. This is the algorithm that a number of books on notation suggest aiming for. It still will chose other slopes in cases where intervening notes make getting this slope impossible. But the examples below (Left: new algorithm; Right: old algorithm) give much more gentle slopes than before and more often convey the overall angle from first to last note. Only some tests included, but all other tests leave the original beam slopes largely alone.

![vexflow_beam_improvements](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3521479/3212364/12dcf64c-ef58-11e3-9425-03a5e9d034dd.jpg)

title: Floating point ticks rounding comparison
body:
I've been having trouble with adding ticks for certain tuplets (quarter note triplets; eighth note 5:4 quintuplets) and getting `Voices should have same time signature` errors when formatting multiple part scores and `Too Many Ticks` errors for `.STRICT` mode voices in 2/2 and 3/2 time signatures.  Looking more closely at `voice.ticksUsed.value()` and `voice.totalTicks.value()`, the problem comes with the comparison of ticks on floating point values.  For instance, putting 6 quarter note triplets into a 3/2 bar gives me ticksUsed and totalTicks values of `16384 16383.999999999998`, while 2 quarter notes + 10 5:4 eighth note tuplets gives `24576 24576.000000000004`.

Two possible patches:

(1. untested) compare based on fractions or give an epsilon to the comparisons in voice.js (`this.ticksUsed.value() > this.totalTicks.value()`) and formatter.js (`voice.getTotalTicks().value() != totalTicks.value()` should be `!(voice.getTotalTicks.equals(totalTicks))`; also suggest change error message from "`Voices should have same time signature.`'' to '`'Voices should have same total note duration in ticks`'' since the former caused me to chase down the TimeSignature glyph).

(2. tested but may have other consequences) change the voice.getTotalTicks function from `{ return this.totalTicks }` to `{ return new Vex.Flow.Fraction(Math.round(this.totalTicks.value()), 1); }` and getTicksUsed to `{ return new Vex.Flow.Fraction(Math.round(this.ticksUsed.value()), 1); }`.  Could also multiply value() \* 100 and put the fraction over 100 for higher resolution while still being 32/64-bit floating point safe.

title: Implement key signature cancellation
body:
**Code**

``` javascript
var keySig = new Vex.Flow.KeySignature("A").cancelKey("C#");
stave.addModifier(keySig);
```

**Previous Key is Cb**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/3153256/46275092-ea99-11e3-967a-d4b234304126.png)
**Previous Key is C#**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/3153262/542af2f2-ea99-11e3-97cc-d1d08a99345f.png)
**Previous Key is C#**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/3153268/5d607644-ea99-11e3-9d7e-9abebb7a966e.png)
**Previous Key is Cb**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/3153274/67820f98-ea99-11e3-80bd-2dba145ed6da.png)

This isn't totally complete. The main issue right now is lines 27-54 in `KeySignature.addAccToStave()`. In order to position the glyph combinations in an aesthetically pleasing way, there's some fine-tuning that has to be applied depending on the next accidental glyph and whether it's above/below the current accidental glyph. Right now it's all hard-coded but should be moved somewhere else. Where should we keep this data? Is this data worth storing in `Vex.Flow.accidentalCodes`? Or make it private data within the `KeySignature` module?

I had to make a change to `glyph.js`. Typically, the glyph width can be found via the `.getMetrics()` which would calculate the width based on `x` coordinates. This gave you an exact width of the glyph, but did not provide any spacing if you wanted it. And the combining of different glyphs in a key signature requires spacing. So I added a `setWidth()` method which essentially overrides the calculated width in `getMetrics()` and allows us to set custom widths for a glyph.

Additionally, I refactored `KeySignature` and `Vex.Flow.keySignature()` to use the accidental codes instead of glyph codes.

title: Added TextBracket class
body:
**Construction**

``` javascript
var octave_bracket = new Vex.Flow.TextBracket({
  start: notes[0],
  stop: notes[1],
  text: "8",
  superscript: "vb",
  position: Vex.Flow.TextBracket.Positions.BOTTOM
});

```

**Render Options**

``` javascript
this.render_options = {
  dashed: true,
  dash: [5],

  color: "black",
  line_width: 1,

  show_bracket: true,
  bracket_height: 8,

  // In the BOTTOM position, the bracket line can extend
  // under the superscript.
  underline_superscript: true
};
```

In this case the first two end up positioned off the canvas. I noticed it because some times they end up stacked and the weight of the font ends up bolded.

title: Improve articulations
body:
While looking at the [lilypond glyphs](http://lilypond.org/doc/v2.17/Documentation/notation/the-feta-font#script-glyphs) I noticed a few things.
1. We're using the downwards facing pedal toe glyph for marcato instead of the prettier available glyph
   - Additionally, marcato should be flipped when positioned on the bottom.
   - There is a downwards facing glyph for marcato
2. Staccatissimo has a downwards glyph
3. We're missing the portato articulation

So it becomes clear that having an up and down glyph is common for many articulations.
- Fermata
  - alternate fermatas also available in font
- Marcato
- Staccatissimo
- Portato (in font, not VF)
- Pedal heel (in font, not VF)
- Pedal toe (in font, not VF)

`Articulation` should automatically figure out which glyph to use, as opposed to manually having to decide the direction like we do with fermatas.

title: Added more robust TextDynamics
body:
So I created a new object for more robust dynamics text. Basically you can create text dynamics that have any combination of the traditional letters: **p, f, m,z, r**

```
var notes = [
  new Vex.Flow.TextDynamics({ text: "sfz", duration: "4" }),
  new Vex.Flow.TextDynamics({ text: "rfz", duration: "4" }),
  new Vex.Flow.TextDynamics({ text: "mp", duration: "4" }),
  new Vex.Flow.TextDynamics({ text: "ppp", duration: "4" }),
  new Vex.Flow.TextDynamics({ text: "fff", duration: "4" }),
  new Vex.Flow.TextDynamics({ text: "mf", duration: "4" }),
  new Vex.Flow.TextDynamics({ text: "sff", duration: "4" })
];
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/2885582/5e0a5ea8-d4c7-11e3-880c-b8d04121914a.png)

Obviously this overlaps with `TextNote` a bit, but provides more targeted functionality. Although, I'm not inheriting from `TextNote` and I'm not sure that's necessary. So let me know your thoughts.

title: Added automatic accidental generation
body:
### Summary

This pull request adds the `Accidental.generateAccidentals(voices, keySignature)` static method for applying accidentals to voices. Works with double sharps/flats.

To be used like this:

``` javascript
Vex.Flow.Accidental.generateAccidentals([voice0, voice1], "Ab");
```

By passing in multiple voices, the accidentals will be remembered between the voices. This facilitates a few different accidental placement styles where accidental "remembering" can happen per voice, per staff or even per grandstaff. Simply include the voices you wish to have accidentals remembered between.

However, I'm thinking about changing the name of the method. `generateAccidentals` sounds like it would return an array of `Accidental` objects (like `generateBeams()`). When in reality, it simply adds them to the StaveNote. So maybe I should rename it to `autoApplyAccicdentals()` or something else ?
### Tests

**Basic**

title: Create a tag / release on GitHub
body:
Hello,

Would it be possible to create a tag or release as soon as you feel that VexFlow has reached some stable point? Pulling a specific version, rather than always the latest code would be useful for other libraries depending on VF.

Thanks

title: Formatter tries to getLineForRest() on BarNote
Added draw_stem_through_stave render option to TabNote
body:
And another pull request! I added an additional option for tab stem rendering called `draw_stem_through_stave`. Currently, the implementation just draws lines bridging the fret positions and the main stem. However, this sometimes leaves a small artifact from the combined lines/anti-aliasing. In its current state, it's as far as I could mitigate it.

**Examples:**

title: Added subscript and superscript to TextNote, with unicode character table
body:
Tests:

title: All augmentation dots below line 0 get shifted
body:
Augmentation dots below line 0 generally get shifted regardless of whether their notes are on a staff line or not. The reason seems to be that in `formatDots()` (`modifiercontext.js`), the condition for an inter-line note `(line % 1 == 0.5)` doesn't take negative numbers into account. An obvious fix would be to write `(Math.abs(line % 1) == 0.5)`, see
https://github.com/aerhard/vexflow/commit/3f1bdd7034c6bae93d0b061cb50a38a2abd178b8.

title: changed conditions for extra voice start_x padding
body: In `getNoteStartX()` from `staves.js`, `start_x` gets increased by 20px if there is a `REPEAT_BEGIN` barline on the left. This is necessary when there are other start modifiers than barlines, but results in superfluous padding when additional modifiers are absent (this is often the case when the repeat barline doesn't occur at the beginning of a staff). I modified the 'multiple stave repeats test' to include a left `REPEAT_BEGIN` barline without modifiers and added a possible solution to the problem in `stave.js`.

title: changed barline length calculation
body: Barlines currently only have correct lengths when the stave line thickness is exactly 2px (that's the value specified in `tables.js`); the length calculation also seems to be a little bit complicated and I can't see a reason for that. I there is none (maybe there is), I would propose to replace the relevant code in `stavebarline.js` with analogous lines from `staveconnector.js` ( https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/blob/master/src/staveconnector.js#L85-L86 ), which are simpler and also work with stave line thicknesses other than 2px. In the pull request, in addition to these changes, I renamed the local variables `top_line` and `bottom_line` in `stavebarline.js` according to `staveconnector.js` and replaced stave property look-ups by calls of the respective getter functions. The tests (all with the default 2px stave line thickness) seem to work well with these changes. I didn't add tests for values other than 2px, since there seems to be no way to change the barline `THICKNESS` other than modifying `tables.js`. Actually, do you think it could be beneficial to make `THICKNESS` accessible in run-time (for instance, by making `var THICKNESS = Vex.Flow.STAVE_LINE_THICKNESS;` https://github.com/0xfe/vexflow/blob/master/src/stavebarline.js#L25 an object property `Barline.THICKNESS = ...`)?

title: Refactor StaveNote/NoteHead
body:
Ok so I think I added all the changes you wanted. Some comments are more helpful than others...

Also, to make `NoteHead` inherit from `Note` and function correctly a few changes had to be made.
1. Had to override `.setStave()`
2. Needed to override `.preFormat()`
3. Needed to change `.getAbsoluteX()` 

So essentially, `NoteHead` handles two cases now, being used internally in `StaveNote` where it doesn't get formatted. Or being placed directly in a voice, where it does format. Note that `.getAbsoluteX()` won't fail if there is no `TickContext`, but will simply default to the `x` value that was set manually (usually by a `StaveNote`). If it has been preformatted, then it goes with the `tickContext`'s x position.

To draw an individual `NoteHead` you could simply add the following object to a `voice` and draw toa  a stave:

``` javascript
var note_head = new Vex.Flow.NoteHead({
  duration: "2",
  line: 2.5
});
```

`StaveNote.setKeyStyle()` now delegates to `NoteHead`. No more notehead style data is stored in StaveNote.

The code that i removed in `note.js` was leftover stuff from early gracenote stuff that shouldn't have been committed.

**New Tests:**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1631625/2586412/a1dd9cb8-b9ff-11e3-934e-9edd74cf5e04.png)

title: Fix code comments
body:
Two parts to this:
- Fix file header comments: purpose, description, copyright, author (optional)
- Add short description to all public methods
- Explain function parameters, where necessary
- Explain complex algorithms, where necessry

title: Stop reaching directly into object properties
body:
Large codebases are easier to refactor and reason about if the API boundaries are clear. Currently there is a lot of "reaching in" in the code which needs to be cleaned up.

Bad:

```
var stave = stem.note.stave;
```

Good:

```
var stave = stem.getNote().getStave();
```

Better (no demeter violation):

```
var stave = stem.getStave();
```

title: StaveNote parts refactor - convert NoteHead to first class element
body:
So I did some refactoring in `StaveNote`... I know you mentioned you're out of town, so no rush to review this :) 

`NoteHead`s are now created on construction through a `buildNoteHeads()` method. Note that this method has to be called in  `setKeyStyle()` because all the style data for each notehead lives in `StaveNote` and so the noteheads have to be rebuilt everytime they change. I should add a `NoteHead.setStyle()` and have `StaveNote.setKeyStyle()` delegate rather than storing indices of each key with the corresponding style.

The `NoteHeads` get their `y` value provided when `setStave()` is called. Ultimately, I think that the `ys` array should be removed from `StaveNote` and that `getYs()` and `setYs()` should access and mutate the `NoteHead`s directly rather than maintaining the y values in two separate places.

The `x` value for each `NoteHead` is added applied within `StaveNote.draw()`, trying to put this in `preFormat()` doesn't work because it's preformats before the `TickContexts` have x values.

I had to refactor `StaveNote.draw()` significantly. Which led me to extracting a bunch of functions:
- `getNoteHeadBeginX()`
- `getNoteHeadEndX()`
- `getNoteHeadBounds()` - returns an object with the y value and staff line for the top and bottom notehead
- `drawLedgerLines()`
- `drawNoteHeads()`
- `drawFlag()`
- `drawModifiers()`

I extracted methods out of  `StaveNote.init()` as well:
- `calculateKeyProps()`
- `autoStem()`

I plan on implementing `Stem` and `Flag` as first class elements as well. But I figure I'd throw this up as a preliminary request so you can code review and tell me if I'm on the right/wrong track.

title: Articulations/annotations not completely above stem, collides with beam
body:
This only occurs with more mixed beams:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1631625/2520800/d5ee88c4-b495-11e3-8617-475a32173959.png)

This happens because the articulation displacement above the stem is based on the default stem extensions. But they should be based on the stem extensions determined by the beam. The issue is that stems for the beam are created in the `draw()` method of the beam. 

In fact, even without beams, a `Stem`'s lifespan in a `StaveNote` begins in the `draw()` method as well. So there's no way to really sore and then modify it. It almost seems more ideal to have a `Stem` be created on construction and actually used as a persistent property (instead of a drawing helper), and applying a beam to a group of notes would modify their `Stems`, as opposed to beams handling the entire logic for drawing the beamed `Stems` within the `Beam.draw()` method.

title: Flag stem placement
body:
Here's the initial pull request for the stem/flag changes. Here's what it looks like:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1631625/2489129/959f8e4c-b154-11e3-9b83-3d2dff0422cf.png)

I'm thinking we should completely remove `StemmableNote.stem_extension` and have the glyph contain the full extensions (currently I implemented the new glyph properties as adjustments to the `stem_extension`). It would just require a refactor to make sure hard coded instances of `stem_extension` are removed. This would also allow us to remove setting the `stem_extensions` in `StaveNote.init()`

Also note that I have another pull request incoming that improves the dot styles. So that there is a little more space between the notehead and the first dot, and the radius is slightly smaller. So they'll be slightly smaller and farther than the flag than they are at the moment.

title: Implement crescendo/decresc with duration
body:
Currently the `StaveHairpin` draws crescendo and decrescendo dynamics according to a first and last note. This isn't ideal because crescendos do not necessarily have to be right at the position of a note. And  sometimes do not have end note (ie: in the case of wind instruments which can control volume on a single note)

I think it should probably take a duration (inherit from `Note` or implement in `TextNote), and expand to that duration. Being able to draw it on a specific stave line would allow convenient in-lining with the other dynamics signs which often precede or follow the crescendo to precisely indicate the volume change.

trebleVoice.draw(ctx, stave)
```

I believe the formatter is not accounting for clefs in staffs and thus is misaligning the notes. Or is there a bug in my code?

title: VexFlow should be able to "plug-in" alternate fonts.
body:
A good start would be the lilypond font or [SMUFL](http://smufl.org).

This means:

1) Factoring out direct references to Gonville font indexes (e.g., "v51", "v7b", etc.) and putting them in a separate table (e.g., "closed_head": "v51", "16th_rest": "v8a", etc.).

2) The table must include all parameters related to the glyphs, e.g., scale, grace_note_scale, x_shift, y_shift, etc, bounding_box, etc.

3) The Glyph renderer should be able to render different JSON font formats.

title: Grace Notes
body:
- Adds a `GraceNoteGroup` modifier which inherits from `Modifier`
- Adds a `GraceNote`, which inherits from `StaveNote`, can be slashed for **[acciaccatura notation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Acciaccatura_notation.png)** by inlcuding a boolean `slash` flag in the note creation configuration object.
- Modified `Accidental.setNote()` and `Dot.setNote()` to change size if being attached to a `GraceNote`. Do we want to be more explicit than this? Maybe have an actual method to toggle the smaller grace note accidental/dot size?
- Adds a `partial_beam_length` to `Beam.render_options`
- Includes tests

title: End secondary beams
body:
Initial pull request for issue #171

> My initial implementation is very simple. I added a `StaveNote.end_secondary_beams` property, which you can set on construction. So to break up the group into groups of three, add the flag every third `StaveNote`.
> 
> ![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1631625/2433676/fcba409a-ad99-11e3-9d58-f1b6b4b70da4.png)

```
new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["c/4"], stem_direction: -1, duration: "16", end_secondary_beams: true}),
```

> Another option would be to store an array in the `Beam` which would contain indices of the notes to break on.
> 
> Probably the best - and more complex - option is to set secondary beam groups in a way similar to the new auto-beaming, to automatically set secondary beam groups based on a rational or sequence of rationals.

title: Beam groups
body:
This isn't quite ready to merge. I'm not really sure about my implementation of `getDefaultBeamGroups`.

What are your thoughts of having a "Time Signature Default Beam Group" table? If you look at my implementation, it first looks for a hard-corded default, and if unsuccessful, guesses off of the meter. But I think I need to do some more research on exact beam rules. Or, at least, what is used often enough to be considered a default.

I also solved a bug where >= quarter note triplets caused weird beam groups.

title: Make auto beaming time-signature aware
body: Beams in 6/8 are different from beams in 4/4. The grouping code could use different `ticksPerGroup` depending on the time signature.

title: extend autostem calculation in stavenote.js?
body: The calculation of stem directions in stavenote.js is currently based on only one note (line 103: this.keyProps[0].line). This sometimes results in wrong stem directions when applied to chords. With chords, the rule should be: If the _middle_ between the highest and the lowest note of the chord is below 3, auto_stem_direction = 1, else -1. Do you think, this rule could be added to the function?

title: Stemmable tab notes appear to break tab articulations
body:
It seems like tab articulations don't render in the right location for tab notes anymore. This occurs with or without a stem. I've traced this behavior back to the addition of stemmable notes, but not exactly sure where things broke.

The articulations need to know the top and bottom of the notes to render themselves.

If you look at the front page of http://vexflow.com, you'll notice a mispositioned staccato on the fifth note of the second tab stave. @Silverwolf90, mind taking a look?

title: Implemented TabNote stems and beams
body:
Alright, so here's the initial pull request. Let me know what you would like changed.
- Adds a `StemmableNote` class which `TabNote` and `StaveNote` now derive from
- Renames `noteGlyph` property to `glyph` in `TabNote` (possible confusion between the new `TabNote.glyph` and `TabNote.glyphs`; the former is for storing duration glyph data and the the latter is for storing the fret position glyph data)
- Extracted out a new method called `drawStem()` into `StemmableNote`. Assigns the created `Stem` object to a `stem` property on the note, so you can access the stem properties at a later time after drawing
- `Beam.draw()` now uses the new method `StemmableNote.drawStem()` instead of its own stem drawing logic.

title: Tab stems/beams
body:
So I've started work on implementing tab stems/beams, which is necessary when you want to display duration data for the tablature without associated standard notation. See the following image:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1631625/2124622/9f157efe-9242-11e3-89bc-90df0ad89ce9.png)

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1631625/2124364/124b2d84-923d-11e3-92eb-0ad9fdaa01f8.png)

I figure stems could be enabled by a flag in `TabNote.render_properties` and that the `stem_direction` would indicate the top or bottom side of the stave.

Right now it's kind of hacked together with a lot of duplicate code in `StaveNote` and `TabNote`. They both need the following functions: `hasStem()` `getStemDirection()` `setBeam()` `getStemX()` `getStemExtents()` So I'm not sure how to handle this. It doesn't make sense to extract these into `Vex.Flow.Note` since some subclasses like `Vex.Flow.TextNote` don't need stems, and adding a `StemmedNote` to the prototype chain seems like overkill. So my initial thought is to extract it all into some sort of `Stemmable` mixin.

@0xfe  thoughts?

title: Minor bug fixes
body:
Fixed a few lines of code which only compared duration strings against the whole/half note aliases `"w"` and `"h"`. Now these lines compare against `"1"` and `"2"` where necessary.  This fixes a bug where articulations are incorrectly rendered when attached to whole notes initialized with a duration string of `"1"` instead of `"w"`

Fixed a small bug with the 128th note rest glyph properties. Previously the upper bound was not quite right so the bounding box was a little off.

title: [enhancement] Add missing bower.json.
body:
#### Hey, maintainer(s) of 0xfe/vexflow!

We at [VersionEye](https://www.versioneye.com/signup?promo_code=BOWER) are working hard to keep up the quality of the bower's registry.

We just finished our initial analysis of the quality of the Bower.io registry:

**7530** - registered packages, _224_ of them doesnt exists anymore;

We analysed **7306**  existing packages and  **1070** of them don't have bower.json on the master branch ( _that's where a Bower client pulls a data_ ).

Sadly, your library `0xfe/vexflow` is one of them.

Can you spare **15** minutes to help us to make Bower better?

Just add a new file `bower.json` and  change attributes.

```
{
  "name": "0xfe/vexflow",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": "path/to/main.css",
  "description": "please add it",
  "license": "Eclipse",
  "ignore": [
    ".jshintrc",
    "**/*.txt"
  ],
  "dependencies": {
    "<dependency_name>": "<semantic_version>",
    "<dependency_name>": "<Local_folder>",
    "<dependency_name>": "<package>"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "<test-framework-name>": "<version>"
  }
}

```

Read more about bower.json [on the official spefication](http://bower.io/#defining-a-package) and nodejs [semver](https://github.com/isaacs/node-semver#ranges) library has great examples of proper versioning.

**NB!** Please _validate_ your bower.json with _jsonlint_ before commiting your updates.

Thank you!

Timo,
twitter: @versioneye
email: timo@versioneye.com
[VersionEye](https://www.versioneye.com/signup?promo_code=BOWER) - no more legacy software!

title: Make rendered music selectable, returning the markup underneath.
body:
I'm involved with the [Hypothes.is Project](https://github.com/hypothesis/h), which is trying to make the web annotatable-- leveraging the draft [Open Annotation](http://www.w3.org/community/openannotation/) standard and the [Annotator](https://github.com/okfn/annotator/) project.

What you've done is awesome.  And I'm really glad to see that this effort is so active.

We'd love to see vexflow render the scored music in such a way that individual notes could be selectable within browsers, and that the underlying markup would be returned as a result.

See [MathJax](http://www.mathjax.org/) as a great example of how this is done for math (MathML and Latex).  (Select some portion of the math at the upper right,Ctrl-C and paste into an editor.

The benefit is that this makes the music annotatable, so that communities can comment, critique, suggest or otherwise address the content semantically and directly rather than by oblique reference.

title: Consider Lilypond syntax?
body:
Have you considered supporting the Lilypond (or ABC) syntax as now used at Wikipedia?

I would think that supporting these syntaxes could be very useful (assuming they are adequately expressive) given that Wikimedia sites are so prominent and their choice of standards has put things like Ogg-Theora into public awareness previously.

http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikimedia_Blog/Drafts/Adding_musical_scores
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Score
https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Help:Sheet_music

The "Score" extension relies on server-side PHP to convert to an image, however, so it is not a substitute.

Just a throwaway idea...
Their extension unfortunately does not support SVG

title: Fix key parsing for explicitly major keys.
body:
`Vex.Flow.Music#getKeyParts()` is broken for major keys that explicitly use the suffix "M", rather than relying on major as the default when no key type is specified. For example, "CM" is interpreted as C minor, rather than C major as expected.

This is because the entire key string is lowercased before parsing, including the key type suffix. With this change, only the note-name portion of the key is case-insensitive, to properly distinguish between key types "m" and "M".

title: Added Stave Connector X Offest + Repeat Begin Barline Offset Fix
body:
**Minor Fix:**
The repeat begin barline should properly offset in front of the other stave modifiers. In addition, offset `REPEAT_BEGIN` barline types should automatically draw a `SINGLE_LEFT` barline. This is how the code was structured before the bug was introduced. I also had to alter the `getNoteStartX` to give more padding for a `REPEAT_BEGIN` barline, or else the notes and barline overlapped.

**Functionality Added:**
The `BOLD_DOUBLE_LEFT` stave connector can now be offset in order to align with offset `REPEAT_BEGIN` barlines

I extracted a method from `Stave.draw()` called `getRepeatBeginXShift()`, that way you can access the barline offset for the stave at any time.

I added a property called `x_shift` to the `StaveConnector` object which can be set via a new `setXShift()` method.

Combine the two like so: `connector.setXShift(stave.getRepeatBeginXShift())` in order to align the Bold Double barline with the repeat begin position. Currently `x_shift` is only applied to the x position of the `BOLD_DOUBLE_LEFT` connector and no others.

The caveat with this implementation is that the clef glyphs do not have uniform widths, so there is a little overlap weirdness if widths don't match up precisely. 

Stave Connector tests have been expanded. And the current Repeat tests should now be rendering correctly.

title: Added Additional Stave Connectors
body:
This pull request adds the following `StaveConnector`s:
- Left Bold Double Line
- Right Bold Double Line
- Right Single Line

I added an alias for `StaveConnector.type.SINGLE` called `StaveConnector.type.SINGLE_LEFT` since it makes sense to have an opposite for the new  `StaveConnector.type.SINGLE_RIGHT` but to not break things.

Tests are included and show how the bold double lines can be used in conjunction with the `REPEAT_END`, `REPEAT_BEGIN` and `END` barline types, as well as how it looks when multiple barline and connector objects overlap.

title: Correct displacement of stavenote keys on same line
body:
This fixes an issue where two keys of a stavenote that are on the same line aren't consistently rendered with the correct displacement. 

_Example:_ if F/4 and F#/4 are keys of a stavenote, only the first one is rendered on the line. The second one is missing, or rather, it is overlayed on the first so that it appears that there is only one note. The expected behavior is that after the first key is rendered, the second one should be displaced and shifted to the right so that it is visible as well.
- [ ] add unit tests

body:
For all but the whole rest, VexFlow can render them at the desired default position by setting the key to "b/4" or "r/4". But whole rest is rendered one line lower.

Test code is here:
var stave1 = new Vex.Flow.Stave(0, 0, 150),
    stave2 = new Vex.Flow.Stave(150, 0, 300),
    notes1 = [
        new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["b/4"], duration: "wr" })
    ],
    notes2 = [
        new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["b/4"], duration: "hr" }),
        new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["b/4"], duration: "qr" }),
        new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["b/4"], duration: "8r" }),
        new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["b/4"], duration: "16r" }),
        new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["b/4"], duration: "32r" }),
        new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["b/4"], duration: "64r" }),
        new Vex.Flow.StaveNote({ keys: ["b/4"], duration: "64r" })
    ];
stave1.setContext(ctx).draw();
stave2.setContext(ctx).draw();
Vex.Flow.Formatter.FormatAndDraw(ctx, stave1, notes1);
Vex.Flow.Formatter.FormatAndDraw(ctx, stave2, notes2);

Please go to https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups=#!topic/vexflow/CbMGZspEfc0 to see the details.

Thanks,
Martin

title: Feature Request: More intelligent automatic beaming
body:
At the moment, the automatic beaming function does not take the time signature or 'beat boundaries' into consideration when applying automatic beaming. As a result, some of the beaming decisions made by the software make the music unreadable.

There are (at least) 4 main issues as far as I can see which are outlined below in very generalised rules. (I have previously submitted some of these as issues)

1) Time signature awareness

At the very minimum, with time signatures whose top number is divisible by 3, and whose bottom number is <= 8th note, beaming should be in groups of 3 or multiples of 3. Binary time signatures (ie: with numerators 2, 4, 8 etc.) should be grouped in 2's or multiples of 2.

It would be helpful if with odd time signatures (with prime number in the numerator, such as 5/16, 7/8, 11/8 etc.) there was a mechanism for deciding how to group the <=8th notes - ie: 3+2+2, 2+3+3 etc.)

2) Respect for beat boundaries

The example below may be a bug, rather than something that hasn't been implemented, but the 1st semiquaver has been orphaned, and Vexflow then proceeds to beam in groups of 4 across the beat boundary.:

![example1](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/4353219/553523/9e1daca8-c388-11e2-9944-b67d7d7b686e.jpg)

3) Grouping of semiquavers

Where you have a group of 3 semiquavers and a rest, Vexflow removes the beaming as in:

![example3](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/4353219/553535/e4140ec8-c388-11e2-9ed2-6961faffd7c5.jpg)

4) Beaming of triplets:

Triplets should always be beamed separately to avoid:

![example2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/4353219/553541/3586ca48-c389-11e2-9ea7-20e65d263f8e.jpg)

title: Multiple voice bar alignment problem
Colors and glow for individual keys in stave notes.
More display issues - semiquaver beaming and grouping and beaming in 6/8 time
body:
In a time signature where the beats are quarter notes, (eg: 4/4, 3/4 etc.) 16th notes are beamed in 4's. This works fine until you put a rest instead of a note either in the 4th semiquaver position, or the 1st semiquaver position. ie:

tabstave notation=true tablature=false
notes :16 Cn-D-E/4 ## ##-D-E/4 F#/5

![example3](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/4353219/491958/ff4753f8-ba6e-11e2-88a2-d77dc9ae5a47.jpg)

You would expect either the groups of 3 16th notes to be beamed, or even better to retain the beaming over groups of 4, with the beam 'hanging over' the rest. 

Also in 6/8 time, the 8th notes are grouped (beamed) in 3 groups of 2, rather than in 2 groups of 3. ie:

tabstave notation=true tablature=false time=6/8 
notes :8 5/4 7/4 8/5 :8 6/3 5/4 5/5

![example4](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/4353219/491955/ae406b2a-ba6e-11e2-8a78-7368f2ba534e.jpg)

Regards,

Richard Gonski

title: get real width & height for ctx.clear method
Beaming of eighth notes in 6/8 time
body:
As far as I can make out, at the moment, if in 6/8 time you input 6 eighth notes, they are grouped in 3 groups of 2 notes, not in 2 groups of 3 notes as you would expect with a 6/8 time signature.

tabstave notation=true tablature=false time=6/8 key=Ab tuning=eb
notes :8 5/3 8/5  5/2 7/3 5/4  5/5

Apologies if I have missed something - perhaps vexflow does not take into account the time signature when beaming notes.

title: Display issues with triplets
body:
While experimenting with triplets in vexflow, I came across two anomalies in the display which I have reproduced in Vextab. They are:

1) Inserting a 16th note(s) after a quarter note triplet - the beaming starts on the second 16th note, leaving the first one an orphan and upsetting the relationship with the (quarter note) beat.

(In our vexflow code, inserting a 16th note after a crotchet triplet causes a runtime error)

This can be reproduced with:

tabstave notation=true tablature=false time=4/4 key=Ab tuning=eb
notes :q 5/5 5/4 5/3 ^3^ :16 5/5 5/5 6/5 7/5 6/5

![example1](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/4353219/466106/86270c7e-b650-11e2-9b12-3cfbd53b50da.jpg)

2) Creating two 16th note triplets, one after the other, causes the first to have a 3 over it (correct) but the second to be bracketed 3¬ which doesn't look right. 

tabstave notation=true tablature=false time=4/4 key=Ab tuning=eb
notes :16 5/5 5/4 5/3 ^3^  :16 5/5 5/5 6/5 ^3^

![example2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/4353219/466108/92bfbc24-b650-11e2-9260-3b268de80a1e.jpg)

One would expect either:
a) both to have a simple 3 above them
b) or better, for the beaming to be in 2 sets of 3 notes, (ie: 2 separate 16th note triplets) with a 3 above each of the triplets. Inserting ^6^ after the second set, is a workaround, but not what one wants always:

tabstave notation=true tablature=false time=4/4 key=Ab tuning=eb
notes :16 5/5 5/4 5/3   :16 5/5 5/5 6/5 ^6^

![example3](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/4353219/466140/84aa4a4a-b651-11e2-93c0-5ef3e64396f9.jpg)

Apologies if I have missed something here.

Regards,

Richard Gonski

title: Problem with chord accidental on wrong line.
Automatic beaming overrides stem direction.
body: It appears that automatic beaming overrides the notes stem direction. This is a problem because where you have two voices on a stave it is good to have all the stems of one voice running in one direction and the stems of the other voice running in the opposite direction.

title: Correct y position for 'inline' articulations
body:
Staccato, Staccatissimo, Accent, and Tenuto are drawn between stave lines when appropriate, and they will avoid overlapping any lines.

Tweaked placement of some articulations so that they don't overlap when stacked on the same note.

There is still room for improvement in the drawing functionality when dealing with multiple articulations on a single StaveNote. Instead of keeping track of a single 'line_spacing', you could keep track of 'line_spacing_above' and 'line_spacing_below'. There is also still unwanted space between inline (i.e. staccato, staccatissimo, accent, tenuto) and non-inline articulations when they are all above the same Middle-C note.

New Functions:
- Vex.Flow.StaveNote.prototype.getLineNum(is_top_note)

New Tests:
- Articulation - Inline/Multiple (Canvas)
- Articulation - Inline/Multiple (Raphael)
  ![Articulation - Inline:Multiple](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/134487/316674/4d4fa66a-9835-11e2-9c3c-01b67ac29747.png)

title: Guitar tablature editor
body:
Hi all,

First of all congratulations for the great library you're developing. It's getting quite impressive.
I used to check it some monthes ago and I didn't have so many features as I see today, so I decided to create something by myself for a custom guitar editor i'm developing.
You can see it working in the following link:
http://kile.stravaganza.org/lab/js/guitartab
Basically you Add Tabs sections and using the mouse or the cursors you move around the tab lines and press which fret you want to play. You can use the shortcuts 'h', 's', 'v',.. for hammers, slides, vibrato.. etc.

The idea of this webapp is to allow flamenco guitarrist with low level of musical score theory to write down their songs instead of using simply textbased tabs.

Flamenco has also some special techniques like for example hitting the wood so I needed these special symbols too.

After checking your new advances I'm thinking about give a try and create a little parser for my data to vexflow syntax. 
Could you recommend me how to make it, I mean, as I'm not going to edit note but frets numbers I don't know if could be a good idea to create each note like a quarternote and each space a quarternote silencce... 
Also when I tried to use vextab format I found some problems while trying to create simple transcriptions with modifiers like for example something simple like:
--0------
--2------
--2-h-3-
--2-------
--0-------
---------.

Should I use the vextab format? Or directly the vexflow syntax?

Sorry for the loooooooooong post :)

title: Automatic Beaming
body:
I'm using VexFlow to render entire scores, which works very good so far. But as I don't have any information about the notes' beams and ties I was thinking about automatically beaming notes in some sort of pre-processing step. 
I found an algorithm that seems suited: http://issuu.com/tobyrush/docs/beaming
Now I was wondering how to actually start implementing this. Oviously the easiest solution is to do the calculations beforehand and pass the resulting beamed notes to VexFlow. But then again, should'nt this be an actual part of VexFlow? I mean it would be awesome if you just passed the notes and they were (optionally) beamed automatically.
What do you think about it? Should this be part of VexFlow, and if so, where would one start to implement such behaviour? Can anyone give me an advice or point me into the right direction?

title: Rests must be positionable with multiple voices.
body: Currently rests are rendered at a fixed position on the stave. This does not work well when there are multiple voices. Either the user should be able to specify a position for the rest, or one of the context managers should automatically position it.

title: Added setMinTotalWidth
body:
There was a discussion about having getMinTotalWidth. After review the code, it turns out that method was there but minTotalWidth would set only when preFormat get called.

As a work around, setMinTotalWidth has been introduced to provide the ability of having the value of minTotalWidth independent from calling preFormat.

title: Upgrade to latest version of QUnit and updated tests to be compatible.
body:
Upgraded QUnit to version 1.10.0.  The QUnit file that was replaced didn't even have a version in the header, so I'm assuming it was pretty old.
The new version is documented at: http://qunitjs.com/

In order to get the tests up and running, I had to go through and update many of them.  Most notably, the equals() function is now equal().

In addition to fixing the breaking changes between the two versions, I took the liberty of fixing some of the most egregious lint errors in the tests.

title: Add in line configuration for Stave
body:
Added in a line configuration data structure the Stave instance options.

This is an array of objects, one per Stave line that can be used to granularly control how each line is drawn in Stave.draw().  Currently, the only configuration parameter is line visibility, but it was designed so that other parameters can be added with minimal effort.

3 new instance functions were added to Vex.Flow.Stave:
- getConfigForLines(): Returns the current line configuration array.
- setConfigForLine(int, object): Sets the line configuration for a single line.  All other lines are unaffected.
- setConfigForLines(array): Sets the configuration for all lines.  The length of the input array must match the existing num_lines option that is set in the Stave constructor.  If the defaults are desired for a particular line index, null may be passed in at that array index.

title: Semantics of "Stave"
body:
Since the API requires one to use multiple `Staves`s for measures (excluding the barline hack), doesn't that make the name of `Stave` a little semantically awkward? Abstractly, there are multiple measures on a single stave (which would take up the width of a page), not a single measure for a single stave.

Thoughts?

title: Fractional Development
body:
forking the fractional duration discussion from issue #20 here. to start off the fractional timings development, i wrote a fraction class to facilitate fractional calculation.

https://gist.github.com/2370065

some notes here - its not thoroughly tested and completed in anyways, so feel free to comment, but it should be able do basic operations. 

The class is also not immutable. this is to prevent tons of unwanted fraction objects from being created and GC-ed.

_Usage_

```
var fractionA = new Vex.Flow.Fraction(1, 2);
var fractionB = new Vex.Flow.Fraction(3, 4);
var total = new Vex.Flow.Fraction();
```

the normal operations

```
total.add(fractionA, fractionB);
total.subtract(fractionA, fractionB);
total.multiply(fractionA, fractionB);
total.divide(fractionA, fractionB);
```

other operations

```
total.value(); // returns a float representation
total.simplify(); // reduce to its simplest form
total.clone(); // create a new fraction class with its value
total.copy(fractionA); // copies value of fractionA into itself
total.toString(); // string representation
```

utils methods

```
fract.gcd();
fract.lcm();
```

updated

```
total.parse(str); // parse a fraction
total.fraction(); // trancat to its fractional component
total.toSimplifiedString(); // returns a simplified string representation
total.toMixedString(); // returns a simplified mixed form string representation
total.abs(); // turns itself positive
```

title: More generic note duration handling
body:
I created a pull request out of my code to get this finally merged, so I can move on with the ABC notation parser implementation.

Please tell me if there is anything that still needs to be changed.

Here's the full explanation for all changes:

This pull request contains changes to the way note durations are expressed to make it easier to dynamically generate notes and to express an arbitrary number of dots for the duration in conjunction with note type, which can be regular note, rest, harmonic or muted note.

To preserve backwards-compatibility there are two ways to express note duration:

1: The extended old way: The code parses durations in format [base-duration][dots][type], such as "8dddr", "2dm". There can be an arbitrary number of dots in the duration. Also, numbers 1, 2 and 4 can be used for durations w, h and q, to make the API more consistent. The old identifiers are still supported as aliases.

NOTE: I removed alias "b" for 32nd note, because I couldn't see that alias being used anywhere, but that broke one of the VexTab tests. I couldn't find the code that generates "b" as note duration:

```
VexTab Parser module: Notation Only Test (2, 1, 3)
1. tabstave notation and tablature
2. Died on test #2: Invalid note initialization object: "b"
```

2: The new way:

StaveNote, GhostNote and TabNote use the following properties in the object passed as a parameter to the class constructor:

```
{
  duration: "2", // duration is still a string to keep it extensible
  dots: 3,
  type: "r"
}
```

Where duration is one of: 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32 or 64.
Where type can be one of "n" (default for regular note), "r" (rest), "h" (harmonic) or "m" (muted).
Parameters dots and type are optional.

To fully support the new API for note duration, GhostNote constructor now accepts both a string or an object containing the properties described above.

I added tests for both the old and new API.

I also fixed a small bug, where line_shift for tenor clef was incorrect (zero).

Since I couldn't find any tests for that, I refactored StaveNote draw tests, so that the same tests are run for all four clefs: treble, alto, tenor and bass.

In addition, I added separate tests for harmonic and muted note types.

title: Added tremelo support.
body:
Tremelo is notated by adding slashes across the note's stem.  It is used to indicate drum rolls, rapid bowing, and other techniques.

See also:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tremolo

Signed-off-by: Mike Corrigan corrigan@gmail.com

title: Extended justification options for annotations.
body:
This is a generic patch to support more justification options for annotations.

Horizontal justification is extended to fully support left, center, and right.  A new option is added, center-stem, which centers the annotation around the stem instead of around the note.  This will be useful for annotating stems for drum rolls.

Vertical justification was extended from setBottom(boolean) to a full-fledged option.  It includes choices for top, center, bottom, and center-stem.

There is a new test that exercises all 16 combinations.

Signed-off-by: Mike Corrigan corrigan@gmail.com

title: Hi! I cleaned up your code for you!
body:
Hi there!

This is WhitespaceBot. I'm an [open-source](https://github.com/Gunio/WhitespaceBot) robot that removes trailing white space in your code, and gives you a gitignore file if you didn't have one!  

Why whitespace? Whitespace is an eyesore for developers who use text editors with dark themes. It's not  a huge deal, but it's a bit annoying if you use Vim in a terminal. Really, I'm just a proof of  concept - GitHub's V3 API allows robots to automatically improve open source projects, and that's really cool. Hopefully, somebody, maybe you!, will fork me and make me even more useful. My owner is [funding a bounty](http://gun.io/open/12/add-security-flaw-fixing-features-to-whitespacebot) to anybody who can add security fixing features to me. 

I've only cleaned your most popular project, and I've added you to a list of users not to contact again, so you won't get any more pull requests from me unless you ask. If I'm misbehaving, please email my owner and tell him to turn me off! If this is pull request is of no use to you, please just ignore it.

Thanks!
WhiteSpacebot from [Gun.io](http://gun.io).

title: ModifierContext x shift computation faulty for two different clefs, or multiple keys in a StaveNote
body:
I discovered this when trying to build a way to consistently render a chord. The chord will consist of two StaveNotes - one for treble clef, and one for bass clef - and within each StaveNote is two keys (I'm basically showing a piano voicing for a Jazz chord).

I'm using a ModifierContext in attempting to get all four keys to line up properly, regardless of which keys have accidentals, in either of the two StaveNotes. Ideally I'd like for all four keys to share the same stem too, but really I just want to get them lined up.

In tracing through the code I found that Vex.Flow.ModifierContext.prototype.formatNotes is what attempts to set x_shifts on notes to get them to line up. The conditional that ultimately decides whether to set the x_shift at all is:

``` javascript
if (top_keys[0].line <= (bottom_keys[bottom_keys.length - 1].line + 0.5)) {
```
## There are two problems with this:
### Assuming First Key

It's only considering the first key in each StaveNote, which may not make sense. It sounds like you really want the minimum or maximum line value for all keys within a StaveNote, no? I guess as long as the keys are ordered properly it doesn't necessary matter, since it's assuming the first and last respectively. There's even a TODO comment above it that seems to suggest this:

``` javascript
// XXX: Do this right (by key, not whole note).
```
### Assuming Same Clef

The comparison of the line value makes sense _within_ a given clef, but not across clefs. So in my case it's looking at a top_note in treble clef and a bottom_note in bass clef, yet their "line" values are only really specific to that particular clef.  So my case is failing the conditional even though in reality it should be passing and setting setting that x shift on the bottom note. It sounds like we really should be comparing line values based off some sort of clef line offset.

Once I get some time and can dig more into VexFlow (and get a local development environment set up) I might try to fix this myself, but in case it's a fairly easy fix for any of the core developers I'm reporting it here. I think a fix here would do a lot to solve formatting issues with chords spanning clefs, with multiple keys each.

title: Adding new bar lines to vextab
body:
I am working on updating the Vexflow tutorial to describe how to use the new bar lines in stavebarline.js. We currently have two techniques for adding bar lines - using multiple staves per line or using one stave per line and using barnote.js to draw the bar lines. VexTab uses the second technique to draw bar lines with barnote.js. I have attempted to update barnote.js to utilize stavebarline.js here: http://code.gregjopa.com/vexflow-barnote-test/docs/tutorial.html (scroll to the bottom and check out technique 2 in step 6). However, this new barnote.js code a bit hacky since stavebarline.js inherits from stavemodifier.js while barnote.js inherits from note.js. This brings up the design question - should bar lines be derived from notes or from stave modifiers?

I see two options to resolve this issue:
1. Eliminate barnote.js and update VexTab to use multiple staves per line
2. Rewrite stavebarline.js to derive from note.js and support both techniques for adding barlines

title: Modified Formatter That Formats Multiple Staves
body:
Modifications to the formatter and supporting classes to align tablature
with the notation and enable formatting voices from multiple staves. Below
is a summary of the modified classes, tests and web pages included in this
commit.
# Classes (src/)

accidental.js      :: Removed redundant functions defined in modifier.js
beam.js            :: Shorten stems by 3 picels when note head is a harmonic
bend.js            :: Changed text width calculation from textWidth() to
                      measureText()
dot.js             :: Removed redundant functions defined in modifier.js
formatter.js       :: FormatAndDrawTab() - reversed order of noteVoices and
                      tabVoices so stave notes formatted first
                   :: preFormat() - completely recoded to layout notes with
                      left justification
modifier.js        :: added setYShift() function
modifiercontext.js :: new functions formatNotesByY() and formatAccidentalsByY()
                      to enable formatting of more than two voices (multiple
                      staves)
                   :: Fixed accidentals drawing over note heads for displaced
                      notes with downward stems
note.js            :: Added getMetrics() to get note onfo needed for formatting
stave.js           :: Added option for no vertical barline
stavebarline.js    :: Added "NONE" as a barline option
staveconnector.js  :: Added single line, brace and brackets stave connectors
stavenote.js       :: Sorted notes during init to ensure they are in correct
                      sequence by line plus minor changes for new formatter
tabnote.js         :: Various changes to support new formatter
tabslide.js        :: draw() mod to draw consistent slide lines in tablature
tickable.js        :: addToModifierContext() did not use correct variable name
tickcontext.js     :: Added variable to support getting tickcontext metrics for
                      new formatter
timesignature.js   :: Corrected constructor definition from KeySignature to
                      TimeSignature
# New Class (src/)

articulation.js    :: Class to draw articulations in notation
# TabDiv (tabdiv/)

tutorial.html      :: Increased width Steps 5 & 6 so notation would display
# Tests (tests/)

flow.html               :: Added articulation & staveconnector tests

beam_tests.js           :: Made stave width larger
bend_tests.js           :: fixed spacing of reverse bends

title: Clef and KeySignature changes
body:
Another attempt at a pull request! 

Made changes to Vex.Flow.KeySignature and to Vex.Flow.Stave, which address the following problem:

Currently, any new key signature added to a stave only places accidentals on the lines as if the clef is a treble clef, regardless of the actual clef on the stave. These changes result in correct key signature placement for treble, bass, alto, and tenor clefs.

Vex.Flow.KeySignature change: added a function to convert the lines for accidentals depending on current clef.

Vex.Flow.Stave change: added a clef property (default = "treble"), updated in the addClef() function.

Also added a test file:

title: Two small code "typos?"
Formatter Quirk
body:
I have created a new "strokes" class to add brush strokes and rolls (arpeggiated chord) into the notation. I was able to successfully modify "modifiercontext" to format the strokes with the appropriate "left_shift" spacing. When I created the tests, the second triad with the accidentals seems to be stealing space from the 3rd triad as opposed to stealing the space between the 1st and 2nd triads (see example link below). This is true with or without the strokes (stave 1 versus stave 2). 

I believe the second triad should be stealing the space between stave 1 and stave2 so all triads are spaced basically the same. In this case the space between triad 1 and triad 2 will be greater, but not that much. Is the current spacing between triads the desired approach for VexFlow?

http://el-kay.com/test/tests/aa.html

Thanks
Larry

title: TabDiv scale property does not zoom in/out tablature with canvas
body:
`<div class="vex-tabdiv" width="500" scale="2.0">...`

When using TabDiv with Raphael.js for SVG the scale property works correctly by zooming in/out the tab just like a browser can zoom in/out webpages.

When using TabDiv with canvas (no Raphael.js) the scale property does not zoom in/out the tab, instead it just increases the width and height of the canvas. It seems like the code `ctx.scale(this.scale, this.scale)` in tabdiv.js is being ignored or overwritten  which is causing the tab not to zoom.

Is this a bug with TabDiv?

title: Rendering Stave Modifiers between Notes

It seems that clefs/ other stave modifiers are currently rendered separately from notes/voices. 

Is there a way to render a clef/key signature in between notes?

For example

[ "Treble" "D major" "4/4" c d e f  "Bass" e f  .... ]

title: Added Tuplets
body:
Sorry it's taken me so long to get this in. It's still more of a preliminary pull request; I'm sending it more to get feedback than in expectation of it getting merged right away. 

What this commit allows you to do:
- Render tuplets, either with beamed or unbeamed notes
- Set the number of beats that the tuplet is meant to occupy
- Optionally display the tuplet as a ratio, e.g. as "3:2" as opposed to just "3" for a standard triplet in 4/4.
- Optionally display the tuplet notation on the top or bottom of the staff

Anyways, a few remaining issues:

I believe that the text for the tuplet is technically meant to be in italics. Unfortunately, I don't think there is an italics Gonville font, so the options are either to forget about the italics or use a font that doesn't match the numbers in the time signature. If anyone has any better ideas, or if I'm wrong, let me know!

I had to make a couple design decisions here that I'm still not 100% convinced of. The main one has to do with the coupling of beams and tuplets. The way I have it implemented now, the tuplet sort of "owns" the beam. That is, if you create a tuplet, on of the options you can specify is whether or not it is beamed. If it is, then a beam is automatically rendered when the tuplet is rendered. If the beam and the tuplet were separated, then the tuplet class would need to figure out whether or not its constituent notes were beamed in order to now whether or not to render the bracket, but this might be better overall. If anyone has any opinions feel free to offer them.

Again, this is just for rendering tuplets. They still need to be incorporated with vextab/tabdiv, which will require some extra work and design decisions, such as how one will go about denoting a tuplet in a tabdiv. 

Tanner

title: Stems Down Support
body:
I realize that adding an integrated capacity for dual-clefs (treble + bass) is probably a long way off (and certainly complex), but I'm wondering if in the meantime we can get bass clefs to show notes stems down (perhaps as an option), as when displaying both a treble clef and bass clef typically bass clef stems are down. 

This will at least allow me to render a bass clef below a treble clef and more-or-less get bass notes to line up decently with associated treble notes in a chord that spans both clefs. In my testing, aside from the issues reported in the other ticket regarding bass clef interpretation of key/octave values, with stems down this should show decently even if the notes aren't lined up completely due to the potential presence of accidentals on only one clef.

title: Beam display algorithm results in abnormally high beams
body:
See http://ice-nine.org/adamf/bad-beams.png

The code to generate this image:

tabstave notation=true  
notes  :w  4/5    

tabstave notation=true  
notes  :8  [ 1/1  1/3  1/4  1/5 ]  [ 1/6  1/1  1/5  0/1 ]  

tabstave notation=true  
notes  :8  [ 1/1  1/3  1/4  1/5 ]  [ 1/6  1/1 ] [ 1/5  0/1 ]  

I think there's a few reasonable approaches to this; one is ignore it and let the user only beam notes that have similar velocities of pitch (that's the current approach). Another is to adjust the slope of the beams such that the slope is never an angle above a few degrees, calculated from the highest stem being beamed.  Third is automatic beaming, discussed below. Thoughts?

It'd be nice to have an automatic beaming option that handles proper beaming rules, but that's a larger change. I have some ideas around this that I might implement in the next few weeks if I get riled up.

title: Key Signature, Time Signature, and Clefs
body:
Hey,

So I added key signatures, time signatures, and support for different types of clefs, as well as a base class called StaveModifier for these types of things (which basically handles spacing).

title: Added dot rendering functionality
body: Basically this kicks in automatically whenever you render a note with a dotted duration.  Check out the tests (one in stavenote, one in beaming) to see what it looks like.

title: Accidental display
body:
There's a couple of issues with how accidentals (sharps and flats) are being displayed.  In traditional music notation, an accidental affects that note for the rest of the measure (or sometimes the rest of the line), so if you want to go back to the natural form of the note within the same measure (or line) it should be "cancelled" with a natural.  So for example, if you have a G#4 in a measure, the next G4 should have a natural symbol.

This problem can be avoided in most cases by using the complementary accent from the other note (for example, A-flat instead of G-sharp) if there are uses of that natural note within the measure.  That also tends to make for more readable music.

There's a lot more than you'd ever want to know about this stuff at this article: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accidental_(music)

title: TabDiv handling input differently in Firefox 3.6 and IE 8
body:
TabDiv is capable of being displayed in both Firefox and IE 8.  However, TabDiv is not processing the input in IE because it is formatted differently than in Firefox.  I think this is due to the use of the jQuery .text() function before .spit() is called.  jQuery's API states "Due to variations in the HTML parsers in different browsers, the text returned may vary in newlines and other white space."  Therefore, I don't think b=b.split("\n"); is correctly parsing in IE.  One solution may be to parse based on another input, but I'm not skilled enough to modify this code.  Just wanted to point it out.

How input is interpreted in Firefox:
tabstave notation=true
notes 4-5-6/3 10/4

How input is interpreted in Internet Explorer:
tabstave notation=true notes 4-5-6/3 10/4

title: WORK-IN-PROGRESS: user beaming -- DO NOT MERGE
body:
Opening a draft PR hoping that someone with more experience can weigh in.

Currently, vextab doesn't support user-requested beaming.  According to the jison, it should be allowed, eg:

```
tabstave notation=true tablature=false
notes [ :32 3/4 4/5 ] :q 5/6
```

Should produce something like beamed 32nd notes, followed by a quarter.  The jison (https://github.com/0xfe/vextab/blob/master/src/vextab.jison#L232) refers to commands "open_beam" and "close_beam", but those aren't implemented in artist.coffee, and are ignored.

This wip PR changes the "if/else" to "switch/case" for executing commands, which fails when the user adds `[ ... ]` in vextab.  I then implemented a bare-bone idea for keeping track of the beam groups, but it currently doesn't work, as the beams are rendered in addition to the existing note stems:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1637133/115806271-4eaab200-a39b-11eb-9f67-5880645d2de8.png)

I tried a few things like this:

```
    if @in_beam
      @beam_notes.push stave_note
    else
      stave_notes.push stave_note
```

but that didn't work (fails with `Note needs a TickContext assigned for an X-Value`)

Hopefully someone can point out what's wrong with this primitive idea, and then beaming can be properly implemented (that is, if it's needed!).

title: Fix notation-vs-tab bar misalignment
body:
Hi @0xfe / Mohit,

This PR fixes a bar misalignment mentioned in https://github.com/0xfe/vextab/issues/99, and PR https://github.com/0xfe/vextab/pull/120.  Prior to this PR, this works (bars aligned)

```
tabstave notation=true key=E time=12/8
notes :w 7/4 | 6/5
```

But this breaks (bars misaligned)

```
tabstave notation=true key=E time=12/8
notes :w 7/4 | 6/5 |
```

In this branch I added some very simple tests verifying the fix: code is rendered and the SVG is compared, eg:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1637133/115323077-31c47380-a13c-11eb-9020-ec3787412ce2.png)

Note that I pulled the single-line code fix from issue #99  -- I couldn't quite see why this fixed the issue, but it did!  The existing tests pass.

title: Would you consider alternate grammars for vextab, or extensions to existing ones?
body:
Hello @0xfe -- this library, and vexflow, are just incredible.  I've been working with vextab for a short while and wondered if you'd consider variations/extensions on the existing grammar, if it increases the clarity/utility of vextab.  

For example, the notation below

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1637133/114809593-5052f500-9d5f-11eb-990b-923fdad88c41.png)

is vextabbed as

```
tabstave notation=true
notes :8 6/4 $.fingering/1:l:f:2.$ h7/4 $.fingering/1:l:f:3.$ :q 0/2 $.fingering/1:r:f:3.$ $.a>/top.$
```

I've only briefly looked at the jison, but believe that it should be possible to extend the grammar to handle some common (?) things in a simplified manner that would render the same results as above, maybe something like:

```
tabstave notation=true fingering=left accents=top
notes :8 6/4[f2] h7/4[f3] :q 0/2[f3:r, >]
```

It's totally a nice-to-have for me at this point, but if you think it would be a good addition, I could take a look into it.  I'd prefer to contribute back here rather than fork.

Cheers and thank you again, jz

title: Add tutorial steps
body:
The vextab tutorial (https://www.vexflow.com/vextab/tutorial.html)  doesn't yet mention that vextab supports multiple voices or fingerings, though there are tests showing that it's possible.  This PR is a documentation-only update.  I tried to match the style and tone of the prior sections, but please edit them as you see fit.

I did note that the TAB section doesn't render correctly when the score is complicated, is that why this hasn't been documented yet?

![vexflow-tut-step-16](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1637133/114336431-ce1ac480-9b03-11eb-86c7-b369d32808c7.png)

Cheers and regards.  Vexflow and Vextab are incredible pieces of work! jz

title: Using down/up strokes or articulations at the bottom impacts position of annotations on top.
body:
When adding down/up strokes and/or articulations at the bottom of the stave, they cause annotations (such as chord names) to be written lower in order to leave the needed space for the down/up strokes. Which is good! 

But even when these annotations are written *on top* of the stave, their position is (for no reason) impacted by the presence of the down/up strokes.

Look at this snippet:

```
tabstave notation=false
notes 4-5-6/3 10/1 $A,B,C$ | 5d-4u-Xd/3 2/2 $A,B,C$
options space=100

tabstave notation=false
notes 4-5-6/3 10/1 $.top.$ $A,B,C$ | 5d-4u-Xd/3 2/2 $.top.$ $A,B,C$
options space=20
```

Result can be seen here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/wuq4zp8pyf7sl5j/githubissue01.png?dl=0

In the second bar of the second stave, A and B are written higher than C, but there is no need for that. A B and C should be written on the same Y position (i.e. the one C currently has).

title: Triplet containing one quarter note and one 8th note
body:
Hello,

More a question than an issue. It seems that it's not possible to render a triplet containing one quarter note and one 8th note (like [this](https://www.dropbox.com/s/adpytdzia3vu7qu/triplet.jpg?dl=0)). The parser seems to always need 3 notes to create a triplet. 

My questions:

1. Is it actually impossible or did I miss something ? 

2. If it's not possible, is it on purpose and if so, what is the reason ? I know I can create an equivalent triplet by replacing the quarter note by two tied 8th notes, but creating a triplet with one quarter and one 8th seems perfectly valid to me.

As said on Wikipedia: "The triplet indication may also apply to notes of different values, for example a quarter note followed by one eighth note, in which case the quarter note may be regarded as two triplet eighths tied together (Gherkens 1921, 19)."

Thanks for your answer!

title: bar breaks staff/tab alignment
body:
Here's a slightly modified snippet from the tutorial (I just added a bar to the notes):

tabstave notation=true time=4/4
notes 4-5-6/3 10/4 |

title: Support rendering new time signature mid-stave
body:
A time signature can be specified mid-stave in the form of \*#/#\*.
Ie. \*3/4\*, \*7/8\* etc:

![timesignote](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10076864/32407131-24521dac-c18d-11e7-852a-31150af4b09e.png)

Limitations:
- mid-stave time signature does not support common and cut-common time signatures
- beam groupings are not changed by the new time signature

If you can provide some brief guidelines where to begin solving these limitations, please do so and I try to solve them.

Note: The tests fail, but this was not introduced by me, it is failing on the master branch too. I made an issue about this: #97

title: Render Complex and playground tests are failing
body:
- The visual test in the playground.html test fails, see screenshot:

![vextab-bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10076864/32407059-a33fbe00-c18b-11e7-8925-521da9d9f643.png)

A related problem is the failure of the "Render Complex" test. It seems that the tested content is the same as in the playground test, so this is the same problem. The error message of the failing test is the following:

title: An option to set an un-rendered time signature
body:
See https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/vexflow/Pw9gPahvc40.

Mohit says there's a slight bug in the spec: 

```
Right now if you don't specify a time signature, it simply assumes 4/4.
If you do, it always renders it. 
What we need is an option to set the time signature, but not render it.
```

title: license ambiguity
body:
Hi,

I'm afraid your licensing terms are ambiguous: it is either
- open-source
- or free for non-commercial use

I think you might want to _double-license_ your code: an open-source license (for all uses) and a non-free license for those customers which prefer a closer, more dedicated commercial support and consultancy from you.

title: Ties missing when preceded by a triplet
body:
Hi there!

It seems there's a subtle bug, or maybe I'm doing something wrong. If a tie is preceded by a triplet, then the tie doesn't illustrate in the clef (just in the tabstave).

Here's an example of the vextab I'm using, with the triplet (and no ties to the B in stave 3 and 4)

```
    options stave-distance=30 space=10 player=true
    tabstave notation=true
             key=E
             time=3/8
      voice
        notes :8 (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) | (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) | (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) | (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) =:|
      voice
        notes :qd (0/6.9/4.9/3) | :16 ## 8/3 6/3 9/4 6/3 8/3 | 6h8p6/3 ^3^ :8 9/4 T9/4 | :qd T9/4
```

And here's the rendered output:

![Triplet, no tie](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/169446/Screen%20Shot%202014-12-12%20at%2012.58.11.png)

Here's one without the triplet, the tie renders correctly (but the bars don't, because the count is wrong, as expected)

```
    options stave-distance=30 space=10 player=true
    tabstave notation=true
             key=E
             time=3/8
      voice
        notes :8 (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) | (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) | (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) | (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) (7/1.9/2) =:|
      voice
        notes :qd (0/6.9/4.9/3) | :16 ## 8/3 6/3 9/4 6/3 8/3 | 6h8p6/3 :8 9/4 T9/4 | :qd T9/4
```

And the rendered output:

![No triplet, ties](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/169446/Screen%20Shot%202014-12-12%20at%2012.59.00.png)

title: Fixed parser name. Fixed Gemfile and Rakefile.
body:
Hi @0xfe 
I made some minor changes to your library. First of all I fixed an issue with the naming of the parser exported by vextab.coffee, that was causing the `vextab_parser is undefined` as mentioned in issue #49 and also was failing all the tests.  
I also switched the `sh` command in the Rakefile, migrating to the backquote command. This was causing an issue when running the rake tasks in a ZSH shell, using rbenv (the wrong ruby was called).  
I removed therubyracer from the Gemfile, and added libv8 instead. therubyracer has some issues right now with OsX Yosemite.  

Thanks for your great work.  
Cheers

title: build process without ruby, just node and npm
body:
This is a pull request for #34

Use DocPad for build process.
For each conversion type (coffee -> js) you need a docpad plugin (npm module) and define it via the extension, for instance: **script.js.coffee**
usually the plugins don't need any configuration, they just recognize the files by the extension.

the deploy stuff (scp and ssh) is a shell script now: **deploy.sh**

The .html files could also be moved to **src/files** (which is used for static files) but I plan to do a next pull request and use a template engine like Jade to keep the html code DRY ;)

That's the reason why the html files are located at **src/lib**

title: put dependencies to package.json fixes #11
body:
**node-modules** directory will not be created when you run `npm install <dependecy>`. It install the dependencies into the next upper directory which contains a **node_modules** directory, which was in my case my home directory. You can see the result console log:

```
jison@0.4.13 ../../node_modules/jison
```

You need to create the **node_modules** before `npm install <dependecy>` manually or run `npm init` which creates a package.json file and you need only to run `npm install`

This works same as Gemfile & bundler

title: Hiding accidentals when they are in the key signature
body:
Is there any way to hide accidentals when they are already in the key signature? For instance, if I am in the Key of D, then all C's and F's should be played sharp. So if I set the key signature to the Key of D, and then type:

```
notes :q C#-E-F#/4
```

The sharps on the C and the F shouldn't actually appear in the tabliture automatically. Maybe there should be a setting for accidentals. "True" would mean that it always shows accidentals, and "False" means that it only shows accidentals if they are not already in the key signature.

title: Should the embedded player be working in google docs yet?
Slides to|from nowhere
body:
This would be sliding in from an indeterminate fret, or starting a slide at a specific fret without specifying the endpoint.

To make the parsing easier, maybe  it's better not to mess with the current use of "s", and instead use "S" for a slide towards the bridge, and "D" for slide towards the nut:

S9/3 means slide into the 9th from from anywhere higher than the 9th fret
9S/3 means start at the 9th fret and slide  towards the bridge
D9/3 means slide up into the 9th fret from anywhere between the bridge and 9th fret
9D/3 means start at the 9th fret and slide towards the nut

Just thinking out loud here ....

title: 1/4-tone bend
body: This would be handy to have.

title: How about pre-bends?
body:
Just to be precise, I'm referring to a situation in which one fingers a note, bends it, strikes the note, then releases the bend. Since "p" is already taken by pulloff, I don't have a great suggestion for a letter so i'll just use "z":

```
         7z8z7/3
```

would indicate fretting the 7th fret, bending up 1/2 note, striking, then releasing the bend.

If you want to be very fancy, you could allow 7z9z8z7 to indicate a bend up 1 note, then releasing 1/2 note, then releasing one more half note.  That may be overkill though.

title: Bending from frets with 1 digit to frets with 2

tabstave
notes :8 8b9/3 8b10/3 9b10/3 9b11/3 10b11/3

The bends from 8 or 9 to 10 or 11 don't render properly, however the bend from 10 to 11 does.

title: Adding support for TabStave num_lines options
body:
Hi there,

I'd like to add support for parsing 'lines' as a tabstave option in the vextab artist. 
e.g.

```
tabstave lines=5
```

I've added an additional key to the opts object (although, do note that these are properties of Staves rather than TabStaves).

```
890   addStave: (options) ->
891     opts =
892       tuning: "standard"
893       clef: "treble"
894       key: "C"
895       notation: "false"
896       tablature: "true"
897       lines: 6
```

I confirmed in the playground that passing options to the TabStave constructor like so _does_ work (but would pass opts.lines in practice):

```
918     if opts.tablature is "true"
919       tab_stave = new Vex.Flow.TabStave(@x, @last_y, @customizations.width -20, num_lines: 5)
```

I'm having a bit of trouble understanding how to add the grammar for this however. Does there need to be a change to the jison grammar to accommodate this? Adding a lines option to tabstave results in:

```
Sucky VexTab: Invalid option 'lines' in line 1 column 9
```

I'll persist with trying to figure it out, but if you could point me in the right direction I'd appreciate it! :smile:
