title: Dealing with multiple contexts
body:
I'm not sure what's really supposed to happen or if we should just ignore this case or what.

The issue seems to be if there's more than one webgl context used there are issues. It used to work somewhat though I'm not sure how since the old code would call

    var hostUI = new gli.host.HostUI(result);

For each newly wrapped context suggesting that it made a separate UI per context.

I think that explains why the UI is slightly messed up on this page (http://twgljs.org/)

![screen shot 2017-01-22 at 3 05 25 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/234804/22180485/e23d4676-e0b4-11e6-8bde-288c3a0cd7fb.png)


but not this page (http://twgljs.org/examples/twgl-cube.html). 

![screen shot 2017-01-22 at 3 05 11 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/234804/22180483/d24a982c-e0b4-11e6-8bee-07757f2bbc0f.png)


The reason is there's 2 contexts on the first page, one for webglstats.com and another for the background where as the second page doesn't have webglstats.com

In any case the new issue is that a page that uses both webgl and webgl2 has big issues because all the windows/tabs/etc make a context and that context has to be compatible with whatever they're inspecting.

It's making me wonder how much I should refactor or if I should start over or what. I went through and tried to fix the webgl/webgl2 issue but then realized that won't fix it because the code currently expects it's inspecting one context. All the tabs/windows etc get passed the one context they are inspecting. To make it work with multiple contexts seems like there would need to be some global object or something that gets passed around the inspector uses to know which context is being displayed in the UI and then a drop down or something to let you select contexts.

Or I could just make it inspect only one context. In that case thought maybe it should generate a warning or alert (can't inspect multiple contexts) or maybe it should just inspect the first one with a warning or alert on any past that and not inspect them.

This brings up another issue in that the inspector makes lots of contexts. At least one for each BufferPreview, another for each TexturePreview, another for each SurfaceInspector. At the moment I think it makes at least 8 contexts. Since the browser only allows a limited number before it starts losing the context on old ones I'm wondering if the UI should just use one extra context every where if possible. I guess the hard part there is each of those UI elements has it's own canvas so there's probably no easy work around for that short of using one offscreen context and using 2d canvases in all those elements then render to the offscreen canvas and copy.

Here's another idea, only inspect 1 context but in some options somewhere let you select which one gets inspected. The easiest would be by number, the first one created would get inspected but you could set it to 2nd or 3rd etc. The issue there is with so much being async order might not be predictable. It probably is most of the time though so maybe that would be enough

title: Dealing with Uniform Block Objects
body:
I'm mostly writing this because it helps me to think but looking for ideas.

If you're unaware, uniform block objects allow uniforms to be stored in buffers. The issue is that basically anything can write to a buffer, using transform feedback you could have a shader write to a buffer. You can also use PBOs to transfer texture data to/from a buffer. As it is now I think you save all buffer updates whereas uniforms are only saved for a specific frame. But, once you put uniforms in buffers those buffers will be updated every single frame, saving all data for all frames seems bad. We'd run out of memory pretty quick.

There's now `getBufferSubData` to get data out of a buffer so maybe we could use that on the capture frame only? I'm not sure. You can also get texture data out of a buffer using PBOs. I guess I could make it so that on capture I get the data for uniforms using `getBufferSubData` and on playback I can use `getBufferSubData` to save the data currently in the buffer, then put the captured data into the buffer, then put the data that was there back.

I'm not sure that would really work. The buffer may have changed size. I could just use a hidden shadow buffer for uniforms and or everything else but it would require lots of remapping.

Or maybe the inspector just can't work with uniform buffer objects. As it is it saves `bufferData` and `bufferSubData` data but it's kind of assuming those are not called that often (right?) There's no way to tell beforehand if the data being put in is for vertices or for uniforms or something else. Also back to the transform feedback issue the inspector would have to save buffers after every transform feedback call to produce the right playback.

Ugh, now that I think about it making it work is going to be pretty hard. 

Maybe capturing all buffer uploads should be an option. It's nice to be able to see all the calls to bufferData or bufferSubData for a particular buffer but given all that stuff above it should like capturing the uploads might need be the exception and otherwise just use `getBufferSubData` during capture.

Another big change is buffer bind target no longer = buffer type. All the code assumes there's 2 buffer types, ARRAY_BUFFER and ELEMENT_ARRAY_BUFFER but now there are 8 targets but only 2 buffer types, ELEMENT_ARRAY_BUFFER, and "other".  You can bind the same buffer to all other 7 targets. They're just bind points for what the buffer will be used for, not it's type.

Anyway I'm not sure how the inspector should handle any of this. Like noticing how it currently needs to save the state of everything for playback means debugging things with video textures or dynamic textures is also problematic. Maybe it should be saving a snapshot of the data and track if things have been updated so it knows on the next capture if it needs new copies or can use the old ones.

Anyway, just thinking out loud but would love to hear thoughts.

title: AMD
body:
See #143 

This PR adds basic WebGL2 support (it runs, adds WebGL2 VAO support, otherwise lots of features still TBD), and switches the module system to use AMD and the builder to use Webpack+Babel so you can use ES6 features and compile down to ES5/IE

The chrome extension works in both release and debug mode and embed.js seems to work in both release and debug mode. Also tested firefox in release. Safari I can't test as the extension no longer works even without these changes, see #145 

A few caveats: Because the debug mode uses require.js there are issues with using debug mode on pages that use require.js themselves. There is a workaround. Non-debug mode does not have that issue. See readme.md

Another issue is in debug mode things are finicky in that it's possible `window.onload` could fire
before `getContext` has been wrapped. At the moment it seems to be working but just in case, for those cases you can (debug mode with embed.js only) you can wait for `gliready` instead of load. In other words assuming you have some code like this

    window.onload = runMyApp;

You'd change it to

    window.addEventListener('gliready', runMyApp);

Again, only when using embed.js in debug mode. In non debug mode there's no issue. Also mentioned in readme

title: AMD and start of WebGL2
body:
for #143 and #142 

Sorry this is such a huge PR. I started on WebGL2 then decided to use AMD and got things dependent on each others.

This commit switches to AMD for the module system and uses webpack/babel
to build lib/gli.all.js. This means you can use ES6 code in the source
and it should be converted to ES5. It also means there's no need to
add files to both the loaded and the buildscript as webpack can
figure out the files. You need to have node.js installed, probably at least version 4 (stable/LTS)

The chrome extension works in both release and debug mode
and embed.js seems to work in both release and debug mode.
Also tested firefox in release. Safari I can't test
as the extension no longer works even without these changes.

A few caveats: Because the debug mode uses require.js
there *may* be issues with using debug mode on pages
that use require.js themselves. Non-debug mode should
not have that issue.

Another issue is in debug mode things are finicky
in that it's possible window.onload could fire
before `getContext` has been wrapped. At the moment
it seems to be working but just in case, for those
cases you can (debug mode with embed.js only) you
can wait for `gliready` instead of load. In other words
assuming you have some code like this

    window.onload = runMyApp;

You'd change it to

    window.addEventListener('gliready', runMyApp);

Again, only when using embed.js in debug mode.

Note the buildscript now runs webpack, it also installs npm modules. Like the firefox extension sdk this will take a minute or so the first time you run it. After that it should be fast.

I've got more WebGL2 texture stuff already waiting for this to land and will then add Sampler support. I will also try to retro fit WebGL1 VAO support in now that VAO support in WebGL2 is working.

title: Switch Loader to AMD or import
body:
Right now there's custom loaders in `core/embed.js` and `core/loader.js`. If I switch to AMD style then I think I can get webpack to do the build automatically. Webpack follows the require calls to find all the included modules which means the build script doesn't have to be updated when new things are added. AMD style can also still be used without compiling as well so that seems like a win

I can also switch to use ES style `import` but that can't be used without a compile step.

Thoughts? Go AMD? Go Import? Leave it as is?

title: Support WebGL2
body:
Currently  [`embed.js` decides to actually enable the UI](https://github.com/benvanik/WebGL-Inspector/blob/master/core/embed.js#L102) only if the value passed to `HTMLCanvasElement.getContext()` is one of: `["moz-webgl", "webkit-3d", "experimental-webgl", "webgl"]`.

WebGL 2 can be instantiated with the string `webgl2` (and, less commonly, `experimental-webgl2`). It's possible to get WebGL-Inspector to enable its UI by adding `webgl2` to the list in `embed.js` (which allows one to inspect state, textures, etc), but I wonder if there's any additional work that needs to be done to actually support it?

Thanks!

Edit: I played around with it a bit more. Although simply having the UI to inspect what it can is immensely more useful than not, here's the (very incomplete) list of things I've noticed are missing:
- The inspector is unaware of all new consts, like the new internal formats, uniform buffer stuff, etc. and displays them as something similar to `?? 0x8a11 ??` as opposed to `UNIFORM_BUFFER` (The [WebGL developer tools](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/WebGLDeveloperTools)'s `glEnumToString` might be a future-proof way to solve this issue)
- The texture display doesn't show meaningful output for the new [sized internal formats](https://www.khronos.org/opengles/sdk/docs/man3/html/glTexImage2D.xhtml) (scroll down to "Table 2") that are not color renderable.
  - Since we can attach textures as the depth/stencil target(s) for a framebuffer, we can have depth and stencil textures like this
- The "Buffers" tab doesn't seem to handle buffers related to draw calls using uniform buffers well.

title: Inspected context is injected with enumerable properties.
body:
In my [js13k game](http://2015.js13kgames.com/) I am doing Very Bad Things to save precious bytes. One such thing is creating a hash of all available methods like so:

``` javascript
var tmp = []
for (i in gl) {
    // First, filter the methods into an array
    gl[i].bind && tmp.push(i)
}
for (i in tmp.sort()) {
    // Then map the sorted methods into the array
    gl[i] = gl[tmp[i]].bind(gl)
}
```

This code injects its own new properties (numeric indices) in a deterministic manner, which satisfies a need for additional minification. E.g.:

``` javascript
gl[0] === gl.activeTexture
gl[3] === gl.bindBuffer
gl[101] === gl.texImage2D
// ... etc
```

When the inspector is enabled, the context returned to the application is given a lot of new enumerable properties, which breaks the determinism of the above code. (The code itself is not deterministic, as it relies on a vanilla WebGL context.)

Some examples of the new enumerable properties are:

``` javascript
gl.captureCallback
gl.errorMap
gl.rawgl // oh hey, it's the original context that I wanted originally
gl.enabledExtensions
// ...
```

See: https://github.com/benvanik/WebGL-Inspector/blob/abb6290cd3df50cb32341cabeb50b1d77e7ed127/core/host/CaptureContext.js#L167-L199

IMHO, this isn't so much a bug that is bad because it breaks silly things like what I'm doing. It's more of an issue that it exposes the WebGL Inspector to the application, and violates the following claim in the readme: https://github.com/benvanik/WebGL-Inspector/blame/master/readme.md#L15

> Non-destructive to host page - everything happens in a separate GL context

body:

title: drawingBufferWidth/Height are different when running with WebGL Inspector
body:
Hi,
WebGL Inspector has not worked properly with PlayCanvas for such a long time now. :( So I've just spent a little time looking into why. Seems to be related to the value of drawingBufferWidth/Height. When running without WebGL Inspector, this is the same as canvas.width/height. However, when running with WebGL Inspector, drawingBufferWidth/Height are 300 and 150 respectively (which I believe is the default width and height of a canvas as creation time. So when I activate WebGL Inspector on a PlayCanvas app/game, the canvas is 300x150 in the lower left of the tab. Any idea why this might be happening?

See here for a test app to run with and without WebGL Inspector:

http://playcanvas.github.io/load_model/index.html

If you open playcanvas_latest.js in Chrome's sources tab and set a breakpoint at line 4223, that is where drawingBufferWidth is being queried and you can see the discrepancy. Any idea why this is happening?

title: Race condition in embed.js?
body:
I think there's a race condition in embed.js.

What happens is that embed.js calls `insertScript` to get all the `gli` code in, but that code is not synchronous.

Later on, embed.js monkey-patches the `HTMLCanvasElement` prototype's `getContext` and introduces a reference to the `gli` variable.

If someone decides to create a context before `gli.all.js` has loaded, the `gli` resolves to null, and the block in lines 116--119 will always throw exceptions. No contexts ever created! :(

There doesn't seem to be a simple way to solve this besides. Perhaps `getContext` should throw a special "come back later" exception? 

Fundamentally, it's not enough to assume that `embed.js` was included before anything else, because script tag insertion is async.

title: Lazy load trace surface preview
body:
I would recommend testing this before merging.

In this patch, the trace tab's surface preview is not created until the first capture.  That helps with pages that resize the canvas _after_ requesting a webgl context.  If it worked before hand, it was pure luck and a race condition.  I didn't try to have the minibar fill all possible width, though I could add that, but it didn't seem like that big of a deal.

title: Displayed buffer names off by one.
body:
The buffer names reported in a captured trace are off by -1 from the buffer names my program is passing to the bindBuffer and bufferData commands.

E.g, my program uses buffers 1, 2, 3, 5, 6 and 7 for vertex attributes and buffer 4 for the element index array. Each frame it updates buffers 5 & 6 and 7 The traces report that buffer 3 is being bound as the element index array and buffers 4, 5 & 6 are being updated by bufferData.

The data reported in both buffers 3 & 4 is also different from what printfs show I am passing to bufferData for  the element array buffer. I do not yet know if this is also a WGI bug as my program is failing to draw anything at all, which problem I am attempting to debug.

title: Frame.prototype.end is expensive
body: I'm not sure what can be done [here](https://github.com/benvanik/WebGL-Inspector/blob/a56d1a83d99a20188ad56978be0a079e25c8a85c/core/host/Frame.js#L259).  Maybe we can initialize this.screenshot once instead of reassigning it a new canvas every time?  You could also pass an [option](http://stackoverflow.com/a/15563621/1027966) to the webgl getContext call for preserving the framebuffer, but that is usually slow as hell.

title: cache parentOffset access
body: [scrollIntoViewIfNeeded](https://github.com/benvanik/WebGL-Inspector/blob/a56d1a83d99a20188ad56978be0a079e25c8a85c/core/shared/Utilities.js#L70) was not super expensive, but stood out.  I suspect accessing offsetParent might be triggering layout.  Might get small performance wins for caching these values.

title: cache for loop lengths if length is static throughout loop
body: Just did some profiling and saw that [TraceListing.prototype.setFrame](https://github.com/benvanik/WebGL-Inspector/blob/4447b63dbfc908009b7d4dcd11b584be4764b917/core/ui/tabs/trace/TraceListing.js#L137) is pretty expensive.  Sure enough, it's got a for loop that is not caching the value of length in an object, though it never changes (so the lookup is being performed every iteration).  That's some pretty low hanging fruit.  It's a good idea to make sure the length doesn't change during iteration; that transformation cannot be applied everywhere!

title: remove all invocations of innerHTML Fixes #96
body:
@benvanik, this is probably going to take some time to review.  I got a little overzealous and removed trailing whitespace, and touched a for loop, so if you want me to remove those from this patch, I'm down; I can do those in a follow up.  I also replaced the templating in the tabs with some helper functions; while not as clear as a giant string literal, it avoids innerHTML and provides helper functions for generating HTML fragments that were used more than once.

I tested this manually multiple times per file I changed.  I'd recommend testing at least on pages with blending, and non compilable shaders, but I wont provide my test cases so you might spot any changes I accidentally made.  That said, I'm pretty confident that I caught every case where you can't just swap innerHTML with textContent.

title: get rid of blocks
body: [BufferView.js](https://github.com/benvanik/WebGL-Inspector/blob/92f2fb32e088e397b1429800199e1a6c45e0a42a/core/ui/tabs/buffers/BufferView.js#L320) has all these blocks.  JavaScript is function scoped, not block scoped (until the `let` keyword lands), so the variable declarations leak into these blocks.  Therefore, there is no point in having them as they introduce unnecessary indentation.

title: use of eval preventing submission to AMO
body:
I can't submit this as an add-on for Firefox because of the usage of eval.  The two cases I can see look like they can be worked around.
1. [shCore.js](https://github.com/benvanik/WebGL-Inspector/blob/a56d1a83d99a20188ad56978be0a079e25c8a85c/core/dependencies/syntaxhighlighter_3.0.83/shCore.js), part of a dependency, uses it to compress its size.  There's other ways to compress the size, we just need to find the original source.
2. [CaptureContext.js](https://github.com/benvanik/WebGL-Inspector/blob/3e3929fdf4027d530b219a07b336db8b912eff76/core/host/CaptureContext.js#L395) looks like it wraps calls to setTimeout and setInterval when passed strings.  I would recommend just not supporting that use case if that doesn't break anything.  Maybe, we could even just patch those when we build the extension for FF, though that's brittle.

title: No License
body: Code not licensed is not available for reuse. :(

title: Fixed setTimer / hijackedDelay NaN delay resulting in "infinite" timeout...
body:
Overridden window.setTimeout behaves differently, causing "infinite" timeouts.

The hijacked version assumes an "infinite" delay (in `hijackedDelay()`) of 999999999ms when the function is called with a non-numeric `delay` (like `undefined`). In common implementations the parameter is optional and a non-numeric delay defaults to `0`.

At least jQuery calls `setTimeout` like this to invoke the callback when calling `$(document).ready(callback)` after the document has already loaded. With WebGL-Inspector included `callback` will not be called.

title: [enhancement] Add missing bower.json.
body:
#### Hey, maintainer(s) of benvanik/WebGL-Inspector!

We at [VersionEye](https://www.versioneye.com/signup?promo_code=BOWER) are working hard to keep up the quality of the bower's registry.

We just finished our initial analysis of the quality of the Bower.io registry:

**7530** - registered packages, _224_ of them doesnt exists anymore;

We analysed **7306**  existing packages and  **1070** of them don't have bower.json on the master branch ( _that's where a Bower client pulls a data_ ).

Sadly, your library `benvanik/WebGL-Inspector` is one of them.

Can you spare **15** minutes to help us to make Bower better?

Just add a new file `bower.json` and  change attributes.

```
{
  "name": "benvanik/WebGL-Inspector",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": "path/to/main.css",
  "description": "please add it",
  "license": "Eclipse",
  "ignore": [
    ".jshintrc",
    "**/*.txt"
  ],
  "dependencies": {
    "<dependency_name>": "<semantic_version>",
    "<dependency_name>": "<Local_folder>",
    "<dependency_name>": "<package>"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "<test-framework-name>": "<version>"
  }
}

```

Read more about bower.json [on the official spefication](http://bower.io/#defining-a-package) and nodejs [semver](https://github.com/isaacs/node-semver#ranges) library has great examples of proper versioning.

**NB!** Please _validate_ your bower.json with _jsonlint_ before commiting your updates.

Thank you!

Timo,
twitter: @versioneye
email: timo@versioneye.com
[VersionEye](https://www.versioneye.com/signup?promo_code=BOWER) - no more legacy software!

The position data was drawn as a single line - should have been 2 triangles

The texture coordinate data was also drawn as a single line. - should also have been 2 triangles.

The final FLOAT attribute was also shown as a line - since all 4 values were the same it should have been a dot.

Also the display of the values did not show anything. I would have hoped to have 3 sections in that display, 1 for specified vertex attrib pointer.

title: embed in Firefox no longer works
body:
embedding in Firefox no longer works (taking it on faith that it once worked...). I am using Firefox 23.0.1, the latest on the Release branch as of this writing. When I try the embed samples given on the home page or with my own application the pages report a failure to create the WebGL context.

Initial debugging reveals that the global variable "gli", that is referenced during GLI's getContext wrapper, is undefined leading to an exception being thrown. The underlying context is actually successfully created.

title: WebGL Inspector doesn't work with Dart generated js files
body:
It's basically a change request, not an issue.

Currently Inspector doesn't work with dart js-generated files out of the box. This is because dart use obj.constructor.name property for resolving types and CaptureContext's property currently returns empty string. 
So it is sufficient from Inspector's side to change CaptureContext declaration from

``` javascript
var CaptureContext = function(canvas, rawgl, options) {
  ...
}
```

to 

``` javascript
function CaptureContext(canvas, rawgl, options) {
  ...
}
```

Corresponding dart issue and proposed workaround can be found here: https://code.google.com/p/dart/issues/detail?id=3351

title: Fix ArrayBuffer cloning (util.clone)
body:
Util.clone wasn't able to clone an ArrayBuffer. Firstly, it referenced non-existent variable `source` when it seems that `arg` was actually meant. Secondly, DataView methods setUint8 and getUint8 were wrongly capitalized.

This should also fix issue #55.

title: setInterval and setTimeout overrides do not satisfy original contract
body:
1. both functions should return id of created timer, so it can be cancelled at later point
2. host.setFrameControl wipes old timeouts and creates new ones, but invalidates original timer ids, which makes it impossible to cancel prior timers
   
   Imagine this scenario (this caused havoc of my setInterval code):
   1. user code calls setInterval, gets id1 back
   2. someone calls host.setFrameControl, this will cancel id1 and re-create it with id2 internally (with possibly hijacked delay)
   3. user code wants to cancel original interval, calls cancelInterval with id1, but there is no id1 anymore
   4. interval id2 is never canceled and keeps triggering code indefinitely

I'm not sure if my code is correct. But it fixed my issues after enabling gli.

title: Fix requestAnimationFrame interception
body: requestAnimationFrame interception is currently broken and throws an exception (splice called with undefined). It's using wrapCode which is expecting setTimeout style params which is not what requestAnimationFrame uses.

title: Fix compatibility with RequireJS in GLSL syntax highlighting brush
body: WebGL Inspector fails on sites that use RequireJS. The GLSL syntax highlighting brush assumes that the presence of the `require` global means that the script is running as a CommonJS module. However, RequireJS too defines a global with the same name. The attached commit changes the brush to also check that the `SyntaxHighlighter` global is not already present, restoring compatibility with RequireJS.

title: Support extension instrumentation
body:
Need a way to support both built-in and custom JS extension instrumentation.
Really two parts:
1. rework things to use enum lookup wherever possible (to bring in enums from extensions)
2. instrumentExtension method to apply rewriting to extension methods

Special cases still required for extensions that modify resources - not sure there is a way around that.

title: Displayed pixel color values are clamped to 1.0 (255)
body:
When rendering to a floating point texture, color values can be greater than 1, but when I click the texture in the Trace tab, they are always clamped to 1.0 (or 255). I'm not sure, but I think that currently the texture data is rendered onto 2D canvas and the color values are read from there.

Is it possible to read these values directly from the texture or maybe store it in a typed array and read it from there?

title: Proper frame resizing on playback
body: Currently not resizing the trace preview canvas on frame open - would fix some resize issues

title: Draw isolation/pixel history broken on barfight
body: Picking never results in the correct display, and isolation causes washed out draws

title: Support arrays in uniform viewer
body:
Currently Program.js only captures the first element of uniform arrays.
ex,
uniform float4x4 matrices[10];
- will show as matrices[0] in all displays (should show as matrices[SIZE])
- in draw info, all but the first element index will be undefined
- possible replay issues caused by naming

title: Properly display any GL error instead of "unknown" in Trace
body:
Currently there's a switch statement in TraceView.prototype.setFrame and TraceListing addCall function that checks for few hardcoded WebGL errors and for all others it returns "unknown" string. It is possible to create a hash of all WebGL constants and simply do hash lookup instead of switch statement to handle all possible WebGL errors. This hash could probably be useful in other places as well.

I can write a patch, but I'm not sure where to actually store WebGL enums hash - I thought about adding it to gli.util in shared/Utilities.js file, but there's no GL context there and I get error when I try to get it from dummy canvas element. Any ideas?

title: Resizing the host canvas causes issues
body: Seen best in the aquarium demo when it auto resizes. Need to watch for canvas resizing, maybe even context loss?

title: Allow toggling of redundant call display
body: Tons of yellow lines can be annoying in the trace view - add a toggle to turn them off

title: Support for OES_texture_half_float
body:
Currently the extension spec is a bit lacking on info.
- support in TextureView.js/createImageDataFromPixels
- enum added to Info.js/textureTypes

title: Better matrix display
body: For uniforms on programs tab as well as uniform calls in the trace listing. Maybe a popup?

title: Redundant call tracking for vertex attribs and uniforms
body:
missing checks for:
vertexAttribPointer
uniforms

title: Firefox extension
body: Things work pretty well in the embed but it would be ideal to have an extension. Stubbed version is in extensions/firefox/, but it needs an implementation.

title: Timeline counter toggle state should be saved in per-page session

title: Texture history support for arrays
body: Currently the texImage2D/texSubImage2D calls that take an array don't display anything pretty in the history. They should be packed into an ImageData and drawn to a canvas.

title: Support Chromium on OSX
body:
In Chromium for Mac the extension's icon does not show in the toolbar.

The inspector does however seem to function correctly...

title: Support Chrome 8 Beta on OSX
body:
In Chrome 8 Beta for Mac the extension's icon does not show in the toolbar.

The inspector does however seem to function correctly...

title: Reverse navigation from resource->trace
body: Instead of just trace->resource it would be useful to see, on a resource information page, exactly where the resource was used that frame and allow navigating back. For example, all the draw calls that used the program, all the bufferDatas that changed a buffer, etc.

title: Differing program versions are not supported in the UI
body: Although most program information is captured in the version, only the live info is used in the UI

title: Implement texture history
body: Should show off the complete upload history (stack traces, source content (such as image urls, etc)). Bonus would be to allow the user to step through the upload calls to see the texture as it changes - this could help with texSubImage2D-heavy dynamic textures.

title: Ensure texture direction is correct in preview
body: Currently always flipping - may be a better idea to snoop the UNPACK_FLIP_Y_WEBGL state for a texture to see what happened.

title: Texture inspector preview for cubemaps should have fancy 3d view mode
body: In addition to the individual faces it would be cool to allow a free-look mode that puts the viewer at the center of the final cube map.

title: Texture inspector preview does not support cube maps
body:
There are two ways to do this:
- replay all calls on just the face interested in
- build a shader that properly picks a side against the final cube map

The advantage of the latter is that if there is any RTT going on you'll see it - if you just replay you won't get any dynamic changes.

title: Support pop-out mode
body:
Already kind of working (set usePopup = true at the top of HostUI.js), but needs surfacing.

A browser bug may prevent this in the near term, as it seems WebGL in popups causes Chromium to freak out and break rendering.

If that can be solved there still may not be a good way to do dynamic inline/popup switching as the replay canvas must be recreated and that may break things (as currently that's not supported). A global option of where to display things, or even a page reload between switches, may be good enough.

title: Generate pretty return values in trace
body: Currently calls that return values, such as getParameter(ARRAY_BUFFER_BINDING), will print out nasty values - they should print the same values as the arguments (with clickable links/etc)

title: Show resources used this frame
body:
Such as used this frame, written this frame, etc.

As resource state changes/etc, the UI would have to update.

Can probably fit in with the existing alive/dead tracker.

title: Resource display toolbar options
body: Allow choice of alive/dead/all and live value/trace value - set and propagate, all views must then make sure they pull the correct versions.

title: Implement Timeline tab
body:
Multiple timelines:
- lifetime: show resource allocations/deletions/uploads/etc
- per-frame: show draws/uploads/etc

title: Implement State tab
body: Show the state in a pretty way

title: Left listing enhancements
body:
The scroll position gets lost when switching tabs.

Allow for keyboard selection changes (up/down? may be overridden by page?).

title: Options system/UI
body: Add a UI for configuring capture/replay options, as well as storage for the settings. If running in-page maybe save in a page cookie, otherwise marshal back to the parent extension so that they are saved globally?

title: Frame listing management
body: Add the ability to capture/delete frames from the listing.

title: Sexy up the page overlays
body: Currently the page overlay buttons (capture/ui) and notifications are ugly. They should be pretty!

title: Show global stats for texture/buffer memory usage
body: The Textures and Buffers tabs should show (maybe in left listing bottom) the total bytes allocated of their respective types.

title: Programs should show attribute bindings
body: Currently program.attribBindings is not presented anywhere. Because of this, the ordinals displayed may not match up to reality.

title: Custom trace markers and object names
body: Allow applications to instrument themselves by injecting custom messages into the trace. Also allow for custom object names (currently partially supported by setting displayName on any WebGL object upon creation).

title: Trace render inspector sizing options
body: Copy the options from the Textures tab for 100%/Fit sizing.

title: SurfaceInspector pop out mode
body: Enable the entire trace/texture inspectors to pop out into a new window (with its UI).

title: Trace render inspector picker
body: Support switching between framebuffers, attachments (color/depth), sizing modes, etc.

title: Force draw modes: wireframe, shaded, etc
body: Not sure of the best way to accomplish wireframe, but shaded view could be done by always forcing a simple fragment shader on all programs when drawing.

title: Draw call functions: isolate, dependencies, script
body:
Select a draw call and get a list of all resources used for that call (programs/shaders, textures, buffers, render targets, etc).

Build the script required to draw just that call - this would allow for extracting models/etc in their entirety.

title: Buffer.constructVersion does not support bufferSubData
body:
Currently all future updates to the buffer after the initial bufferData are ignored. This means that the pattern of bufferData with just a size followed by bufferSubData updates yields empty results.

Seen here in the second to last buffer created:
http://webglsamples.googlecode.com/hg/spacerocks/spacerocks.html

title: Cubemaps not working
body:
http://webglsamples.googlecode.com/hg/fishtank/fishtank.html

Everything seems ok but the things that touch the cubemaps - possible binding issues?

title: Implement support for multiple framebuffers
body:
Need to implement resource tracking (via resources/framebuffer.js + renderbuffer.js) and UI to switch between the active buffer on the output HUD.

It all 'works' right now, but the output HUD will only show the contents of the current framebuffer during stepping.

Demos that hit it:
http://webglsamples.googlecode.com/hg/electricflower/electricflower.html
http://webglsamples.googlecode.com/hg/field/field.html

title: Bad texture uploads or invalid bindings
body:
Need to investigate what the page is doing during texture upload:
http://webglsamples.googlecode.com/hg/imagesphere/imagesphere.html

The replay has all the textures as the same. Many possible causes. Would be useful to have a resource browser...

title: Demos using tdl often fail with shader errors
body:
The following demos fail on calls to compileShader() for no reason. It seems to be possible to work around this by removing all refresh() calls made on shader operations, however it's unreliable.

http://webglsamples.googlecode.com/hg/aquarium/aquarium.html
http://webglsamples.googlecode.com/hg/spacerocks/spacerocks.html

title: Implement texSubImage2D
body: Required for http://media.tojicode.com/q2bsp/ (and others)

title: Find a good way to delineate frames
body: Currently using setTimeout(..., 0) in hopes of getting an event, but this is not always reliable. May be possible to use MozAfterPaint in Firefox, but need a WebKit solution too.

title: Corrupt buffer data in replay
body:
This demo (as well as some others) have corrupt buffer data in the replay view:
http://learningwebgl.com/lessons/lesson10/index.html

Not sure if this is bad uploads (maybe bufferSubData?) or bad drawing.

title: Replay not working
body:
Sometimes the replay shows nothing - even if it should show _something_.
Most/all of the demos here show this:
http://www.ibiblio.org/e-notes/webgl/webgl.htm

Also happens on http://media.tojicode.com/q3bsp/ sometimes (randomly?)

Even if things fail to draw, the canvas should still be cleared, so maybe it's a context setup failure?

title: Blending/depth test broken
body:
At least under Chromium/Windows, any demo disabling/enabling GL_BLEND or GL_DEPTH_TEST is broken.

Can be seen here:
http://learningwebgl.com/lessons/lesson09/index.html

Suspect it's an ANGLE bug, as this code demonstrates:
gl.disable(gl.DEPTH_TEST);
var value = gl.getParameter(gl.DEPTH_TEST);
console.log(value); // will print true

Also possible to see it here:
http://media.tojicode.com/q3bsp/ (so long as the replay works) - will only end up seeing the sky, almost as if the depth buffer is inverted

title: Turn.js not working on newer browsers
body:
Hi, I have been using turn.js for a while and have become quite fond of it.  However, lately I have noticed that on newer versions of Chrome it appears not to be working - even the demos on the site remain static.  The code on my page worked up until about a week ago, at which point I could no longer flip the pages - even though the code remained the same.  I also know the code is not faulty because it works on my old Dell machine, as well as on my Galaxy S8.  I am currently using Chrome 59.0.3071.115 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable), and it is not working for this.  I would turn to another flipbook API,  but I have grown quite fond of this one and would hate to stop using it.  How could I fix this issue?

Any help is appreciated.

title: Fix incompatibility with jQuery 3
body:
This is fix for issues #569 #589 #562 #573

In jQuery 3 they changed internal implementation of height() method. Before it used offsetHeight to return height value of the element. Now it uses value from getBoundingClientRect().

title: Make the package installable via npm/yarn
body:
This PR contains all the changes needed to make the package available via `npm install turn.js` or `yarn add turn.js`. 

Apart from adding a package.json file and removing the IIFE wrapper I have not changed any of the functionalities of the library. I have also pinpointed the version of jQuery to `1.12.0` because other versions were breaking the page flip mechanism (there's another issue for that, opened by someone else).

title: Support for NPM / Yarn
body:
Currently the package can only be downloaded and dropped into your project + loaded with a <script> tag.

Ideally it would be better if you could `npm install turn.js` or `yarn add turn.js`.

I have created [this repository](https://github.com/igghera/turn.js) as a fork of this project and added a package.json file to the project. I have also published it to NPM. I'll send a PR soon

title: Issues when turning hard pages with display single
body:
If the display option is set to "single",
    - the first hard page won't turn when the corner is dragged
    - an error will be shown when dragged/turning the last hard page:
        **Uncaught b {name: "TurnJsError", message: ""609" is not a valid page"}**
        (where 609 exceeded the maximum number of pages (608) by 1)

Is there any possible solution to this?

I have also a feature request:
If someone removed the class "hard" from pages after the flipbook is being initialized
and while the display is "single", the plugin should check if the page is hard or not before dragging from the corner; thus avoiding those issues.

title: Update to jQuery 3.1.1 from the 1.7 version, breaks the flipbook

As the title says, I have taken your basic example for turnjs, and implemented it into a website only to find that it did not work. The version used on the site of jQuery is 3.1.1, where your demo is 1.7, when trying the basic example with the same change, I get the same broken flipbook.

To describe the break, the bottom corner is relocated to the middle of the page and doesn't fully work (unless on a touch screen, where I can grab it when it appears), and on flipping of the page it is as if I am tearing the book at the seam.

Anyone have any insight into a fix for this?

title: Request on update for current licensing status in 2016
body:
Does anyone know the current licensing status of turn.js? Version 4 appears to be freely available on the website, however there are inconsistencies on whether a license applies for commercial use (for either version 3 or version 4):
- The Download link on the website links to version 4, just above the Github link
- The licensing comment on the website (http://turnjs.com/#licensing) refers to a BSD license and states the project is available on Github, however it also states that the license doesn't cover the version 4 release (the link to the v4 release PDF appears to be broken)
- The version 4 download ZIP contains no licensing information, however it does refer to the 'commercial version' in the API docs contained within
- The Github page states version 3 is available under 'a non-commercial BSD license'
- In this issue - https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/issues/61 - the author states commercial use is ok with an MIT license
- In this issue - https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/issues/342 - the author states commercial use requires purchasing a license

There are a number of open issues covering licensing, these include:
- https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/issues/491
- https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/issues/488
- https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/issues/486
- https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/issues/474
- https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/issues/473
- https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/issues/464
- https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/issues/287

From these, it appears the author is no longer supporting the project nor responding to issues or e-mails; however he is still active on Twitter (https://twitter.com/blasten). He now appears to work for Google.

Last month he asked a Twitter user to contact him by e-mail to enquire about licensing (https://twitter.com/blasten/status/698610530538254336).

I've e-mailed Emmanuel enquiring about licensing for a commercial project and haven't heard back; I've just tweeted him today and will update this issue if I hear back from him.

If anyone else knows what the correct licensing status of this project is, please do share!

_Other relevant links (quite possibly old and no longer in use as they are no longer linked from the home page):_
- Licensing purchase system: http://turnjs.com/get
- Licensing docs on wiki: http://turnjs.com/docs/Licensing

title: turn.js issue with image crop plugins
body:
Hi all,
I am creating a photo album flipbook in which most of the pages have image uploading an cropping feature.
![screen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11991383/7199589/9a38fe2c-e513-11e4-9e0a-fc9390d25625.jpg)

Please check the above image. As you can see, the first page contains 2 image upload areas and second page with one. I used croppic ( http://www.croppic.net/) for this feature. The problem is that It works only for first page and and for first time only. And we can add as many instances of the plugin in the first page it works. But the upload/crop plugin instance on the second page do not work. And if we turn the page, first page instances also get not working. We tried it with other plugins also and the result was same. title: Please; this needs your attention!

The project is not at all under the BSD license, so, Please refrain from miscommunicating facts and let people know the truth, right away! (It not even Open Source, by definition, let alone BSD.) 
Besides that, your work is good, but I personally would better be inclined towards a permissive license, rather than a restrictive one. And, the updates could have had an extra price, to support the development. Anyways, that's strictly a personal viewpoint. 

Thanks! 

Anime.sh

title: Proprietary software
body:
If any of the four freedoms is denied for whatever reason, the license is considered non-free.
The software is non-free (ie proprietary) due to the non-commercial clause.
The effect that I think you're trying to achieve is having a say when people sell derived versions of your software.
If this is so, the resolution may be to dual license the software under a copyleft license and a commercial one.
I suggest the version 3 of the GPLv3 (or, alternatively, AGPLv3), which, in addition to being copyleft forbid "TiVoization" and protect you from any contributors' patent claims (which may otherwise apply even if the contributor signed over their copyright to you).
P.S. I also think there's an unreported issue, but as-is, I'm not inclined to support the project with a bug report and I won't be using it either.

body:

Eitherway,  I am having an issue with getting the count of pages dynamically for each book clicked.  Instead of like the TurnJS website book shelf we now only use one CSS and one JS file for all the books.

I would like to set the number dynamically when book is clicked on.  Some reason I can not get the value back until the when: turning: function fires, but by that time I am already in the flipbook.turn method.  
So when I try to do something like this to get the number of pages option:

```
 flipbook.turn{(
 duration:1000,
 pages: $(this).turn('pages')
 //pages: 16  // originally set as a static value. Need it dynamic.
 })

I can not get the number of pages on the selected book.  I have tried setting a global variable and tried getting the number of pages from the addPage function but for some reason it is being seen in the .turn{()}

title: Exclude elements
body:
hello @blasten,

wouldn't it be nice to have a `exclude` option to let the user specify elements inside the turn container that have not to be transformed and treated as page?
alternatively, if you prefer, it could also be `elements` or `items` and behaves in the opposite way.

this parameter could accept a DOM element, a well-formed jQuery selector, a jQuery object or a function that returns any of the latter value.

a concrete case: i need to have some extra elements with `position: absolute` inside the book and rely on its `position: relative`, page placement and size to accurately position them. my current workaround is: write them outside the book and, only after turnjs has been initalized, execute a relocation inside the book with `.append()`.

what do you think?

P.S: besides, it would also be delicious to leverage on a new event fired when the initialization of the book is completed, something like `initialized` or `init`.

title: [enhancement] Add missing bower.json.
body:
#### Hey, maintainer(s) of blasten/turn.js!

We at [VersionEye](https://www.versioneye.com/signup?promo_code=BOWER) are working hard to keep up the quality of the bower's registry.

We just finished our initial analysis of the quality of the Bower.io registry:

**7530** - registered packages, _224_ of them doesnt exists anymore;

We analysed **7306**  existing packages and  **1070** of them don't have bower.json on the master branch ( _that's where a Bower client pulls a data_ ).

Sadly, your library `blasten/turn.js` is one of them.

Can you spare **15** minutes to help us to make Bower better?

Just add a new file `bower.json` and  change attributes.

```
{
  "name": "blasten/turn.js",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": "path/to/main.css",
  "description": "please add it",
  "license": "Eclipse",
  "ignore": [
    ".jshintrc",
    "**/*.txt"
  ],
  "dependencies": {
    "<dependency_name>": "<semantic_version>",
    "<dependency_name>": "<Local_folder>",
    "<dependency_name>": "<package>"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "<test-framework-name>": "<version>"
  }
}

```

Read more about bower.json [on the official spefication](http://bower.io/#defining-a-package) and nodejs [semver](https://github.com/isaacs/node-semver#ranges) library has great examples of proper versioning.

**NB!** Please _validate_ your bower.json with _jsonlint_ before commiting your updates.

Thank you!

Timo,
twitter: @versioneye
email: timo@versioneye.com
[VersionEye](https://www.versioneye.com/signup?promo_code=BOWER) - no more legacy software!

title: Dynamically removing pages is very slow
body:
I have a 40 page book, if I dynamically remove every page (except the cover) using `$('#book').turn('removePage', i)` it is very slow.

Using the Chrome timeline I was able to measure it at ~2.24 seconds on my 2012 Macbook Air. Running the same operation on a new iPad (iOS6) takes about 14 seconds. Looking in the timeline, there is a whole bunch of rendering calls to Recalculate Style and Layout.

![screen shot 2013-08-02 at 14 42 58](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/26971/901192/967d68d4-fb79-11e2-893d-6ff13969ad2f.png)

Can this be done more efficiently by batching the style changes so that the browser isn't forced to do a layout after each one? Or possibly batching the removal of pages by using something like `$('#book').turn('removePage', [2,3,4,5,6,7,8..])`.

From quickly debugging what's going on it seems that the issue might be the repeated calls to `_pageSize()` (stack trace: `turnMethods.removePage -> turnMethods._movePages -> move -> _pageSize()`) which calls the `$.fn.width()` and `$.fn.height()` height methods (which force a style recalculation).

Can you advise if there are any hacks that you can think of to make this faster? Also, is this something that you think will be improved in an upcoming release?  

By the way I'm using the licensed version of turn.js (4th release)

title: zoom out broken within fixed position overlay
body:
I have flipbook with zoom plugin within a fixed position overlay. When zooming out and scrolled down the page, the transition position is calculated wrong.
This is because the zoomOut function mixes .offset() (offset relative to document, which takes scrollOffset into account even for fixed containers) and .findPos() (offset relative to offsetParent, which is the fixed element).
This results in transitioning to something like {x:400,y:5000} when scrolled down the page, insteadof {x:400,y:400}.

title: zoom.js drag not working on mobile devices [fix]
body:
added this line of code at 
line : 816
method : _eTouchStart

```
    data.dragging = true;

    data.draggingCur = point2D(
            event.originalEvent.touches[0].pageX,
            event.originalEvent.touches[0].pageY
        );
```

*_eMouseDown is not registering on mobile but _eTouchStart was

I'd issue a pull request but I can't find the zoom.js library on your account

title: Conflict between TurnJS and Uplodifive
body:
Hi

I have a project which uses TurnJS and Uploadifive (http://www.uploadify.com), and there appears to be a conflict. Without Uploadifive, TurnJS works perfectly, however once I put an instance of Uploadifive into a div which forms a TurnJS page, then Uploadifive does not work, though TurnJS still works fine.

I have confirmed it is a conflict, by moving the Uploadifive instance outside of the TurnJS controlled divs, and it works as expected. As of now, the only solution I have had is to place the Uploadifive instance in a separate html page, and use an <iframe>, thus my conclusion is, when TurnJS modifies the DOM, it modifies the Uploadifive instance such that it breaks. I am still playing with the order of execution to see if I can find a simple solution, though hoping someone here can suggest something

cheers
SockThief

I've managed to piece together the following from the Bible example and PHP to Javascript tutorials that I have found. I know a little bit of html/php/js but i'm by no means an expert. This also shows for the page_content if I remove the line showing the title. This may be the cause of the other issue I am seeing: Problem/SymptomI'm finding that the content on the last page is not shown (there was an issue with the first page also but i've just now discovered that this was due to an extra element in the HTML of the template page). FYI with 4 Custom Post Types the book goes cover/page1, page2/page3, page4/backcover. The pages are also out of order which I believe is to do with this being an object rather than an array but I am unsure how to change that. (Of course, I also haven't considered what will happen if the content is bigger than a single page but one thing at a time!) Can anyone point me in the right direction? I only have the site locally at the moment using Mamp, however here is the code: Single-Leaf Template - http://pastebin.com/UMirbBSP Main Plugin File - http://pastebin.com/r622RWgw PopulatePages - http://pastebin.com/eadwf7DP Thank you for your time.

title: Page turn too intensive for iOS.
body:
When turning the page "Automatically" on iOS, some intensive process takes place making the webpage almost unusable. This happens when I call the $(flipbook).turn('page', pageIndex) function.

However it does not slow down when I manually curl a page by dragging it, it becomes slow again only when I release and the flipbook turns to a previous or next page. The animation is smooth when the page curl returns to the current page.

By making some profiling it seems calling $(flipbook).turn('page', pageIndex); invokes a lot of jQuery events. My two cents is that the bottleneck feels like the jQuery event propagation mechanisms and event handlers. ( versus animation limitations )

title: Issue in rtl and Scissor.js
body:
Hello,

There seems to be an issue when the direction is rtl and i'm using scissor.js.
The solution would be to flip the order of the two double pages.

Since Turn.js and Scissor.js are not fully integrated i'd suggest a new option in Turn.js which would be called Double Class

for example:

```
$('#flipbook').turn({doubleClass: "double"});
```

What this code would do is call scissor.js on elements with selected class, then (if the direction is rtl) it will reverse the order of the two parts of the element so that the order would become correct.

This might be a convenient solution instead of coding the solution manually for each project.

title: Bug in numeration
Full spread video
body:
Hi!

Payd customer here ;o) - Anyway, we are building a catalogue using turn.js right now and have an ege-case scenario here it seems. The client wants us to have a video that spans two pages on one of the spreads in the magazine.

I first tried just inserting two pages and then have the video element on the first page - My thinking was that with z-indexing, absolute positioning and sizing I could force the video on top of both pages and have it cover both. This did not work (of course) as turn.js imposes strict overflow hidden on pages.

Next I tried looking at scissor, but that just duplicates my video element and I still only have video visible / playing on the first page.

My next approach was to just have it on one page, set own-size, specify a double width for that page and when the user turns I apply $(this).turn("display", "single"); - This sort of works, but I loose my next/prev arrows due to the (even stricter) overflow hidden applied by turn.js, and then when I go onwards to the next page everything is messed up, as the internal page count doesn't match the catalogue layout - a simple example:

page 1 - page 2 & 3 - page 4&5 as one page - page 6

That internally translates to:

index 1  - index 2 - index 3 - index 4 - index 5

Here turn.js will show the cover page fine and auto center, next spread is shown fine as two pages (index 2 & 3), next my combined single page spread is shown fine but when going to page 6 it shows both my single page and the last (back) page (index 4 and 5)

This is also very wrong and broken. So my ultimate question is:

Is there any "correct" way I can overlay an element across two pages?

Thank you!!

title: 4th gen source / domains license / IOS glitches / sluggishness on Chrome/Firefox/Opera/Safari
body:
I did not receive any reply on emails to blasten@gmail.com, so I will try here.

I am considering purchasing a (4th release) license for turn.js, however I do have a few questions:
1.  It seems you have not open-sourced the newest release of turn.js? Will we get the full source code when we purchase a commercial license? This is important for us, because we will in all likelihood need to make some modifications to the script to work for our scenario.
2.  The order page only talks about a license for ‘up to 5 domains’. Our HTML5 application would also be distributed for offline usage (packaged with XULRunner probably) and as a hybrid app for iOS and Android. What kind of license would we need?
3.  There is a jarring visual glitch on all iOS devices we have tried (iPad 1/3, iOS 5/6, iPhone 4S, iPod Touch 4th gen), and it manifests with all demos on turnjs.com: after each page turn, the left page will flicker back to the previous page briefly, then return to the new page. It only fully goes away after turning all pages once. It is 100% reproducible for me on all devices. This glitch really breaks the effect of the page turns, so at this point it seems it is not fully ready yet for iPad/iPhone use? Or is this fixed in the latest release?
4.  Performance is good on IE9 and iOS, but the page turn animation gets quite choppy on Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Opera and Safari (latest builds, all on Windows 8 x64). Safari is slightly better than the rest. Again, looking at the demos on turnjs.com. It happens especially when zooming in. For our needs would need to display books fullscreen, maximum size. This is also manifest on fast desktop machines with good video cards. Looking at the CSS through Web Inspector, it seems no 3d hardware accelerated CSS3 transforms are used? Is this different in turnjs 4th release? If the animation is too slow to use full-screen, we cannot really use it. Of course we would check beforehand if a browser supports GPU acceleration, if not, we would default to a simple fade animation.

Looking forward to your answers and using your wonderful script!

title: How can I insert a page dynamically?

``` javascript
book.turn('addPage',
    newPage, // element created from data
    book.turn('pages') - 1 // I want to insert before last 2 hard covers
);
```

But this just **overwrote** last 2 hard covers! If I watching the total pages I would get `4`, never increased.

I noticed in the source code [line 331](https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/blob/master/turn.js#L331), whether the judgement is necessary? Why insert a page without increasing the total page count?

title: Customizing
body:
Hello, 

I would like to buy this script but to be honest am not sure if configuring it will be beyond me. I currently work with a flash version but want to upgrade to a jquery one. I have some questions which will hopefully let me decide. 

Firstly is it possible to use image and link map links. What I mean is clicking an area to display a pop up image or open a new web window with the link address (they are the most important things). If it is possible then I would need code examples on how to do this - at the moment I am very visual with little code knowledge. 

Secondly is it possible to configure things like turning off zoom and resize, I would prefer one size and browser window scroll bars. Also, I don't want menu items etc initially. 

Last question. Is it possible (and easy) to add a navigation page if I need to? Something like naming pages with anchors so that if future updates to a publication occur the navigation doesn't go out of sync.

title: Version:4.0.7 When turning a page, it turns twice
body:
Reproducible at turnjs4/samples/basic/index.html.

When you turn the first page with your mouse starting from a corner and you then let the page go at the left side, it jumps back and then turns instead of just dropping to the right.

We have this behavior also in our flipbook:

Events called in this order: (no start since we simulate a peel), turning, end (pageObject=false) , start, end (pageObject=true) , end (pageObject=false), turned.

Normal behavior: start, turning , end (pageObject=true) , end (pageObject=false), turned.

This behavior wasn't present in the version 3. The bug was already present in version 4.0.0

title: turnjs v4 dev is a lot harder to follow

I can do a manual diff but it is still a pain to use emails and zips to update the code instead of submodules and github.

title: Can I "free" the swipe function on first and last pages?
body:
Hi everyone,

I am working on a project for an iPad app. The app has a built-in swipe functionality to change between pages. One of the pages will be a webview window with a turn.js-magazine in it (as a multi-paged ad).

It appears that turn.js prevents the app's swipe function from kicking in on the last page (which would be what I'd want), so the reader can't leave the ad (since swiping would be the only possible way out).

Is there a way to disable the turn.js-"swipe block" for both ends of the magazine?
It appears to me that turn.js says "There can't be any right-to-left swipe on the last page and I will actively assign a non-function to any that occur", would it be possible to make that "I don't care about any right-to-left-swipes on the last page, but go ahead if you think that helps you"? (The same thing for left-to-right swipes on the first page.)

Any advice on this would be greatly appreciated!
Many thanks!
Per

title: Corner-peel animation without mouseover?
body:
Hi everyone,

I am looking for a simple way to inform the reader that the page they see is "swipable".

On the desktop version, there is that nice mouseover effect of a peeling corner.
Would it be possible to fire that effect without a mouseover? So that, for instance, iPad users have that visual clue as well?
Would it even be possible to have that repeated every ten seconds or something?

Something like $('magazine').peel('br', 10000); ?

Many thanks in advance for your advice!
Per

title: Swipe and Zoom on iPad
body:
I want to use turn.js to create online catalog, dedicated for ipad. I want to keep ability to zoom (i left user-scalable attribute with its default value). Swipe gesture to turn pages would be also useful, like on http://www.turnjs.com/ but when you try to zoom, even on official website, pages will turn after pinch gesture. 

I suppose it happens because start of pinch gesture works the same way like swipe - I mean one finger slide. There is condition to turn the page only when touchmove event is made by only one finger (e.originalEvent.touches.length == 1) but I guess before swipe (one finger) becomes pinch (two fingers touches the screen) browser sees first event swipe, next event pinch separately. Same way when somebody take fingers off the screen (it never happens in exactly the same time). 

I tried to change e.originalEvent.touches to e.originalEvent.changedTouches to get count of fingers that were used in event, but it also doesn't work like i want it to.

Any simple idea how to fix it?

title: pagesInDOM limitation & buttons hide issue
body:
Hi Emmanuel, as you already should know I did an integration of turn.js with Magic Zoom (first I tried jQZoom & Cloud Zoom but none of them gives me as much features as Magic Zoom & I really needed a activate/deactivate the zoom by clicking the page).

I make this intro because I found that all the three zoom scripts got disabled after the sixth page of the catalog. On my first attempts I replaced the zoom activation of jQZoom & Cloud Zoom when hovering with a click but the issue was still there after clicking the seventh page. I temporary solved this issue by enabling a live clicking on the jQuery code but after acquiring the Magic Zoom script their support found that the problem lied on the pagesInDOM number.

Increasing this number solved the zoom problem but introduced a new one. Normally my catalogs will have 12 pages, as you can see here: http://grosmercat.iritec.es/digitalizacion/visualizacionPDF.php?file_name=horeca_05_centro_04-_04-30-2012_22-16-44, but I don't wanna limit my system to work with 12 only but to work as an standard that dynamically auto-adjust its size. I use turnjs.com scripting to solve IE issue and to recreate the shadow & side-buttons features but modified it a bit to include another buttons trying to simulate what happens here: http://issuu.com/folleto_oferta_gm/docs/gm09_catalunyaislas?mode=window&pageNumber=1 here you have the modified code: http://grosmercat.iritec.es/digitalizacion/js/prueba.js (compare with yours using Notepad++ or Araxis Merge to easily see the changes)

For some reason after changing the pagesInDOM number to 40 to test, when the catalog has less that 12 and finish with an even page the shadow appears wrongly when the catalog moves to close: http://grosmercat.iritec.es/digitalizacion/visualizacionPDF.php?file_name=euroleafletes_05-02-2012_18-45-06#8 Is there any way to change this number dynamically to avoid this issue? Are my changes correct? I also have problems hiding the secondary buttons I made. I hope you can help me. Thanks in advance.

title: Bring back "end" event
body:
First of all, kudos for your work on this library. It's quite easy to use and works well on the handful of browsers and devices I tried it with.

While browsing the Reference, I noticed the "end" event has been removed from the latest version, although "start" remains. However, I find myself in need of that event. Is it possible to have it re-added?

My use case is as follows: I want an element to be displayed to the left of a magazine while it is "closed" (that is, only page 1 is showing), as if it were page 0. When page 1 is flipped, thus making the magazine display pages 2 and 3, I want page 2 to cover that element.

I attempted to implement this behaviour by defining the element and using absolute positioning to move it to the desired place, and then adjusting its z-index whenever it is supposed to stand above or below the magazine and its pages. I managed to get it to work for page flips with the "turn" and "turned" events, but I still need to take actions when the user starts and stops dragging the folded page even when the page isn't flipped -- hence the need for an "end" event to complement the "start" event.

Right now I resorted to version 0.11 (at commit 9a978a2526ca9429ca5db35509aa0ed91f42a7de) to implement the desired behaviour.

Thanks

title: One way looped navigation
body:
Hello there !

First of all, I wanted to thank you for this great jQuery plugin you made there ! It's just awesome and the API is of very high standard.

After discovering your plugin, I tried to play with the code a little bit and I finally got stuck at some point !

Here is what I'm trying to do :

I've got my book in the background, but contents are displayed only on the right page of the book. So I activated only the bottom right and top right corner to navigate through the book in forward mode only. Everything is working fine, I can navigate through all the pages until the last one.

I've tried to add one last trick to this : when the user reaches the last page of the book, I want that the 2 forward navigation corners to still be activate and to redirect the user to the very first page of the book.

I've tried a bunch of things (playing with the addPage & removePage of the API and so on), but nohting worked. I don't know if I'm doing it right, so that's why I decided to try my luck here.

I really hope that you'll be able to give me the answers I've been seeking for.

Thank you a lot again for this super tool !

PS : Sorry for my not-so-perfect english, it's not my native language ^^

title: Non-WebKit browsers don't get gradients.
body:
Non-WebKit browsers don't get to see the gradient-based page curve effect when flipping pages.

https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/blob/master/turn.js#L899 and https://github.com/blasten/turn.js/blob/master/turn.js#L907 are most likely the culprit: there's only -webkit- prefixes there. It would be nice to add -ms-, -o-, -moz- as well.

title: Re-enable addon after closing tab / window
body:
Similar to https://github.com/ChrisAntaki/disable-webrtc-firefox/issues/35 it looks like we can not disable WebRTC on a tab by tab basis. But can we temporary disable WebRTC globally, and then have it re-enabled when the user closes the tab or closes the window?

The use case is as follows:
- by default I want to disable WebRTC
- but sometimes I need WebRTC e.g. for a half an hour call
- I'm a stupid human who then forgets to disable WebRTC after the call again leaving me exposed

If we could scope the WebRTC disabling to a tab / session concept, that wold be great. Is this technically possible?

title: Feature Request: whitelist URLs or individual tabs
body:

Maybe this is not possible or sensible as in https://github.com/ChrisAntaki/disable-webrtc-firefox/issues/33 ... but it would be useful. 
If it is not possible, I would suggest briefly documenting this in a paragraph on the code page as I would think that this issue will come up more and more with increasing online video conferences etc. Thanks!!

title: Addon doesn't work on Waterfox
body:
I'd already tried preventing the WebRTC leak using "media.peerconnection.enabled = false" in  prefs, but it didn't work, so I tried using your addon instead. However, [whoer.net](https://whoer.net/#extended) still showed WebRTC as enabled. 

At the time, I was using the latest version of Waterfox and was connecting to the Web using my Android mobile as a hotspot. The latter was connected to the data packet I'd purchased from a Thai ISP called AIS. Here's the Wikipedia article on them: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Info_Service

Thailand requires registration to use any ISP, but restricts tourists to a specific SIM which enables the authorities to track users. The SIM expires automatically once the user leaves the country. That might be the reason why WebRTC continues to leak users' IP, but I'm not sure.

title: Verbosity in status message
body:
Hi!

It's a nice plugin. Though I would suggest you to change a status label when WebRTC is enabled (because a current one is slightly confusing). So my proposed change:

`WebRTC is not disabled. Be careful.` => `WebRTC is *enabled*. Be careful.`

The thing is that the double negation "not disabled" might be overlooked by a user such as me. After locating the word "disabled" I assume that everything is OK. 

Thanks for considering my issue.

Best regards,
dd

title: Light / more flexible mode, which asks user for permission for peer connection
body:
There is a hook for createOffer/createAnswer, which enables extensions to allow or deny these calls. So extension could show dialog similar to that used to ask user for permission to use cam or mic, and then enable WebRTC connections only if user explicitly granted that permission. This seems like a good alternative to completely disabled WebRTC.

For more info see this [article with **proof of concept extension**](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2015/09/controlling-webrtc-peerconnections-with-an-extension/) and [WebRTC Privacy page on Mozilla Wiki](https://wiki.mozilla.org/Media/WebRTC/Privacy).

title: Can't you just set media.peerconnection.enabled to false to disable WebRTC?
body: Can't you just set media.peerconnection.enabled to false to disable WebRTC? What does this addon offer additionally?

title: Not compatible with e10s
body:
Is this add-on compatible with Electrolysis (e10s)? Electrolysis is the new architecture of Firefox and Mozilla already rolls out some stable Firefox versions with e10s enabled.

More information:
- https://arewee10syet.com/
- https://wiki.mozilla.org/Electrolysis

---

According to [ACL](https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/addon/add-on-compatibility-reporter/) this add-on is not compatible with e10s.

title: persist enabled webrtc
body:
After clicking the 'disable webrtc' icon to enable webrtc, and restarting firefox, then webrtc is disabled again. The only way to enable webrtc persistently is to disable this extension it seems.

(Because `ublock origin` blocks `webrtc` to some extent, and sites like airbnb do not work without webrtc, sometimes it's sufficient and more convenient to keep webrtc enabled by default. But the comfort of disabling it by the click of an icon is still appreciated.)

title: airbnb.com broken
body:
Learned from [Fat-Free](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/fat-free-firefox/) Fox documentation:

> WebRTC Private IP Address Leak: Note that enabling this option will only block private IP address leak due to WebRTC. It will not disable WebRTC completely. Firefox Hello would still be usable as before.

Airbnb can not be used with your add-on (no animation on the main page on aribnb.com, defunct search filters, etc), but Airbnb can be used with Fat-Free Firefox ("Block private IP address leak due to WebRTC (applicable for Firefox 42 and above)" enabled).

title: It does not work with 1a.org
body:
It does not work with 1a.org

Hi. I installed the Disable WebRTC 1.0.11 Firefox 45.0.2 extension and try the privacy of public IP with 1a.org web site, public IP is still displayed. Moreover, the same symptom occurs when you install another extension of another company, "WebRTC Control". Therefore, it seems that modifications that make these extensions to Firefox settings are not sufientes to block the WebRTC protocol. The funny thing is that in IRON browser extension "Prevent WebRTC 1.0.8 Leak" if it works and looks like it is because it has the option to set "Set IP WebRTC handling policy to Disable non-proxied UDP (force proxy)"
