It'd be nice to be able to whitelist a domain so that I can keep the add-on active and avoid having to turn it on and off when I need to test/use my applications.

title: Public IP
body:
I'm only continuing to post here to HELP YOU learn about your mistake.  I have a working addon already so I don't really care if you ever admit that you are mistaken or not. 

> > Essentially, many of the WebRTC "Here are your IPs" test pages are outdated. They'll still claim >> to show your ISP's public IP, even if you're behind a VPN. If you have this addon installed though, >> they'll just see your VPN's public IP
> > 
> > LAN IP addresses are not generated, the external IP address for that interface is (for a VPN, the >> exit portal of the VPN)

Let's set up the environment to be sure that you fully understand what I'm saying.

1) I am using a VPN.  Firefox is routed through this VPN. Every normal "what is my ip" website shows the IP of the VPN only.

2) Using **your addon**, every website that checks for WebRTC IP leaks shows my ISP's public IP.  **This is the WebRTC leak that is supposed to be blocked**.

Despite what you claim or whatever Mozilla's site claims about this new option, it does not work as an WebRTC leak prevention.

**USE A VPN FOR YOURSELF TO VERIFY AND DON'T JUST RELY ON WHAT "SHOULD" HAPPEN ACCORDING TO SOMEONE ELSE**

You can have all the reviews and comments removed that you wish but it does not change the fact that your addon does not work, and people will obviously see that for themselves.

Here's the PROOF.

My VPN's IP from whatismyip.com
![vpnip](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16733299/12372593/21bd214e-bc2c-11e5-9c68-b6aa96c79dc2.png)

Results of WebRTC leak test from https://diafygi.github.io/webrtc-ips/ with no addons enabled. Shows my lan ips and my ISP IP.
![rtc1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16733299/12372604/61ef4a6c-bc2c-11e5-828d-8dfdd682a1ca.png)

https://www.browserleaks.com/webrtc
![rtc2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16733299/12372616/ad6328f6-bc2c-11e5-9bde-15d41ed9abd7.png)

https://www.privacytools.io/webrtc.html
![rtc3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16733299/12372620/ce370e30-bc2c-11e5-8e1e-2460951bf936.png)

Everything the same, local ip and ISP ip are exposed, while on a VPN with no addons enabled.

The same tests, **with your addon enabled**
![t1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16733299/12372646/49f9ec36-bc2d-11e5-9987-83333f3bd9af.png)
![t2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16733299/12372648/4a0e6ee0-bc2d-11e5-969e-d57bda342e95.png)
![t3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16733299/12372647/4a0c01d2-bc2d-11e5-99a8-5bb7bad5c34a.png)

This shows, with absolute proof, that your addon does not work as it should. WebRTC leak is to block your real public ip from being exposed through a VPN.

Same tests, with your addon disabled, and WebRTC Control addon enabled.
![r1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16733299/12372664/8c3db406-bc2d-11e5-9c3a-fb749d9194e7.png)
![r2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16733299/12372665/8c77c448-bc2d-11e5-976a-e538da655541.png)
![r3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16733299/12372666/8c873e46-bc2d-11e5-9b00-e5b7e60006c6.png)

Works as it should to prevent public IP exposure through a VPN.

Please stop trying to convince me, or yourself, that your addon is working as it should. As I said before, if you think this is correct then change your name to "WebRTC Publically Identifiable IP Leaker".  

I have shown you with 100% absolute proof that your addon does not work.  Blocking your LAN IP's from being exposed is not the important part of the WebRTC leak.

Since you are a fan of posting search terms in some way to validate anything, here's one for you.  Read the first few sites that come up.

https://duckduckgo.com/?q=webrtc+security+flaw

> > "VPN users are facing a massive security flaw as websites can easily see their home IP-addresses >>through WebRTC."
> > 
> > "security researchers revealed a massive security flaw that enables website owner to easily see >>the real IP addresses of users through WebRTC, even if they are using a VPN"

If you still want to claim that any of these test sites are outdated and that would somehow make any difference --- the fact that the public ISP IP is being exposed is the only issue at hand.  It doesn't matter how the leak is tested or against what version of webrtc implementation it is tested against.. exposing the public ip is a failure.  If Mozilla wants to claim 

for what it's worth, just playing with the settings real quick

media.peerconnection.enabled = false; no webrtc leak
or
media.peerconnection.ice.default_address_only = true; hides lan ip but exposes public ip
or
media.peerconnection.ice.relay_only = true; hides all ips, no webrtc leak
but may still have exposure against a new detection method that these sites do not test for. according to mozilla's page

> > NOTE: does not hide your external IP address from the TURN server itself (see >> use_document_iceservers and default_iceservers to restrict to a TURN of your choice). 

Ultimately, the only way to be sure there is no IP leak is to disable WebRTC completely.

title: FF42+ allows finer grained configuration options
body:
With Firefox version 42 and up a new configuration is available which allows the user to return the default address without leaking the local ip: media.peerconnection.ice.default_address_only
- The default interface used for general routing is identified and only that address is used for candidate generation
- LAN IP addresses are not generated, the external IP address for that interface is (for a VPN, the exit portal of the VPN)
- If your router does not support 'hairpinning', a within-LAN call will end up being routed through an external TURN server
- NOT supported with e10s (only available in Nightly and DevEdition) yet (see bug 1194259)

Details: https://wiki.mozilla.org/Media/WebRTC/Privacy

title: Add a method to ask the user for every connection
body:
In Firefox 42 [a feature was added](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2015/09/controlling-webrtc-peerconnections-with-an-extension/) which allows add-ons to get information if a web service wants to use WebRTC.
I think implementing this here would be a nice idea too, so you only have to answer a question if you want to use WebRTC and otherwise you have no privacy impact.

An example implementation was published [on GitHub](https://github.com/fippo/plumber).

title: License note missing in file
body:
Can you please add this to /resources/happybonobo_disable_webrtc/lib/main.js

/\* This Source Code Form is subject to the terms of the Mozilla Public
- License, v. 2.0. If a copy of the MPL was not distributed with this
- file, You can obtain one at http://mozilla.org/MPL/2.0/. */

Please add license headers in the rest of your files for all of your work, and I will be glad to approve them in https://directory.fsf.org/wiki/Free_Software_Directory_talk:IceCat_extensions_%28proposed%29. Please confirm if you want to help us so I can have a look later.

title: network.http.speculative-parallel-limit
body:
There's a new risky setting that got active with firefox 40:
network.http.speculative-parallel-limit
Maybe setting this to 0 could be added to the disable webrtc addon.
Webrtc could then evolve to an addon giving a stringent, sane and secure default. Although I am open for adding another addon beside Disable webrtc.

body: Looks like a GREAT addition to firefox, and thanks.  When I try to also add to my mobile it isn't in the addins.  Can you update the package to support firefox mobile
